title: Fix panel content overflow and boundary bleeding
description:
## Problem
Panel content bleeding outside panel boundaries, text wrapping incorrectly into adjacent panels.

## Code Review Findings (2026-01-19)

### Panels Already Use Width Constraints

Found extensive use of lipgloss Width() in panels:
- ticker.go:128 - Width(m.width)
- spawn.go:146,169 - Width(w)
- metrics.go:125,151,191 - Width(w-2), Width(w-4)
- files.go:208,239 - Width(w-2), Width(w-4)
- history.go:145,169 - Width(w-2), Width(w-4)
- etc.

### Potential Remaining Issues
1. **Content generated without width constraint** before being placed in panel
2. **Text truncation** not applied to all user-generated content
3. **Vertical overflow** - height not constrained

## Fix Approach

### 1. Ensure All Content Respects Panel Width
```go
// Panel render pattern
func (p *Panel) View() string {
    content := p.renderContent()

    // Apply width constraint to ALL content
    constrained := lipgloss.NewStyle().
        Width(p.width - 2).  // Account for borders
        MaxWidth(p.width - 2).
        Render(content)

    return p.borderStyle.Render(constrained)
}
```

### 2. Add Height Clipping
```go
func clipHeight(content string, maxLines int) string {
    lines := strings.Split(content, "\n")
    if len(lines) <= maxLines {
        return content
    }
    return strings.Join(lines[:maxLines], "\n") + "\n..."
}
```

### 3. Apply TruncateWidth to User Content
```go
// Any user-provided text should be truncated
name := layout.TruncateWidthDefault(agent.Name, maxNameWidth)
task := layout.TruncateWidthDefault(agent.Task, maxTaskWidth)
```

## Unit Tests Required
```go
func TestPanelContentConstraint(t *testing.T) {
    panel := NewMetricsPanel()
    panel.SetSize(40, 20)
    panel.SetData(testData)

    rendered := panel.View()
    lines := strings.Split(rendered, "\n")

    for i, line := range lines {
        width := lipgloss.Width(line)
        if width > 40 {
            t.Errorf("line %d width %d exceeds panel width 40", i, width)
        }
    }
}

func TestVerticalOverflow(t *testing.T) {
    panel := NewHistoryPanel()
    panel.SetSize(40, 10)
    panel.SetData(largeHistoryData)

    rendered := panel.View()
    lines := strings.Split(rendered, "\n")

    if len(lines) > 10 {
        t.Errorf("panel has %d lines, max should be 10", len(lines))
    }
}
```

## E2E Test (VHS)
```tape
# panel_overflow_test.tape
Set Width 100
Set Height 30
Type "ntm dashboard --demo-data"
Sleep 2s
# Check that no content bleeds outside panel borders
Screenshot panel_boundaries.png

Set Width 60
Sleep 1s
# Narrow width should truncate, not overflow
Screenshot panel_narrow.png
```

## Verification
- [ ] No text extends past panel right border
- [ ] Vertical content clips when exceeding panel height
- [ ] User-generated names/tasks are truncated
- [ ] Works at narrow and wide terminal widths
close_reason: Verified: All panels already implement proper overflow handling. Multi-line panels use FitToHeight for vertical clipping. Width constraints via lipgloss Width() in place. Ticker panel is single-line with Width constraint. All panel tests pass.

title: E2E Tests: ntm errors command with real tmux sessions
description:
## Purpose
End-to-end tests for the ntm errors command with real tmux sessions and error injection.

## Test Script

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# e2e_ntm_errors.sh
set -euo pipefail

LOG_PREFIX="[E2E-ERRORS]"
TEST_SESSION="ntm_e2e_errors_$$"
PASSED=0
FAILED=0

log() { echo "$LOG_PREFIX $(date +%H:%M:%S) $*"; }
pass() { log "PASS: $1"; ((PASSED++)); }
fail() { log "FAIL: $1"; ((FAILED++)); }

cleanup() {
    log "Cleaning up test session: $TEST_SESSION"
    tmux kill-session -t "$TEST_SESSION" 2>/dev/null || true
}
trap cleanup EXIT

log "Starting ntm errors E2E tests"

# Setup: Create test session
log "Setup: Creating test session with multiple panes"
tmux new-session -d -s "$TEST_SESSION" -x 120 -y 30
tmux split-window -t "$TEST_SESSION" -v
tmux split-window -t "$TEST_SESSION" -h
sleep 0.5

# Inject errors into different panes
log "Injecting test errors into panes"

# Pane 0: Python error
tmux send-keys -t "$TEST_SESSION:0.0" 'echo "Traceback (most recent call last):" && echo "  File \"test.py\", line 1" && echo "FileNotFoundError: test.txt"' Enter
sleep 0.3

# Pane 1: Go panic
tmux send-keys -t "$TEST_SESSION:0.1" 'echo "panic: runtime error: index out of range [5]" && echo "goroutine 1 [running]:"' Enter
sleep 0.3

# Pane 2: Normal output
tmux send-keys -t "$TEST_SESSION:0.2" 'echo "INFO: Everything is fine"' Enter
sleep 0.3

# Test 1: Capture all errors
log "Test 1: Capture all errors"
RESULT=$(ntm --robot-errors="$TEST_SESSION" 2>&1 || echo '{"errors":[]}')
log "Result: $RESULT"

ERROR_COUNT=$(echo "$RESULT" | jq '.total_errors // .errors | length' 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
log "Error count: $ERROR_COUNT"

if [[ "$ERROR_COUNT" -ge "2" ]]; then
    pass "Found errors in session"
else
    fail "Expected at least 2 errors, got $ERROR_COUNT"
fi

# Test 2: Filter by pane
log "Test 2: Filter by specific pane"
RESULT=$(ntm --robot-errors="$TEST_SESSION" --panes=0 2>&1 || echo '{"errors":[]}')
log "Result for pane 0: $RESULT"

HAS_PYTHON_ERROR=$(echo "$RESULT" | jq '.errors[] | select(.line | contains("Traceback"))' 2>/dev/null || echo "")
if [[ -n "$HAS_PYTHON_ERROR" ]]; then
    pass "Found Python error in pane 0"
else
    fail "Missing Python error in pane 0"
fi

# Test 3: Check error structure
log "Test 3: Verify error structure"
FIRST_ERROR=$(echo "$RESULT" | jq '.errors[0]' 2>/dev/null || echo "{}")
log "First error structure: $FIRST_ERROR"

HAS_PANE=$(echo "$FIRST_ERROR" | jq 'has("pane")' 2>/dev/null || echo "false")
HAS_LINE=$(echo "$FIRST_ERROR" | jq 'has("line")' 2>/dev/null || echo "false")

if [[ "$HAS_PANE" == "true" ]] && [[ "$HAS_LINE" == "true" ]]; then
    pass "Error structure is correct"
else
    fail "Error structure missing fields"
fi

# Test 4: Non-existent session
log "Test 4: Non-existent session error handling"
RESULT=$(ntm --robot-errors="nonexistent_session_xyz" 2>&1 || echo '{"error":""}')
log "Result: $RESULT"

HAS_ERROR=$(echo "$RESULT" | jq 'has("error")' 2>/dev/null || echo "false")
if [[ "$HAS_ERROR" == "true" ]]; then
    pass "Proper error for non-existent session"
else
    fail "Missing error for non-existent session"
fi

# Summary
log "=========================================="
log "E2E ntm errors Tests Complete"
log "Passed: $PASSED"
log "Failed: $FAILED"
log "=========================================="

[[ $FAILED -eq 0 ]] && exit 0 || exit 1
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Test error capture from multiple panes
- [ ] Test pane filtering (--panes flag)
- [ ] Test error structure (pane, timestamp, line fields)
- [ ] Test non-existent session error handling
- [ ] Test Python traceback detection
- [ ] Test Go panic detection
- [ ] Proper cleanup on exit
- [ ] Detailed logging with [E2E-ERRORS] prefix

# Task: RedundancyScore Implementation

Detect how similar outputs are (high = wasteful).

## Implementation
```go
// internal/ensemble/similarity.go
type RedundancyAnalysis struct {
    OverallScore    float64 // 0-1, higher = more redundant
    PairwiseScores  []PairSimilarity
    Recommendations []string
}

type PairSimilarity struct {
    ModeA        string
    ModeB        string
    Similarity   float64 // 0-1
    SharedFindings int
    UniqueToA    int
    UniqueToB    int
}

func CalculateRedundancy(outputs []ModeOutput) *RedundancyAnalysis
func (r *RedundancyAnalysis) GetHighRedundancyPairs(threshold float64) []PairSimilarity
func (r *RedundancyAnalysis) SuggestReplacements(catalog *ModeCatalog) []string
func (r *RedundancyAnalysis) Render() string
```

## Similarity Calculation (Deterministic)
1. Build normalized finding sets per mode:
   - normalize finding text + evidence_pointer when present
2. Jaccard similarity on findings sets
3. Optional small weight for recommendation overlap (normalized text)
4. Combine with fixed weights (e.g., 0.8 findings, 0.2 recommendations)

No heavy NLP or external models.

title: EPIC: Robot Mode Operational Intelligence
description:
## Overview

This EPIC addresses critical gaps in NTM's robot mode that were discovered through real-world
multi-agent swarm orchestration sessions. The core insight: **robot mode should eliminate
the manual debugging loop that operators currently go through**.

## Background & Motivation

During a session orchestrating 15+ agents across Claude, Codex, and Gemini, the following
pain points were identified:

1. **Environment Discovery** - Had to discover through trial and error that:
   - Window index is 1, not 0
   - Must use `/usr/bin/tmux` not `tmux` (zsh plugin conflict)
   - Pane 1 is control shell, agents start at pane 2
   - Fast Ctrl-C timing (0.1s gap) is required to exit claude code

2. **Health Detection** - No way to programmatically detect:
   - Rate-limited panes ("You've hit your limit" in output)
   - Hung/unresponsive processes vs just slow ones
   - Process state (running, zombie, dead)
   - Which child PID to kill when restart is needed

3. **Recovery Actions** - Manual complex procedures for:
   - Restarting stuck panes (timing-sensitive Ctrl-C, fallback to kill -9)
   - Re-assigning beads after restart
   - Bulk allocation of beads to panes based on bv triage

4. **Diagnosis** - No single command to answer "what's wrong and how do I fix it?"

## Goals

1. Make robot mode self-documenting about environment quirks
2. Provide rich health telemetry in --robot-status
3. Add atomic restart operations that handle all edge cases
4. Create a single diagnose command that identifies all problems
5. Enable bulk bead assignment from bv triage output
6. Add active responsiveness probing (not just timeout-based)

## Success Criteria

An AI agent orchestrator should be able to:
- Spawn a swarm
- Get environment info to avoid targeting mistakes
- Allocate beads intelligently in one command
- Detect failures immediately via enriched status
- Diagnose all problems with one command
- Fix problems with atomic restart commands
- Never need to manually grep output or discover PIDs

## Architecture Considerations

- All new commands follow existing robot mode patterns (--robot-* prefix)
- JSON output for all commands
- Graceful degradation if some info unavailable
- No blocking operations in status (use probe for active checks)
- Respect existing robot mode ergonomics work (bd-2dovu)

## Related Work

- Should align with TOON encoding work (bd-2dovu) for output format
- Complements existing ntm assign work (bd-9tbv)
- Builds on tool health patterns (bd-3jbum)

## Non-Goals

- This EPIC does not cover rate limit AVOIDANCE (that's bd-ayjn)
- Does not cover account switching (that's ntm-qoaf)
- Does not replace manual recovery, just makes it programmatic

2. **Output pattern matching**: Look for completion phrases in agent output
3. **Idle detection**: No new output for N seconds after activity burst
4. **Agent Mail message**: Agent sends completion message to coordinator

## Implementation
```go
type CompletionDetector struct {
    PollInterval    time.Duration  // Default 5s for bead status
    IdleThreshold   time.Duration  // Default 120s for idle detection
    Patterns        []string       // Completion patterns to match
    AssignmentStore *AssignmentStore
}

type CompletionEvent struct {
    Pane       int
    AgentType  string
    BeadID     string
    Method     string    // bead_closed, pattern_match, idle, agent_mail
    Timestamp  time.Time
    Duration   time.Duration  // How long agent worked on bead
    Output     string    // Last N lines of output (for debugging)
}

func (d *CompletionDetector) Watch(ctx context.Context) <-chan CompletionEvent
func (d *CompletionDetector) CheckNow(pane int) (*CompletionEvent, error)
```

## Default Completion Patterns
```
- "bead .* complete"
- "task .* (done|finished|complete)"
- "closing bead"
- "br close"
- "marked as complete"
- "successfully completed"
```

## Idle Detection Logic
1. Track output timestamps per pane
2. Detect "activity burst" (rapid output)
3. After burst ends + IdleThreshold, consider complete
4. Reset on new output

## Error Handling
```go
type CompletionError struct {
    Method   string  // bead_poll, pattern_match, idle, agent_mail
    Pane     int
    Cause    error
    Fallback bool    // Whether fallback method was used
}

// Error scenarios and handling:
// 1. br CLI unavailable
//    - Log warning, fall back to pattern matching + idle detection
//    - Set Fallback=true in CompletionEvent
//    - Don't fail entirely - degrade gracefully
//
// 2. Pane no longer exists (agent crashed)
//    - Return CompletionEvent with Method="pane_lost"
//    - Update assignment status to "failed"
//    - Log: "[DETECT] Pane %d lost, marking bd-%s as failed"
//
// 3. Agent Mail unavailable
//    - Skip agent_mail method, continue with others
//    - Log once: "[DETECT] Agent Mail unavailable, using other methods"
//
// 4. Output capture permission denied
//    - Try alternate capture method (tmux vs direct)
//    - If all fail, rely only on bead status polling
//
// 5. Bead already closed (stale check)
//    - Emit CompletionEvent immediately
//    - Log: "[DETECT] bd-%s already closed, emitting completion"
//
// 6. Multiple methods detect completion simultaneously
//    - Use first detected, log all methods that matched
//    - Prevent duplicate events with dedup window (5s)
```

## Retry and Recovery
```go
type DetectionConfig struct {
    RetryOnError      bool          // Retry failed checks (default true)
    RetryInterval     time.Duration // Time between retries (default 10s)
    MaxRetries        int           // Max retries before giving up (default 3)
    DedupWindow       time.Duration // Prevent duplicate events (default 5s)
    GracefulDegrading bool          // Fall back to lesser methods (default true)
}
```

## Integration with Assignment Tracking
- On completion: Update assignment status to 'completed'
- On failure patterns: Update assignment status to 'failed'
- Emit event for ntm assign to potentially reassign

## Failure Patterns (detect agent giving up)
```
- "unable to complete"
- "cannot proceed"
- "blocked by"
- "giving up"
- "need help"
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Polls bead status via br CLI
- [ ] Matches completion patterns in output
- [ ] Detects idle after activity burst
- [ ] Updates assignment store on completion
- [ ] Emits structured CompletionEvent
- [ ] Configurable patterns and thresholds
- [ ] Detects failure patterns separately
- [ ] Works in dashboard and CLI modes
- [ ] Logs all detection decisions
- [ ] Graceful degradation when methods unavailable
- [ ] Handles pane loss (agent crash)
- [ ] Deduplicates simultaneous detections

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Pattern matching with various phrases
- Unit test: Idle detection timing accuracy
- Unit test: Bead status polling integration
- Unit test: Failure pattern detection
- Unit test: Graceful degradation when br unavailable
- Unit test: Pane loss handling
- Unit test: Event deduplication
- E2E test: Full completion workflow with real agent

title: CAAM: Implement automatic account switching on rate limit
description:
When rate limit detected, automatically switch to next available account.

## Switch Flow

1. Rate limit detected (from detector)
2. Identify affected provider (claude, openai, gemini)
3. Call: `caam switch <provider> --next --json`
4. Parse response for new account details
5. Update agent environment (see subtask)
6. Log switch event
7. Notify user via dashboard

## CAAM Switch Response

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "provider": "claude",
  "previous_account": "account1",
  "new_account": "account2",
  "cooldown_until": "2024-01-15T11:00:00Z",
  "accounts_remaining": 2
}
```

## Error Handling

- No more accounts: Alert user, agent must wait
- CAAM binary error: Log, continue with current account
- Switch timeout: Retry once, then fallback

## Implementation

```go
func (m *CAAMManager) SwitchAccount(provider string) (*SwitchResult, error) {
    cmd := exec.Command("caam", "switch", provider, "--next", "--json")
    output, err := cmd.Output()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, fmt.Errorf("caam switch failed: %w", err)
    }
    var result SwitchResult
    if err := json.Unmarshal(output, &result); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    return &result, nil
}
```

## Code Location
- internal/integrations/caam/switch.go

## Testing
- Mock caam responses, verify switch flow
- Test exhausted accounts scenario
- Test CAAM failure scenario

- child_pid

- New pane (no history): treat as healthy if process running
- Agent in long operation: distinguish from stuck

title: Feature: Manual rebalance suggestions
description:
## Overview
Provide a **manual** rebalance command that analyzes workload distribution and suggests reassignments when agents leave/join or workloads become uneven, without automatic reassignment.

## User Story
As a user managing a fleet of agents, I want to see workload imbalances and get suggestions for redistributing work so that all agents are utilized efficiently and no single agent becomes a bottleneck.

## When to Rebalance
- An agent dies unexpectedly (reassign its work)
- An agent is spawned (can take on work from overloaded agents)
- Workloads become uneven (some idle, some overwhelmed)
- Priority changes (high-priority work should go to available agents)

## Scope
- `ntm rebalance <session>` analyzes and produces recommended reassignment map
- Uses assignment tracking + agent status to propose moves
- `--apply` prompts for confirmation before reassigning
- `--format json` for robot mode integration
- `--dry-run` shows what would change without prompting

## Workload Metrics
```
Current Workload Distribution:
  cc_1:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà 5 tasks (overloaded)
  cc_2:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà             2 tasks
  cc_3:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà                 1 task
  cod_1: ‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë 0 tasks (idle)
  cod_2: DEAD                 -- (unavailable)

Imbalance Score: 0.73 (high - rebalance recommended)
```

## Rebalance Algorithm
1. **Identify sources** - Agents with above-average workload
2. **Identify targets** - Agents with below-average workload or idle
3. **Calculate transfers** - Move tasks from sources to targets
4. **Respect constraints**:
   - Don't move tasks that are in-progress
   - Prefer moving tasks to agents of same type (cc‚Üícc)
   - Respect task affinity (some tasks may be locked to specific agents)
   - Consider priority (move lower priority tasks first)

## Suggestion Output
```
Rebalance Suggestions for 'myproject':

Recommended Transfers:
  1. [bd-123] "Fix auth bug"
     cc_1 ‚Üí cod_1
     Reason: cc_1 overloaded (5 tasks), cod_1 idle

  2. [bd-456] "Write tests"
     cc_1 ‚Üí cc_3
     Reason: Even out Claude agent workload

  3. [bd-789] "Update docs"
     cc_2 ‚Üí cod_1
     Reason: Low priority task, cod_1 available

After rebalance:
  cc_1:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà         3 tasks
  cc_2:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà                 1 task
  cc_3:  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà             2 tasks
  cod_1: ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà             2 tasks

Apply these changes? (y/n/edit)
```

## Robot Mode Output
```json
{
  "session": "myproject",
  "imbalance_score": 0.73,
  "transfers": [
    {
      "task_id": "bd-123",
      "task_title": "Fix auth bug",
      "from_agent": "cc_1",
      "to_agent": "cod_1",
      "reason": "source_overloaded"
    }
  ],
  "before": {"cc_1": 5, "cc_2": 2, "cc_3": 1, "cod_1": 0},
  "after": {"cc_1": 3, "cc_2": 1, "cc_3": 2, "cod_1": 2}
}
```

## CLI Examples
```bash
# Show rebalance suggestions (no action)
ntm rebalance myproject

# Show suggestions and apply after confirmation
ntm rebalance myproject --apply

# Dry run - show what would happen
ntm rebalance myproject --dry-run

# Robot mode for scripting
ntm rebalance myproject --format json

# Only rebalance Claude agents
ntm rebalance myproject --filter cc

# Set imbalance threshold (only suggest if score above threshold)
ntm rebalance myproject --threshold 0.5
```

## Handling Dead Agents
When an agent dies:
```
Agent cod_2 detected as DEAD (no response for 5m)

Orphaned tasks: 3
  - [bd-111] "Implement feature X" (in_progress)
  - [bd-222] "Review PR #42" (pending)
  - [bd-333] "Update config" (pending)

Reassignment suggestions:
  1. [bd-111] ‚Üí cc_1 (similar work in progress)
  2. [bd-222] ‚Üí cc_2 (available)
  3. [bd-333] ‚Üí cod_1 (same agent type)

Apply? (y/n)
```

## Non‚ÄëGoals
- No automatic/background rebalancing
- No AI-based task matching (simple heuristics only)
- No cross-session rebalancing

## Implementation Notes
- Requires assignment tracking (bd-92e1) to know current assignments
- Uses agent status from tmux to detect dead/idle agents
- Imbalance score: stddev(workloads) / mean(workloads)
- Rebalance is advisory - user always confirms

## Tests
- Unit: imbalance score calculation
- Unit: transfer suggestion algorithm
- Unit: constraint handling (in-progress, affinity)
- E2E: simulate agent death ‚Üí rebalance suggestions
- E2E: simulate new agent spawn ‚Üí rebalance suggestions
- E2E: apply rebalance with confirmation

## Logging
```go
log.Printf("[E2E-REBALANCE] session=%s imbalance=%.2f suggestions=%d", session, score, count)
log.Printf("[E2E-REBALANCE] transfer task=%s from=%s to=%s reason=%s", task, from, to, reason)
log.Printf("[E2E-REBALANCE] applied=%t transfers=%d errors=%d", applied, transfers, errors)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Recommendations deterministic for same state
- [ ] Safe confirmation before applying
- [ ] Works even if some agents unavailable
- [ ] Detects dead agents and suggests reassignment
- [ ] Respects in-progress task constraint
- [ ] Imbalance score calculated correctly
- [ ] Robot mode outputs valid JSON
- [ ] Dry-run shows changes without prompting

## Dependencies
- Requires bd-92e1 (assignment tracking) to function
notes:
Rescoped from automatic rebalancing to manual suggestions to avoid hidden state changes.\n\n## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests: core logic, error paths, edge cases.
- E2E scripts: full CLI/robot flow with detailed log/slog prefixes (e.g., [E2E-<AREA>]) and include session/agent/bead IDs.
- If structured outputs are affected, assert schema stability + deterministic ordering.
close_reason: Over-engineering: dynamic rebalancing requires tracking all assignments, detecting agent status changes, and reassigning work. Manual rebalancing with 'ntm send' is more predictable.

title: Add ntm assign --clear for removing assignment from agent
description:
## Overview
Allow users to clear/cancel an assignment, returning the bead to the unassigned pool.

## Use Cases
1. Agent crashed and assignment is stale
2. User wants to restart a bead from scratch
3. Bead was assigned by mistake
4. Agent gave up and user wants to retry later

## Usage
```bash
# Clear single assignment
ntm assign myproject --clear bd-xyz

# Clear multiple assignments
ntm assign myproject --clear bd-xyz,bd-abc,bd-def

# Clear all assignments for a pane (agent crashed)
ntm assign myproject --clear-pane=3

# Clear all failed assignments
ntm assign myproject --clear-failed
```

## Workflow
1. Validate bead is currently assigned
2. Update assignment status to "cleared"
3. Release file reservations (call Agent Mail release_file_reservations)
4. Bead is now available for reassignment
5. Optionally update bead status in br (if bead was marked in-progress)

## Output (Standard Envelope)
```json
{
  "command": "assign",
  "subcommand": "clear",
  "session": "myproject",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T12:00:00Z",
  "success": true,
  "data": {
    "cleared": [
      {
        "bead_id": "bd-xyz",
        "bead_title": "Implement feature X",
        "previous_pane": 3,
        "previous_agent": "GreenCastle",
        "previous_status": "working",
        "file_reservations_released": true
      }
    ],
    "summary": {
      "cleared_count": 1,
      "reservations_released": 1
    }
  },
  "warnings": [],
  "error": null
}
```

## Error Output
```json
{
  "command": "assign",
  "subcommand": "clear",
  "session": "myproject",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T12:00:00Z",
  "success": false,
  "data": null,
  "warnings": [],
  "error": {
    "code": "NOT_ASSIGNED",
    "message": "bead bd-xyz is not currently assigned"
  }
}
```

## Error Codes
- NOT_ASSIGNED: Bead doesn't have an active assignment
- ALREADY_COMPLETED: Bead assignment already completed (use --force)
- PANE_NOT_FOUND: Specified pane doesn't exist

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Clear single assignment
- [ ] Clear multiple assignments (comma-separated)
- [ ] Clear by pane (--clear-pane)
- [ ] Clear failed assignments (--clear-failed)
- [ ] Release file reservations via Agent Mail
- [ ] Standard JSON envelope output
- [ ] --force flag for completed beads
- [ ] Clear error codes

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Assignment clearing logic
- Unit test: File reservation release
- Unit test: Output format validation
- E2E test: Clear and re-assign workflow

User wants to run cc+cod agents on each of 30+ repos at once for flywheel development.

```bash
# Basic: spawn cc+cod per project
ntm spawn --multi-project /dp/repo1 /dp/repo2 /dp/repo3 --cc=1 --cod=1

# Recent GitHub repos
```

- --multi-project-file FILE - Read paths from file
- --multi-project-gh-recent - Use recent GitHub repos
- --multi-project-default - Use default flywheel repos

2. **CLI wrapper**: call the `tru` binary (toon_rust) if installed; Node `toon` is not allowed.
3. **Minimal encoder**: implement TOON subset for NTM payloads (uniform arrays + primitives).

## Inputs
- TOON reference implementation is JS (`toon-format/toon`).
- Spec lives in `toon-format/spec` (v3.0).

## Decision Criteria
- Reliability (no partial/invalid TOON)
- Minimal dependencies for Go build
- Graceful fallback behavior
- Token savings on real NTM payloads (see bd-rmnfk)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Documented decision and chosen path
- Follow-up tasks updated to match choice
notes: Decision (2026-01-20): Use a minimal in-process TOON encoder in Go (no external CLI). Rationale: highest reliability + lowest deps; avoids Node/CLI availability failures; can strictly validate supported shapes. Scope: uniform arrays of objects + primitives; deterministic field order; tab delimiter only when safe; for unsupported shapes use JSON fallback in auto mode or error in explicit TOON.

title: EPIC: Robot Mode Ergonomics + Token Efficiency (TOON + JSON)
description:
## Goal
Make robot mode maximally ergonomic and token‚Äëefficient for AI agents while preserving first‚Äëclass JSON support for tooling.

## Rationale
Robot mode is consumed primarily by AI agents (Codex/Claude/Gemini) where tokens and readability directly affect cost and accuracy. JSON is reliable for tooling but verbose; TOON can be far more compact for uniform arrays. We should support both and choose defaults based on evidence.

## Ground Truth
- `RobotResponse` already exists in `internal/robot/types.go` and is the canonical envelope.
- JSON output is currently pretty‚Äëprinted (stable and easy to diff) but not token‚Äëefficient.

## Scope
- Evaluate TOON vs JSON for NTM robot payloads (token savings, clarity, failure modes).
- Add a robot output **format selector** (`json`, `toon`, `auto`) with config/env overrides.
- Standardize/validate the robot output envelope (reuse existing struct; no new schema).
- Provide token‚Äëefficient profiles (terse vs full) **without** breaking parseability.
- Add pagination/limits where payloads are large.

## Non‚ÄëGoals
- No breaking removal of JSON.
- No dependency on a specific external CLI if not installed.

## Success Criteria
- Agents can request TOON output when beneficial.
- JSON remains first‚Äëclass and stable for scripts.
- Robot outputs are consistent and easier for LLMs to parse.
- Unit + E2E tests cover format selector, envelopes, and large payloads.
notes:

title: Add ntm assign --pane for assigning specific bead to specific agent
description:
## Overview
Allow users to assign a specific bead to a specific agent pane directly.

## Use Cases
1. User knows which agent is best for a specific task
2. Testing/debugging with controlled assignments
3. Manually implementing a custom assignment strategy
4. Assigning high-priority bead to best-performing agent

## Usage
```bash
# Assign specific bead to specific pane
ntm assign myproject --pane=3 bd-xyz

# With custom prompt
ntm assign myproject --pane=3 bd-xyz --prompt="Focus on the API changes"

# Multiple beads to one pane (queued)
ntm assign myproject --pane=3 bd-xyz,bd-abc

# Bypass strategy entirely
ntm assign myproject --pane=3 --bead=bd-xyz --no-strategy
```

## Workflow
1. Validate pane exists and is idle (or use --force)
2. Validate bead is assignable (not blocked, not already assigned)
3. Create assignment in store
4. Create file reservations via Agent Mail
5. Send prompt to agent
6. Return result

## Output (Standard Envelope)
```json
{
  "command": "assign",
  "subcommand": "pane",
  "session": "myproject",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T12:00:00Z",
  "success": true,
  "data": {
    "assignment": {
      "bead_id": "bd-xyz",
      "bead_title": "Implement feature X",
      "pane": 3,
      "agent_type": "claude",
      "agent_name": "GreenCastle",
      "status": "assigned",
      "prompt_sent": true,
      "assigned_at": "2026-01-19T12:00:00Z"
    },
    "file_reservations": ["src/api/*.ts"]
  },
  "warnings": [],
  "error": null
}
```

## Validation
- Pane must exist in session
- Bead must not be blocked (unless --ignore-deps)
- Bead must not already be assigned (unless --force)
- Agent should be idle (unless --force)

## Error Output
```json
{
  "command": "assign",
  "subcommand": "pane",
  "session": "myproject",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T12:00:00Z",
  "success": false,
  "data": null,
  "warnings": [],
  "error": {
    "code": "BEAD_BLOCKED",
    "message": "bead bd-xyz is blocked by bd-abc",
    "details": {
      "blocked_by": ["bd-abc"]
    }
  }
}
```

## Error Codes
- PANE_NOT_FOUND: Pane doesn't exist in session
- BEAD_BLOCKED: Bead has unresolved dependencies
- ALREADY_ASSIGNED: Bead already assigned to another agent
- AGENT_BUSY: Target agent is working on another bead

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Assign specific bead to specific pane
- [ ] Validate pane exists
- [ ] Validate bead is assignable
- [ ] Support --force for override
- [ ] Support --ignore-deps for blocked beads
- [ ] Create file reservations via Agent Mail
- [ ] Custom prompt support
- [ ] Standard JSON envelope output
- [ ] Clear error codes and messages

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Validation logic
- Unit test: Force override behavior
- Unit test: Output format validation
- E2E test: Direct pane assignment
close_reason: done

title: rano: Implement --robot-rano-stats command
description:
## Overview

Add `ntm --robot-rano-stats` command for per-agent network statistics via rano integration.

## IMPORTANT: API Design Consistency

This command follows the established robot mode patterns:
- **Naming**: `--robot-rano-stats` (tool prefix: rano)
- **NOT** `--robot-network-stats` (must include tool name)
- **Modifiers**: shared `--panes=` flag

## Command Interface

```bash
# Get network stats for all agents
ntm --robot-rano-stats

# Filter to specific pane
ntm --robot-rano-stats --panes=2,3

# Custom time window
ntm --robot-rano-stats --rano-window=10m
```

## Output Schema

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "window": "5m",
  "agents": {
    "pane_2": {
      "connections": 3,
      "bytes_sent": 45000,
      "bytes_received": 120000,
      "requests_estimate": 15,
      "providers": {
        "anthropic": {
          "connections": 2,
          "bytes_sent": 40000,
          "bytes_received": 100000
        }
      },
      "avg_latency_ms": 250
    }
  },
  "total": {
    "connections": 4,
    "bytes_sent": 55000,
    "bytes_received": 170000
  }
}
```

## Error Response

```json
{
  "success": false,
  "error": "rano not found in PATH",
  "hint": "Install rano: go install github.com/.../rano@latest"
}
```

## Implementation

1. Check rano availability via ToolRegistry
2. Get PID map for all/specified panes via tmux
3. Call rano with PIDs: `rano --pids=PID1,PID2 --window=DURATION --json`
4. Aggregate stats by pane
5. Format as JSON

## Modifier Flags

| Flag | Description | Default |
|------|-------------|---------|
| `--panes=N` | Filter to specific pane(s) | All agent panes |
| `--rano-window=DURATION` | Time window for stats | 5m |

## Code Location
- internal/robot/rano_stats.go

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `--robot-rano-stats` flag registered in root.go
- [ ] `--panes=N` filter works with comma-separated pane IDs
- [ ] `--rano-window=DURATION` accepts Go duration format (5m, 1h, etc.)
- [ ] JSON output matches schema exactly
- [ ] Missing rano returns actionable error with install hint
- [ ] PID-to-pane mapping correctly attributes traffic
- [ ] Provider breakdown (anthropic/openai/google) works
- [ ] Exit code 0 on success, 1 on partial data, 2 on error

## Testing Requirements

### Unit Tests (internal/robot/rano_stats_test.go)
- [ ] Flag parsing for all options
- [ ] PID-to-pane mapping logic
- [ ] rano output parsing
- [ ] Provider aggregation
- [ ] JSON output serialization
- [ ] Error handling for missing rano
- [ ] Error handling for rano failures

### E2E Tests (scripts/e2e_robot_rano.sh)
```bash
#\!/bin/bash
# [E2E-RANO] Robot Rano Stats Tests
set -euo pipefail
LOG_PREFIX="[E2E-RANO]"

echo "$LOG_PREFIX Starting robot rano E2E tests"

# Check if rano is available
if \! command -v rano &>/dev/null; then
    echo "$LOG_PREFIX SKIP: rano not installed"
    exit 0
fi

# Setup: Create test session
TEST_SESSION="e2e_rano_$$"
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Creating test session: $TEST_SESSION"
ntm spawn "$TEST_SESSION" --cc=1 --no-prompt
sleep 5

# Test 1: Basic stats
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Test 1: Basic rano stats"
RESULT=$(ntm --robot-rano-stats)
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Result: $RESULT"
[[ $(echo "$RESULT" | jq -r ".success") == "true" ]] || exit 1
[[ $(echo "$RESULT" | jq -r ".timestamp") \!= "" ]] || exit 1

# Test 2: Pane filter
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Test 2: Pane-filtered stats"
RESULT=$(ntm --robot-rano-stats --panes=1)
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Result: $RESULT"
[[ $(echo "$RESULT" | jq -r ".success") == "true" ]] || exit 1

# Test 3: Custom window

RESULT=$(ntm --robot-rano-stats --rano-window=1m)
echo "$LOG_PREFIX Result: $RESULT"
[[ $(echo "$RESULT" | jq -r ".window") == "1m" ]] || exit 1

# Cleanup

echo "$LOG_PREFIX All robot rano E2E tests passed"
```

title: Task: Create ContextPredictor module
description:
## Purpose
Implement context window exhaustion prediction based on token velocity tracking.

## Module Location
internal/context/predictor.go

## ContextPredictor Struct
type ContextPredictor struct {
    samples      []TokenSample
    window       time.Duration    // Velocity averaging window
    pollInterval time.Duration
}

type TokenSample struct {
    Timestamp time.Time
    Tokens    int
}

type Prediction struct {
    CurrentUsage         float64
    TokenVelocity        float64  // tokens per minute
    MinutesToExhaustion  float64
    ShouldWarn           bool
    ShouldCompact        bool
}

## Key Methods
func (p *ContextPredictor) AddSample(tokens int)
func (p *ContextPredictor) PredictExhaustion(modelLimit int) *Prediction
func (p *ContextPredictor) calculateVelocity() float64

## Prediction Logic
velocity = (latest_tokens - oldest_tokens_in_window) / window_duration
remaining = model_limit - current_tokens
minutes_to_exhaustion = remaining / velocity

ShouldWarn = minutes < 15 && usage > 0.70
ShouldCompact = minutes < 8 && usage > 0.75

## Acceptance Criteria
- Accurately tracks token velocity
- Handles bursts and pauses in output
- Returns nil Prediction when insufficient data
- Thread-safe for concurrent access

## Technical Notes
Use ring buffer for sample storage
Consider exponential moving average for smoothing
notes:

- E2E scripts: full CLI/robot flow with detailed log/slog prefixes (e.g., [E2E-<AREA>]) and include session/agent/bead IDs.
- If structured outputs are affected, assert schema stability + deterministic ordering.

title: Feature: Mode Contribution Scoring
description:
## Summary
Track and display how much each mode contributed to the final synthesis, enabling users to understand which reasoning approaches were most valuable.

## Rationale
When synthesis completes, users can't tell which modes drove the conclusions. Contribution scoring:
- Builds trust by showing reasoning transparency
- Helps users pick better mode combinations over time
- Identifies modes that consistently add/don't add value

## Implementation
1. Compute **ContributionScore** in synthesis (do **not** mutate ModeOutput):
   - Use deduped findings, final citations, and unique insights.
   - Unique insights determined via normalized finding text + evidence pointer + RedundancyScore normalization.
2. Store results in a `ContributionReport` attached to SynthesisResult / run metadata.
3. Display per-mode contribution in synthesis output and `ntm ensemble status --show-contributions`.
4. Optional: persist historical contribution summaries in ensemble state store for preset tuning.

## Scoring (Deterministic)
- Normalize counts into 0-1 ranges.
- Score = w1*unique_findings + w2*citations + w3*diversity_bonus.
- Stable ordering by score desc, then mode_id.

## Logging
- Log per-mode counts (findings, unique, citations) and final score.
- Log scoring weights and normalization ranges per run.

## Tests
- Unit: scoring math, deterministic ordering, and tie-break rules.
- Unit: unique-insight detection with overlap cases.
- Integration: multi-mode fixture with known overlaps.
- E2E: report/CLI/robot JSON include contribution data.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Each mode gets a contribution score 0-100
- [ ] Scores reflect actual impact on synthesis
- [ ] Dashboard shows contribution breakdown
- [ ] Historical data enables mode selection optimization
- [ ] Robot API includes contribution data in output
- [ ] Unit + E2E tests cover scoring and output schema

## Dependencies
- Requires ModeOutput schema (bd-1wnxl)
- Requires Synthesis System (bd-2qwm8)
- Requires RedundancyScore normalization (bd-254do)
- Requires ensemble state persistence for historical data (bd-25wul)

comments.author: Dicklesworthstone
comments.text:
## Implementation Note
Contribution scoring depends on provenance tracking (bd-3n3ti) to calculate:
- UniqueInsights: findings from this mode not found by others
- CitationCount: how often synthesis referenced this mode's findings
- Score formula: (CitationCount * 0.5 + UniqueInsights * 0.3 + FindingsCount * 0.2) / total

title: Task: Implement redundancy score via output similarity detection
description:
Detect redundant outputs by measuring similarity between mode outputs.

## Implementation
```go
// internal/ensemble/similarity.go
type SimilarityAnalyzer struct {
    Outputs []ModeOutput
}

type SimilarityResult struct {
    OverallScore float64  // 0-1, higher = more redundant
    PairwiseScores map[string]float64  // 'F1:E2' -> 0.23
    RedundantPairs []string  // Pairs with similarity > threshold
    Recommendations []string  // Suggested mode replacements
}

func NewSimilarityAnalyzer() *SimilarityAnalyzer
func (s *SimilarityAnalyzer) AddOutput(output ModeOutput)
func (s *SimilarityAnalyzer) Analyze() *SimilarityResult

// Similarity metrics
func (s *SimilarityAnalyzer) computeJaccardSimilarity(a, b []Finding) float64
func (s *SimilarityAnalyzer) computeThesisSimilarity(a, b string) float64
func (s *SimilarityAnalyzer) computeRecommendationOverlap(a, b []Recommendation) float64
```

## Similarity Computation
- Jaccard similarity on finding sets
- Text similarity on thesis statements
- Recommendation overlap percentage
- Weighted combination of all metrics

## Thresholds
- < 0.3: Good diversity
- 0.3-0.6: Acceptable overlap
- > 0.6: High redundancy, suggest replacement

title: EPIC: Cross-Session Agent Memory via CM Integration
description:
**IDEA #3 - TRANSFORMATIVE (90% confidence)**

## What It Does
Agents automatically query CASS Memory (CM) at session start to retrieve relevant procedural knowledge, anti-patterns, and lessons learned from past sessions working on this project.

## Why This Matters
- Agents feel like they 'remember' past sessions
- Dramatically reduces re-explaining project conventions
- Users no longer need to repeat 'we use structured logging' every session
- The 'wow' factor when an agent says 'Based on past work, I will use...'

## How It Works
On agent spawn, before first user prompt:
1. Query CM: cm context '<project_name>: starting new coding session' --json
2. Extract relevant memories: Procedural rules, anti-patterns, historical snippets
3. Inject into initial context: Prepend to first prompt or send as separate message
4. Track effectiveness: When agents invoke rules ('Following b-8f3a2c...'), record positive signal

## Memory Categories Retrieved
- Procedural rules: 'Always run tests before committing in this project'
- Anti-patterns: 'Don't use ORM for this project; raw SQL only'
- Historical context: 'Last time we touched auth, the session at X solved Y'
- Suggested CASS queries: 'Search for rate limiting middleware to see prior solutions'

## Flywheel Alignment: Core
- CM exists specifically for this use case
- Makes CASS indexing immediately valuable
- Each session teaches agents something; that knowledge persists
- The more you use NTM, the smarter your agents become

## Technical Implementation
- New file: internal/cm/client.go
- CMClient.Context() method to query cm context
- Config under [memory] section
- Graceful degradation if CM not available

## Dependencies
Depends on: ntm init, Session Recovery infrastructure

- Exposes progress and partial reasoning
- Enables early cancellation while preserving useful work

- Streaming is a view over the same synthesis logic (no divergence from non-stream behavior).
- CLI: `ntm ensemble synthesize --stream` prints incremental output; `--stream --json` emits JSONL events + final summary envelope.
- TUI/dashboard: incremental updates (no SSE/web unless an HTTP API already exists).
- Integrate with checkpointing/resume (bd-3didt) and state persistence (bd-25wul).

## Logging
- Log stream start/end, run_id, chunk_count, time_to_first_chunk, cancel reason.

## Tests
- Unit: chunk ordering + deterministic emission
- Integration: stream + synthesis fixture
- E2E: CLI stream output, Ctrl+C resume hint, robot JSONL schema

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Streaming begins before synthesis completes
- [ ] Chunk ordering is deterministic
- [ ] Cancel preserves partial results with resume command
- [ ] Non-stream path is unchanged
- [ ] Structured logs include run_id + stream stats

# Task: Implement Mode-to-Agent Assignment Strategies

## Location
internal/ensemble/assignment.go

## Purpose
Assign reasoning modes to agent panes while respecting agent strengths, user preferences, and available pane types.

## Assignment Strategies

### 1. Round-Robin (default)
Distribute modes evenly across available panes.
```go
func AssignRoundRobin(modes []string, panes []tmux.Pane) []ModeAssignment
```

### 2. Category-Affinity (intelligent)
Prefer agent types based on **ModeCategory** (A‚ÄìL taxonomy), not hard-coded mode IDs.
```go
// Category -> preferred agent types (ordered)
var CategoryAffinities = map[ModeCategory][]string{
    CategoryFormal:      {"cc", "cod"},
    CategoryUncertainty: {"cod", "cc"},
    CategoryCausal:      {"cc", "cod"},
    CategoryPractical:   {"cod", "cc"},
    CategoryStrategic:   {"cc", "cod"},
    CategoryDialectical: {"cc"},
    CategoryModal:       {"cc", "cod"},
    CategoryDomain:      {"cc", "gmi"},
    CategoryMeta:        {"cc"},
    CategoryAmpliative:  {"gmi", "cc"},
    CategoryVagueness:   {"gmi", "cc"},
    CategoryChange:      {"cc", "cod"},
}

func AssignByCategory(modes []string, panes []tmux.Pane, catalog *ModeCatalog) []ModeAssignment
```
- Resolve mode by **id or code**
- Pick available pane of preferred type; fallback to any

### 3. Explicit (user-specified)
User provides exact mapping: `abductive:cc,adversarial:cod` or `A1:cc`.
```go
func AssignExplicit(specs []string, panes []tmux.Pane) ([]ModeAssignment, error)
```

```go
func groupPanesByType(panes []tmux.Pane) map[string][]tmux.Pane
func pickAvailablePane(byType map[string][]tmux.Pane, preferred []string, used []ModeAssignment) tmux.Pane
func ValidateAssignments(assignments []ModeAssignment, modes []string) error
```

- Assignment order must be deterministic (stable ordering by mode id/code).
- Tie-breaking is stable and logged (preferred type chosen + fallback reason).

title: DCG Integration: Destructive Command Guard for Agent Safety
description:
Integrate DCG (destructive_commit_guard) to block dangerous commands across all managed agents.

## Project Location
/dp/destructive_commit_guard (Rust CLI)

## What DCG Does

DCG is a whitelist-first pattern matcher that intercepts commands before execution and blocks known-dangerous patterns:
- `rm -rf /`, `rm -rf ~`, `rm -rf *`
- `git reset --hard`, `git push --force origin main`
- `DROP DATABASE`, `TRUNCATE TABLE`
- `kubectl delete namespace`, `terraform destroy`
- `chmod -R 777`, `chown -R` on sensitive paths

### Architecture
- Whitelist patterns: known-safe commands pass through
- Blocklist patterns: known-dangerous commands blocked
- Context-aware: understands git branch, current directory
- Override: `--i-know-what-im-doing` flag for explicit bypass

## Integration Strategy for NTM

### Option A: PreToolUse Hook (Recommended)
Claude Code agents support PreToolUse hooks that run before any Bash tool execution.
NTM can configure this hook for all spawned agents automatically.

```json
{
  "hooks": {
    "PreToolUse": [{
      "matcher": "Bash",
      "command": "dcg check --command \"\""
    }]
  }
}
```

### Option B: Shell Wrapper
Wrap bash with dcg-guarded version, but this is more invasive.

### Option C: NTM Send Interception
Intercept `ntm send` commands and run through DCG before forwarding to pane.
Good for non-Claude agents (Codex, Gemini).

## Implementation Plan
1. Detect if dcg binary is available on PATH
2. Add config option: [integrations.dcg] enabled = true
3. For Claude agents: auto-configure PreToolUse hook
4. For other agents: intercept at ntm send level
5. Add --robot-dcg-status command to check DCG state
6. Dashboard indicator: üõ°Ô∏è when DCG active

## Considerations
- DCG must not slow down agent execution (< 10ms overhead)
- Override mechanism needed for legitimate destructive ops
- Logging: record all blocked commands for audit
- Need to handle dcg binary not found gracefully

title: CRITICAL: Always send Enter twice after marching orders
description:
When sending marching orders to agents via tmux send-keys, Enter must be sent TWICE.

## The Problem
Agents appear to receive marching orders but never start processing them.

## Root Cause
A single Enter key press may not reliably submit the message in Claude Code / Codex CLI.
The message sits in the input buffer without being submitted.

## The Fix
After sending the marching orders text, ALWAYS send Enter twice with a small delay:

```bash
# Send marching orders (no Enter at end)
tmux send-keys -t "$session:1.$pane" "$msg"
sleep 1
# CRITICAL: Send Enter TWICE
tmux send-keys -t "$session:1.$pane" Enter
sleep 0.5
tmux send-keys -t "$session:1.$pane" Enter
```

## Code Locations to Fix
- internal/commands/spawn.go - sendMarchingOrders()
- internal/commands/send.go - sendToPane()
- Any function that sends text to agent panes

## Testing
After fix, verify with:
```bash
tmux capture-pane -t session:1.1 -p | tail -20
```
Should show agent actively processing, not waiting at input prompt.

```bash
ntm swarm myproject --cc=5 --prompt-file=marching_orders.txt --monitor
```

## Lifecycle Phases
1. **Spawn Phase**: Create agents using `ntm spawn`
2. **Init Phase**: Send marching orders to all agents
3. **Assign Phase**: Distribute beads using `ntm assign`
4. **Monitor Phase**: Watch for completion, failures, stuck agents
5. **Reassign Phase**: When agents complete, assign next beads
6. **Shutdown Phase**: Graceful shutdown when all work done

## Config File Format (swarm.yaml)
```yaml
session: myproject
agents:
  claude: 10
  codex: 10
  gemini: 4
prompts:
  init: |
    Read AGENTS.md and register with Agent Mail...
  review: |
    Review code written by fellow agents...
assignment:
  source: bv
  limit: 24
  auto_reassign: true
monitor:
  stuck_threshold: 300  # seconds
  auto_restart: true
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Parses swarm.yaml config files
- [ ] Spawns agents with correct mix
- [ ] Sends initialization prompts
- [ ] Assigns beads using bv integration
- [ ] Monitors agent health and progress
- [ ] Auto-reassigns when agents complete
- [ ] Graceful shutdown when queue empty
- [ ] JSON output for all phases in robot mode

## Dependencies
- ntm spawn (existing)
- ntm assign (bd-k3zq)
- ntm status (existing)
- Assignment tracking (bd-92e1)
- Completion detection (bd-3c4q)

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Config file parsing
- Unit test: Lifecycle state machine
- E2E test: Full swarm lifecycle

description:
## Test Coverage
Full end-to-end test of dependency-aware assignment with real bead graph.

1. Create test workspace with dependency chain:
   - bd-A: no deps (ready)
   - bd-B: blocked by A
   - bd-C: blocked by A
   - bd-D: blocked by B and C

4. Complete bd-A (close it)
5. Verify bd-B and bd-C become assignable

7. Complete bd-B and bd-C

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
set -euo pipefail

LOG=/tmp/ntm-e2e-deps-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S).log
exec > >(tee -a $LOG) 2>&1

echo "[INFO] Starting dependency-aware assignment E2E test"

# Setup workspace with dependency chain
echo "[STEP 1] Creating test workspace with dependencies..."
TEST_DIR=/tmp/ntm-deps-test-$$
mkdir -p $TEST_DIR && cd $TEST_DIR
br init

# Create beads
A=$(br create "Bead A - no deps" --type task | grep -oP 'bd-\w+')
B=$(br create "Bead B - blocked by A" --type task | grep -oP 'bd-\w+')
C=$(br create "Bead C - blocked by A" --type task | grep -oP 'bd-\w+')
```

title: Fix status bar to render exactly once at fixed bottom position
description:
## Problem
The status bar (Fleet/Alerts/Beads/Mail/Ckpt/Bugs) is included in the main scrollable content area instead of being rendered in a fixed footer region.

## Screenshot Evidence
Multiple "Fleet: 0/17 (C:16) Alerts: 5w Beads: R:0 Mail: offline Ckpt: none Bugs: --" lines appearing at the bottom of the dashboard.

## Code Location
- internal/tui/dashboard/dashboard.go:2067-2070 (ticker panel rendering)
- The tickerPanel.View() is written directly to the strings.Builder without height constraints

## Root Cause
The View() function at line 1972 builds content sequentially:
1. Header (banner + session)
2. Stats bar
3. Main content (pane grid)
4. Ticker bar (line 2069)
5. Quick actions (line 2075)
6. Help bar (line 2084)

When total content exceeds terminal height, the ticker/help bars get duplicated as old frames remain visible.

## Fix Required
1. Create a fixed footer region that renders independently of main content
2. Use lipgloss height constraints to ensure footer is always at the bottom
3. Implement a layout manager that allocates:
   - Fixed header region (top)
   - Scrollable content region (middle, fills remaining space)
   - Fixed footer region (bottom)

## Implementation Pattern
\`\`\`go
func (m Model) View() string {
    // Fixed regions
    header := m.renderHeader()   // ~6 lines
    footer := m.renderFooter()   // ticker + help, ~3 lines
    
    // Calculate available height for content
    headerH := lipgloss.Height(header)
    footerH := lipgloss.Height(footer)
    contentH := m.height - headerH - footerH
    
    // Render and constrain content
    content := m.renderMainContent()
    contentView := lipgloss.NewStyle().
        Height(contentH).
        MaxHeight(contentH).
        Render(content)
    
    // Assemble with explicit positioning
    return lipgloss.JoinVertical(lipgloss.Left,
        header,
        contentView,
        footer,
    )
}

func (m Model) renderFooter() string {
    var b strings.Builder
    b.WriteString(m.tickerPanel.View() + "\n")
    if qa := m.renderQuickActions(); qa != "" {
        b.WriteString(qa + "\n")
    }
    b.WriteString(styles.GradientDivider(m.width-4, ...) + "\n")
    b.WriteString(m.renderHelpBar())
    return b.String()
}
\`\`\`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Status bar appears exactly once at the bottom
- [ ] Resizing terminal doesn't cause duplication
- [ ] Footer remains visible even with long content
- [ ] Scrolling main content doesn't affect footer

## Unit Tests
1. TestFooter_RendersOnce - footer content appears exactly once in View()
2. TestFooter_PositionedAtBottom - footer is at terminal bottom regardless of content
3. TestFooter_WidthFillsTerminal - footer spans full width
4. TestFooter_ContentOverflow - long content doesn't push footer off-screen

## E2E Tests (VHS)
1. Record dashboard at 80x24 - verify footer visible
2. Record dashboard at 200x50 - verify footer at bottom
3. Record resize sequence - verify no footer duplication

## Logging
- DEBUG: Log footer height calculation
- DEBUG: Log content truncation when exceeding available height

title: Feature: Manual scale to target agent counts
description:
## Overview
Provide a safe, **manual** scaling command that wraps existing `ntm add`/`ntm kill` flows to reach a target agent count without introducing autonomous auto-scaling.

## User Story
As a user managing agent fleets, I want to quickly scale my agent counts up or down with a single command so that I can respond to changing workloads without running multiple add/kill commands.

## Rationale
Auto-scaling adds complex workload prediction and can kill useful context. A deterministic "scale to N" command gives the same user value (one command to resize) while preserving control.

## Scope
- `ntm scale <session> --cc=N --cod=N --gmi=N` (desired target counts)
- Computes delta vs current counts and calls `ntm add` / `ntm kill` appropriately
- Never auto-kills user pane; confirm when removing agents
- Optional: `--dry-run` to show planned changes without executing
- Optional: `--force` to skip confirmation on scale-down

## Delta Calculation
```
Current state:
  Claude (cc):  3 agents
  Codex (cod):  2 agents
  Gemini (gmi): 0 agents

Target: --cc=5 --cod=1 --gmi=2

Delta:
  cc:  +2 (spawn 2 new Claude agents)
  cod: -1 (kill 1 Codex agent)
  gmi: +2 (spawn 2 new Gemini agents)
```

## Scale-Up Flow
```bash
$ ntm scale myproject --cc=5

Current Claude agents: 3
Target Claude agents: 5
Action: Spawn 2 new Claude agents

Spawning cc_4... done
Spawning cc_5... done

Scaling complete. Current state:
  cc: 5, cod: 2, gmi: 0
```

## Scale-Down Flow (with confirmation)
```bash
$ ntm scale myproject --cod=1

Current Codex agents: 3
Target Codex agents: 1
Action: Kill 2 Codex agents

WARNING: Scaling down will terminate agents and lose their context.

Agents to terminate:
  - cod_3 (idle for 5m, no pending work)
  - cod_2 (idle for 3m, no pending work)

Proceed? (y/n/select)
> y

Terminating cod_3... done
Terminating cod_2... done

Scaling complete. Current state:
  cc: 3, cod: 1, gmi: 0
```

## Agent Selection for Scale-Down
When scaling down, agents are selected for termination in this order:
1. **Idle agents** - No pending work, longest idle first
2. **Agents without assignments** - No beads assigned
3. **Agents with completed work** - Already finished their tasks
4. **Never auto-kill user pane** - usr_* panes are always protected
5. **Never kill working agents** - Unless --force is specified

## CLI Examples
```bash
# Scale Claude agents to 5
ntm scale myproject --cc=5

# Scale all types at once
ntm scale myproject --cc=3 --cod=2 --gmi=1

# Dry run - show what would change
ntm scale myproject --cc=10 --dry-run

# Force scale-down without confirmation
ntm scale myproject --cc=1 --force

# Scale to zero (kill all agents of type)
ntm scale myproject --cod=0

# Mixed scaling (up and down)
ntm scale myproject --cc=5 --cod=1 --gmi=3

# Robot mode for scripting
ntm scale myproject --cc=5 --format json
```

## Robot Mode Output
```json
{
  "session": "myproject",
  "before": {"cc": 3, "cod": 2, "gmi": 0},
  "after": {"cc": 5, "cod": 1, "gmi": 2},
  "actions": [
    {"type": "spawn", "agent_type": "cc", "count": 2, "agents": ["cc_4", "cc_5"]},
    {"type": "kill", "agent_type": "cod", "count": 1, "agents": ["cod_2"]},
    {"type": "spawn", "agent_type": "gmi", "count": 2, "agents": ["gmi_1", "gmi_2"]}
  ],
  "success": true
}
```

## Error Handling
- If spawn fails: continue with remaining, report failures at end
- If kill fails: continue with remaining, report failures at end
- If target already met: no-op, report "Already at target"
- Partial success: report what succeeded and what failed

```
Scaling partially completed:
  cc: 3 ‚Üí 5 (success)
  cod: 2 ‚Üí 1 (success)
  gmi: 0 ‚Üí 2 (FAILED: API key not configured for Gemini)

To retry failed scaling: ntm scale myproject --gmi=2
```

## Non‚ÄëGoals
- No automatic scaling based on load/metrics
- No background daemon
- No predictive scaling
- No cost-based scaling decisions

## Implementation Notes
- Reuse existing `ntm add` and `ntm kill` logic internally
- Run scale-up before scale-down to avoid losing agents then needing them
- Track which agents were scaled for logging
- Validate target counts are non-negative

## Tests
- Unit: delta calculation with various scenarios
- Unit: agent selection algorithm for scale-down
- Unit: edge cases (zero, negative, same as current)
- E2E: scale up from 0 to N
- E2E: scale down from N to 1
- E2E: mixed scale (up and down together)
- E2E: dry-run shows correct plan
- E2E: force flag skips confirmation

## Logging
```go
log.Printf("[E2E-SCALE] session=%s action=start current=%v target=%v", session, current, target)
log.Printf("[E2E-SCALE] delta cc=%+d cod=%+d gmi=%+d", ccDelta, codDelta, gmiDelta)
log.Printf("[E2E-SCALE] spawn agent_type=%s agent_id=%s success=%t", agentType, agentID, success)
```

title: Task: Add --stagger flag to spawn
description:
## Purpose
Add staggering option to spawn command for rate limit avoidance.

## Flag
ntm spawn myproject --cc=5 --stagger=smart|fixed|none

## Stagger Modes
- smart: Use learned optimal delays from RateLimitTracker
- fixed: Use fixed delay (--stagger-delay=15s)
- none: No staggering (default for backward compatibility)

## Implementation
func (s *SpawnCmd) spawnWithStagger(agents []AgentSpec) error {
    delay := s.rateLimitTracker.GetOptimalDelay(agents[0].Provider)
    
    for i, agent := range agents {
        if i > 0 && s.staggerMode \!= 'none' {
            time.Sleep(delay)
        }
        
        if err := s.spawnAgent(agent); err \!= nil {
            if isRateLimitError(err) {
                s.rateLimitTracker.RecordRateLimit(agent.Provider)
                delay = s.rateLimitTracker.GetOptimalDelay(agent.Provider)
                i-- // Retry
                continue
            }
            return err
        }
        s.rateLimitTracker.RecordSuccess(agent.Provider)
    }
    return nil
}

## Acceptance Criteria
- Staggered spawning works
- Retries on rate limit
- Progress shown during spawn
- Default is backward compatible

Add flag to existing spawn command

title: Add ntm send --priority-order - send to agents in order of bead priority (P0 first)
description:
## Overview
Add --priority-order flag to ntm send to deliver prompts to agents in order of bead priority (P0 first, P4 last).

## Problem
When assigning multiple beads, critical work should start first. Default round-robin ignores priority.

## Solution
`ntm send myproject --priority-order` sorts beads by priority before assignment.

## Implementation
```go
func sortByPriority(beads []Bead) []Bead {
    sorted := make([]Bead, len(beads))
    copy(sorted, beads)
    sort.Slice(sorted, func(i, j int) bool {
        return sorted[i].Priority < sorted[j].Priority // 0 = highest
    })
    return sorted
}
```

## Priority Order
- P0 (critical) ‚Üí sent first
- P1 (high) ‚Üí sent second
- P2 (medium) ‚Üí sent third
- P3 (low) ‚Üí sent fourth
- P4 (backlog) ‚Üí sent last

## CLI Examples
```bash
# Send in priority order
ntm send myproject --priority-order

# Combine with assignment
ntm assign myproject --priority-order --auto

# Show what would be sent
ntm send myproject --priority-order --dry-run
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] P0 beads sent before P1, etc.
- [ ] Stable sort (same priority maintains order)
- [ ] Works with --batch and assign
- [ ] Logging shows priority order
- [ ] Compatible with --limit

title: Implement BeadScanner to count open beads across projects
description:
## BeadScanner: Core Interface and Types

### Purpose
Implement the BeadScanner component that discovers projects and counts their open beads via the `br` CLI. This is the data collection layer that feeds the AllocationCalculator.

### Context
The SwarmPlan allocation depends on knowing how many open beads each project has. BeadScanner wraps the `br` (beads_rust) CLI to query each project's .beads directory.

### Implementation Details

**File:** `internal/swarm/bead_scanner.go`

**Interface:**
```go
// BeadScanner discovers projects and counts their open beads.
type BeadScanner struct {
    // BaseDir is the root directory to scan (e.g., "/dp")
    BaseDir string
    
    // ExplicitProjects overrides directory scanning
    ExplicitProjects []string
    
    // brPath is the path to the br binary (default: "br")
    brPath string
}

// ScanResult contains the complete scan output.
type ScanResult struct {
    Projects      []ProjectBeadCount `json:"projects"`
    TotalProjects int                `json:"total_projects"`
    TotalBeads    int                `json:"total_beads"`
    ScanDuration  time.Duration      `json:"scan_duration"`
    Errors        []ScanError        `json:"errors,omitempty"`
}

type ScanError struct {
    Project string `json:"project"`
    Error   string `json:"error"`
}
```

**Core Methods:**
```go
// Scan discovers all projects and counts their beads.
func (s *BeadScanner) Scan(ctx context.Context) (*ScanResult, error)

// ScanProject counts beads for a single project.
func (s *BeadScanner) ScanProject(ctx context.Context, projectPath string) (ProjectBeadCount, error)

// discoverProjects finds all projects in BaseDir.
func (s *BeadScanner) discoverProjects() ([]string, error)

// isProject checks if a directory is a project (.git or .beads exists).
func isProject(path string) bool

// countBeads runs `br list --status open --json` and parses output.
func (s *BeadScanner) countBeads(ctx context.Context, projectPath string) (int, error)
```

### br CLI Integration
```bash
# Command to run per project:
cd /project/path && br list --status open --json 2>/dev/null

# Expected JSON output:
[{"id": "bd-xxx", "status": "open", ...}, ...]

# Count = len(array)
# If br fails or no .beads, return 0 beads (not an error)
```

### Logging Requirements
- Log each project scanned: `[BeadScanner] Scanning project=%s`
- Log bead count result: `[BeadScanner] project=%s beads=%d`
- Log scan errors: `[BeadScanner] project=%s error=%v`
- Log total scan time: `[BeadScanner] scan_complete projects=%d beads=%d duration=%v`

### Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] BeadScanner struct with configurable base dir
- [ ] Project discovery via directory listing
- [ ] Filter to only directories with .git or .beads
- [ ] Count beads via br CLI subprocess
- [ ] Handle missing br gracefully (log warning, return 0)
- [ ] Concurrent scanning with configurable parallelism
- [ ] Context cancellation support
- [ ] Detailed structured logging

title: Docs: Robot Mode API Design Principles
description:
## Overview

Document the canonical robot mode API design principles to ensure consistency across all current and future robot commands. This serves as the authoritative reference for contributors implementing new robot mode features.

## Document Location

Create `docs/robot-api-design.md` with the following content.

---

## Robot Mode API Design Principles

### 1. Command Naming Patterns

#### Core Session Operations
Session-scoped commands use `=SESSION` syntax:
```bash
--robot-send=SESSION
--robot-tail=SESSION
--robot-spawn=SESSION
--robot-context=SESSION
--robot-env=SESSION
--robot-probe=SESSION
```

#### Global Commands
Commands that operate globally (no session context) are bool flags:
```bash
--robot-status        # Lists all sessions
--robot-version       # Version info
--robot-plan          # bv global plan
--robot-tools         # Tool inventory
--robot-capabilities  # API discovery
```

#### Tool Bridges
External tool integrations follow `--robot-<tool>-<action>` pattern:
```bash
--robot-jfp-list      # JFP prompt listing
--robot-jfp-search    # JFP search (uses --query=)
--robot-xf-search     # XF archive search (uses --query=)
--robot-dcg-check     # DCG safety check (uses --command=)
--robot-mail-check    # Agent Mail inbox (uses --project=)
--robot-cass-search   # CASS history search
--robot-rano-stats    # rano network stats
--robot-rch-status    # RCH build offload status
```

### 2. Parameter Patterns

#### Use Modifier Flags, NOT Inline Values
Tool bridges should NOT use inline values in the main flag.

**CORRECT:**
```bash
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="rust async" --limit=10
ntm --robot-dcg-check --command="rm -rf /data"
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproj --agent=cc_1
```

**INCORRECT:**
```bash
ntm --robot-xf-search="rust async"     # AVOID
ntm --robot-dcg-check="rm -rf /data"   # AVOID
ntm --robot-mail-check=myproj          # AVOID
```

#### Global Shared Modifier Flags
These flags are shared across many commands and should NOT be tool-prefixed:
- `--limit=N` - Max results (not `--xf-limit`)
- `--offset=N` - Pagination offset (not `--mail-offset`)
- `--since=DATE` - Start date filter (not `--cass-since`)
- `--until=DATE` - End date filter (not `--xf-until`)
- `--panes=1,2,3` - Pane filter
- `--lines=N` - Lines to capture
- `--query=Q` - Search query
- `--verbose` - Detailed output (optional, see ¬ß6)

#### Tool-Specific Modifier Flags
Only use tool prefix for options unique to that tool:
- `--xf-mode=semantic` - XF-specific search mode
- `--xf-sort=date` - XF-specific sort order
- `--rano-window=10m` - rano-specific time window
- `--probe-method=keystroke_echo` - probe-specific method

### 3. Output Envelope

All robot commands MUST include these fields:
```json
{
  "success": true,         // Required: always first
  "timestamp": "RFC3339",  // Required: when response generated
  "error": "...",          // Only on failure
  "error_code": "...",     // Only on failure, machine-readable
  "hint": "..."            // Recovery suggestion
}
```

#### Standard Error Codes
- `SESSION_NOT_FOUND` - Session does not exist
- `PANE_NOT_FOUND` - Pane does not exist
- `TOOL_NOT_FOUND` - External tool not installed
- `PROJECT_NOT_FOUND` - Project does not exist
- `AGENT_NOT_FOUND` - Agent does not exist
- `THREAD_NOT_FOUND` - Thread does not exist
- `INVALID_FLAG` - Invalid flag combination
- `INVALID_INPUT` - Invalid parameter value
- `MISSING_REQUIRED` - Required parameter missing
- `TIMEOUT` - Operation timed out
- `NOT_IMPLEMENTED` - Feature not yet available
- `PERMISSION_DENIED` - Authorization required
- `INTERNAL_ERROR` - Unexpected internal error

### 4. Exit Codes

| Code | Meaning | When Used |
|------|---------|-----------|
| 0 | Success | Operation completed successfully |
| 1 | Error | Parse error, command failed, invalid input |
| 2 | Unavailable | Tool not installed, NOT_IMPLEMENTED |

**Exit Code Mapping:**
- `TOOL_NOT_FOUND` ‚Üí exit 2
- `NOT_IMPLEMENTED` ‚Üí exit 2
- `MISSING_REQUIRED` ‚Üí exit 1
- `INVALID_FLAG` ‚Üí exit 1
- `INVALID_INPUT` ‚Üí exit 1
- `SESSION_NOT_FOUND` ‚Üí exit 1
- All other errors ‚Üí exit 1

### 5. Pagination Pattern

Commands that return lists MUST support pagination:

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "total_matches": 150,      // Total available (before limit)
  "offset": 20,              // Current offset
  "count": 10,               // Items in this response
  "has_more": true,          // More items available
  "items": [...],
  "_agent_hints": {
    "next_offset": 30,       // Offset for next page
    "pages_remaining": 12    // Approximate pages left
  }
}
```

**Required Pagination Flags:**
- `--limit=N` - Max items to return (default varies by command, typically 20)
- `--offset=N` - Skip first N items (default 0)

**Required Response Fields:**
- `total_matches` or `total_messages` or similar - Total count before pagination
- `offset` - Current offset echoed back
- `count` - Number of items in current response
- `has_more` - Boolean indicating more results available
- `_agent_hints.next_offset` - Next offset value for convenience
- `_agent_hints.pages_remaining` - Approximate pages left (optional but recommended)

### 6. Verbose Flag Pattern

The `--verbose` flag is a global modifier that increases output detail. **It is optional and should only be implemented when there is meaningful additional detail to provide.**

**When to implement `--verbose`:**
- Safety checks (DCG) - show analysis details, rule explanations
- Status commands - show extended metadata, timing info
- Commands where abbreviated vs detailed output makes sense

**When NOT to implement `--verbose`:**
- Search commands that already return full content (xf-search)
- Commands where all useful information is already in the default output

**Example (DCG without --verbose):**
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "allowed": false,
  "severity": "high",
  "rationale": "Destructive command"
}
```

**Example (DCG with --verbose):**
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "allowed": false,
  "severity": "high",
  "rationale": "Destructive command",
  "rule_matched": "HARD_RESET",
  "analysis": {
    "command_parsed": ["git", "reset", "--hard"],
    "flags_detected": ["--hard"],
    "risk_factors": ["discards uncommitted changes", "cannot be undone"],
    "affected_files_estimate": 42
  }
}
```

### 7. Array Fields

Critical arrays are ALWAYS present, even if empty:
```json
{
  "sessions": [],    // Empty array, not absent
  "agents": [],      // Empty array, not absent
  "messages": [],    // Empty array, not absent
  "hits": []         // Empty array, not absent
}
```

This allows safe iteration without null checks.

### 8. Optional Fields

Use `omitempty` for optional fields - they are absent when not applicable:
- `error`, `error_code`, `hint` - Only on error
- `_agent_hints` - Only when hints available
- `variant` - Only if agent has model variant
- `body` - Only when `--include-bodies` set

### 9. Agent Hints

Include `_agent_hints` object with actionable suggestions:
```json
{
  "_agent_hints": {
    "summary": "Brief human-readable summary",
    "suggested_action": "What to do next",
    "next_offset": 20,
    "pages_remaining": 5,
    "safer_alternative": "Alternative command if blocked",
    "warnings": ["Any issues to be aware of"]
  }
}
```

### 10. Filter Echo Pattern

Commands with multiple filters SHOULD echo the active filters:
```json
{
  "success": true,
  "filters": {
    "status": "unread",
    "urgent_only": true,
    "thread": null,
    "since": "2024-01-01",
    "until": "2024-06-30"
  },
  ...
}
```

This helps agents verify their filters were applied correctly.

### 11. Context/Intent Pattern

Commands that benefit from context SHOULD accept `--context=`:
```bash
ntm --robot-dcg-check --command="rm -rf ./build" --context="Cleaning CI artifacts"
```

Context helps the tool make better decisions and improves error messages.

### 12. Documentation Requirements

Every robot command must document:
1. **Command interface** with examples
2. **Output schema** with JSON example
3. **Error response** with JSON example (including error_code)
4. **Modifier flags** table with scope (global/tool-specific)
5. **Exit codes** (must follow standard)
6. **Unit tests** (80% coverage target)
7. **E2E test script** with log prefix

### 13. Testing Requirements

#### Unit Test Coverage
Every robot command implementation must include unit tests for:
- Flag parsing for all parameters
- Required parameter validation
- Invalid input rejection
- Output JSON serialization
- Timestamp field inclusion
- Error code generation
- Exit code mapping
- Empty result handling
- Pagination calculations (offset, count, has_more, next_offset)
- Filter application
- Date range validation (if --since/--until supported)

#### E2E Test Script Standards
Every robot command must have an E2E test script following this pattern:

```bash
#!/bin/bash
# =============================================================================
# [E2E-XXX] Robot <Command> End-to-End Tests
# =============================================================================
# Tests the --robot-<command> for <description>.
# Exit codes: 0=all passed, 1=test failed, 77=skipped (tool not installed)
# =============================================================================

set -euo pipefail

LOG_PREFIX="[E2E-XXX]"
PASSED=0
FAILED=0
SKIPPED=0

log_info()  { echo "$LOG_PREFIX [INFO]  $*"; }
log_pass()  { echo "$LOG_PREFIX [PASS]  $*"; ((PASSED++)); }
log_fail()  { echo "$LOG_PREFIX [FAIL]  $*"; ((FAILED++)); }
log_skip()  { echo "$LOG_PREFIX [SKIP]  $*"; ((SKIPPED++)); }
log_debug() { echo "$LOG_PREFIX [DEBUG] $*"; }

cleanup() {
    log_info "Test summary: $PASSED passed, $FAILED failed, $SKIPPED skipped"
}
trap cleanup EXIT

log_info "Starting robot <command> E2E tests"
log_info "Test timestamp: $(date -Iseconds)"

# Prerequisite checks...
# Test cases with IDs (XXX-001, XXX-002, etc.)...
# Final summary...
```

**E2E Test Naming Convention:**
- XF commands: `[E2E-XF]` prefix, test IDs `XF-001`, `XF-002`, etc.
- DCG commands: `[E2E-DCG]` prefix, test IDs `DCG-001`, `DCG-002`, etc.
- MAIL commands: `[E2E-MAIL]` prefix, test IDs `MAIL-001`, `MAIL-002`, etc.
- CASS commands: `[E2E-CASS]` prefix, test IDs `CASS-001`, `CASS-002`, etc.

**Required Test Cases:**
1. Basic successful operation
2. All optional parameters individually
3. Missing required parameters
4. Invalid parameter values
5. Empty results handling
6. Exit code verification (0, 1, 2)
7. Timestamp field presence
8. Error code in error responses
9. Pagination (limit, offset, count, has_more)
10. Combined options
11. Date range validation (if applicable)

### 14. Backward Compatibility

- JSON output is the default and must remain stable
- TOON format is opt-in via `--robot-format=toon`
- Schema changes must be additive (new fields ok, removal requires deprecation)
- Deprecation period: 2 minor versions before removal

---

title: rano Integration: Network Observer for Per-Agent API Tracking
description:
Integrate rano for network-level visibility into agent API calls.

## Project Location
/dp/rano (Rust CLI)

## Problem Being Solved

When agents are working:
- Which agent is making API calls?
- What is the latency per call?
- How much data is being transferred?
- Which provider is being called?

Currently invisible without rano.

## What rano Does

rano monitors network activity per process:

### Data Collection
- Reads /proc/net/tcp, /proc/net/tcp6
- Correlates connections to PIDs via /proc/<pid>/fd
- Tracks bytes sent/received per connection
- Attributes to known providers (api.anthropic.com, api.openai.com, etc.)

### Key rano Commands
```bash
rano status              # Current connections
rano status --pid 1234   # Connections for specific PID
rano history --today     # Historical data
rano watch               # Real-time monitoring
```

## Integration Strategy for NTM

### 1. PID Mapping
NTM knows which PID belongs to which pane via tmux session ‚Üí pane ‚Üí shell PID.

### 2. Dashboard Widget
Show per-agent network activity.

### 3. Robot Mode Commands
- --robot-rano-stats: Get network stats per agent

## Acceptance Criteria

2. PID-to-pane mapping implemented

4. Provider breakdown accurate

title: Feature: Robot Diagnose Command (--robot-diagnose)
description:
## Overview

Add `ntm --robot-diagnose <session>` command that provides a single comprehensive
health check answering "what's wrong and how do I fix it?"

## Background

Currently diagnosing swarm health requires:
1. Loop through each pane
2. Capture and grep output for error patterns
3. Check process state
4. Interpret results
5. Decide on action

This is tedious and error-prone. A single diagnose command should do all of this.

## Proposed Interface

```bash
ntm --robot-diagnose myproject
```

## Proposed Output

```json
{
  "session": "myproject",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T23:15:00Z",
  "overall_health": "degraded",  // "healthy", "degraded", "critical"
  "summary": {
    "total_panes": 16,
    "healthy": 12,
    "rate_limited": 2,
    "unresponsive": 1,
    "crashed": 1
  },
  "panes": {
    "healthy": [2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16],
    "rate_limited": [4, 10],
    "unresponsive": [15],
    "crashed": [1]
  },
  "recommendations": [
    {
      "pane": 4,
      "status": "rate_limited",
      "action": "wait_or_caam",
      "reason": "Output contains 'You've hit your limit'",
      "reset_time": "4pm ET",  // parsed from output if available
      "auto_fixable": false
    },
    {
      "pane": 10,
      "status": "rate_limited",
      "action": "wait_or_caam",
      "reason": "Output contains 'You've hit your limit'",
      "auto_fixable": false
    },
    {
      "pane": 15,
      "status": "unresponsive",
      "action": "kill_restart",
      "reason": "No output for 312 seconds, process state: sleeping",
      "auto_fixable": true,
      "fix_command": "ntm --robot-restart-pane myproject 15"
    },
    {
      "pane": 1,
      "status": "crashed",
      "action": "restart_cc",
      "reason": "Shell prompt visible, no agent process",
      "auto_fixable": true,
      "fix_command": "ntm --robot-restart-pane myproject 1"
    }
  ],
  "auto_fix_available": true,
  "auto_fix_command": "ntm --robot-diagnose myproject --fix"
}
```

## Health Classification Logic

| Status | Detection Criteria |
|--------|-------------------|
| healthy | Agent process running, recent output, no error patterns |
| rate_limited | Output contains rate limit patterns |
| unresponsive | No output for >5min AND process running |
| crashed | No agent process OR zombie process |
| unknown | Cannot determine (provide raw data) |

## Flags

- `--fix`: Automatically fix what can be fixed (crashed/unresponsive, not rate limits)
- `--json`: (default) JSON output
- `--brief`: Just summary, no per-pane details
- `--pane=N`: Diagnose specific pane only

## Why This Matters

Reduces "what's wrong?" from a 5-minute manual inspection to a 1-second command.
The recommendations with fix commands enable scripted recovery.
