title: TOON: Research Go integration approach (CGO vs subprocess)
description:
Evaluate approaches for calling toon_rust from Go code.

## Options

### Option A: Subprocess (Simpler)
Call toon CLI as subprocess:
```go
cmd := exec.Command("toon", "encode")
cmd.Stdin = strings.NewReader(jsonData)
toonOutput, _ := cmd.Output()
```

Pros: Simple, no CGO, easy updates
Cons: Process overhead per call, latency

### Option B: CGO + Rust FFI (Faster)
Build toon_rust as C-compatible library, call from Go via CGO.

Pros: Near-zero overhead, native speed
Cons: CGO complexity, cross-platform builds, version coupling

### Option C: WASM (Middle Ground)
Compile toon_rust to WASM, run via Go WASM runtime.

Pros: Sandboxed, cross-platform, single binary
Cons: WASM overhead, runtime dependency

## Recommendation

Start with **subprocess** for simplicity. If latency becomes issue, migrate to CGO.

Robot mode commands are not high-frequency (maybe 1-10/second), so subprocess overhead (~5ms) is acceptable.

## Research Tasks
1. Verify toon CLI exists and has encode/decode commands
2. Benchmark subprocess overhead
3. Evaluate if CGO is needed for any use case
4. Check if toon_rust has WASM build

## Deliverable
Decision document with benchmarks and recommendation.

```go
type CommonFlags struct {
```

title: xf: Implement --robot-xf-search command
description:
## Overview

Add `ntm --robot-xf-search` command for searching X/Twitter archives via xf integration.

## IMPORTANT: API Design Consistency

This command follows the **harmonized** robot mode patterns for tool bridges:
- **Naming**: `--robot-xf-search` (tool prefix: xf, no inline value)
- **Query param**: `--query=QUERY` (standard modifier flag)
- **Shared modifiers**: `--limit=N`, `--since=DATE`, `--until=DATE`, `--offset=N` (global flags)
- **Tool-specific modifiers**: `--xf-mode=`, `--xf-sort=` (unique to xf)

**NOTE**: This supersedes bd-1osrc which proposed a different interface. This bead is the canonical implementation.

## Command Interface

```bash
# Basic search (uses --query= modifier, NOT inline value)
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="error handling patterns"

# With search mode
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="rust async" --xf-mode=semantic --limit=10

# With date range filter
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="claude code" --since=2024-01-01 --until=2024-06-30

# With pagination
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="ai agents" --limit=20 --offset=20

# Sort by date (newest first)
ntm --robot-xf-search --query="llm" --xf-sort=date
```

## Output Schema

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "query": "error handling patterns",
  "mode": "hybrid",
  "sort": "relevance",
  "count": 5,
  "offset": 0,
  "hits": [
    {
      "type": "tweet",
      "date": "2023-06-15",
      "content": "Been thinking about error handling patterns in Rust...",
      "score": 0.95,
      "url": "https://x.com/user/status/123456",
      "author": "rustacean",
      "thread_id": "123456"
    }
  ],
  "total_matches": 150,
  "has_more": true,
  "_agent_hints": {
    "next_offset": 5,
    "pages_remaining": 29,
    "suggested_query_refinement": null
  }
}
```

## Error Response

```json
{
  "success": false,
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z",
  "error": "xf not found in PATH",
  "error_code": "TOOL_NOT_FOUND",
  "hint": "Install xf: go install github.com/.../xf@latest"
}
```

## Modifier Flags

| Flag | Description | Default | Scope |
|------|-------------|---------|-------|
| `--query=Q` | Search query (required) | - | **Required** |
| `--xf-mode=M` | Search mode: keyword, semantic, hybrid | hybrid | Tool-specific |
| `--xf-sort=S` | Sort order: relevance, date, date-asc | relevance | Tool-specific |
| `--limit=N` | Max results to return | 20 | Global shared |
| `--offset=N` | Skip first N results (pagination) | 0 | Global shared |
| `--since=DATE` | Filter to tweets after date (YYYY-MM-DD) | none | Global shared |
| `--until=DATE` | Filter to tweets before date (YYYY-MM-DD) | none | Global shared |

## Code Location
- internal/robot/xf_search.go

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `--robot-xf-search` flag registered in root.go (bool flag)
- [ ] `--query=` required modifier for search term
- [ ] `--xf-mode=` accepts: keyword, semantic, hybrid (default: hybrid)

- [ ] `--limit=N` caps results (default 20) - uses global shared flag
- [ ] `--offset=N` skips first N results for pagination - uses global shared flag
- [ ] `--since=DATE` filters by start date - uses global shared flag
- [ ] `--until=DATE` filters by end date - uses global shared flag
- [ ] JSON output matches schema exactly (includes timestamp, offset, total_matches)
- [ ] Missing xf returns actionable error with hint and error_code

```bash
log_info "========================================="

if [[ $FAILED -gt 0 ]]; then
    exit 1
fi

log_info "All robot xf E2E tests passed!"
exit 0
```

## API Harmonization Notes

This bead was updated to follow the canonical robot mode tool bridge pattern:
- Tool bridges use `--robot-<tool>-<action>` (bool flag)
- Parameters use modifier flags (`--query=`, `--limit=`)
- Global shared flags (`--limit`, `--since`, `--until`, `--offset`) are NOT tool-prefixed
- Tool-specific flags (`--xf-mode`, `--xf-sort`) ARE tool-prefixed

This matches the established JFP and CASS patterns.

title: EPIC: Progressive CLI Discovery System - Tiered Command Visibility
description:
## Overview
Implement a proficiency-tiered command discovery system that progressively reveals NTM commands as users gain experience. This reduces cognitive overload for new users while preserving full power for experts.

## Problem Statement
NTM has 40+ commands and flags. New users face a wall of options in --help, making the tool feel overwhelming. Meanwhile, power users need quick access to advanced features. Current flat --help listing serves neither audience well.

## Design Philosophy
- Tier 1 (Apprentice): Core workflow commands only (spawn, send, status, kill, help)
- Tier 2 (Journeyman): Full standard commands (all current public commands)
- Tier 3 (Master): Advanced/experimental features (robot mode, internal debugging)

## Key Features
1. Tiered help output: Commands filtered by proficiency level
2. Automatic tier promotion: Track usage patterns to suggest promotions
3. ntm level command: View/change proficiency tier
4. Contextual suggestions: Suggest relevant commands based on current state
5. Progressive disclosure in dashboard: Show only tier-appropriate controls

## Configuration
- Store tier in ~/.config/ntm/proficiency.json
- Support NTM_PROFICIENCY_TIER env var override
- Default new users to Tier 1

## Success Criteria
- New users see only 5-7 essential commands initially
- Help output adapts to proficiency tier
- Users can manually upgrade/downgrade tier
- Dashboard respects tier for keybinding hints
- Contextual suggestions appear for common next actions

## Files Likely Affected
- internal/cli/help.go (new file for tiered help)
- internal/cli/root.go (tier-aware command registration)
- internal/config/proficiency.go (new file for tier management)
- internal/tui/dashboard/help.go (tier-aware hints)

## Implementation Phases
1. Define tier taxonomy and command categorization
2. Implement proficiency config storage
3. Create tiered help renderer
4. Add usage tracking for auto-promotion
5. Implement contextual suggestions
6. Update dashboard help to respect tiers
notes: Closed as dropped: only keep help --minimal/--full + contextual suggestions; no tier gating.

All 6 child tasks done: taxonomy defined (3 tiers with command categorization), proficiency config storage (JSON-based with env override), ntm level command (show/up/down/set tiers), usage tracking (commands, sessions, advanced attempts), unit tests (56+ tests), E2E tests (12 tests). System reduces cognitive overload for new users while preserving full power for experts.

CAAM Integration: Coding Agent Account Manager for Rate Limit Recovery
description:
Integrate CAAM (coding_agent_account_manager) for instant account switching when agents hit rate limits.

## Project Location
/dp/coding_agent_account_manager (Rust CLI)

## Problem Being Solved

Rate limits are the #1 operational pain point in multi-agent workflows:
- Claude Code: 5-minute to multi-hour cooldowns
- OpenAI Codex: Per-minute/per-day limits
- Gemini: Regional and tier-based limits

Current workaround: Wait, or manually switch browser profiles. This kills productivity.

## What CAAM Does

CAAM is an OAuth token vault with instant profile switching:
- Stores encrypted OAuth tokens for multiple accounts per provider
- Detects rate limit responses automatically
- Switches to next available account in <100ms
- Tracks usage per account to predict limits
- Supports: Claude, OpenAI, Gemini, Anthropic API, etc.

### Key CAAM Commands
```bash
caam list                    # List all accounts
caam switch claude account2  # Switch to specific account
caam status                  # Show current account and usage
caam auto-rotate             # Enable automatic rotation on rate limit
```

## Integration Strategy for NTM

### 1. Rate Limit Detection
NTM monitors agent output for rate limit signals:
- "Rate limit exceeded"
- HTTP 429 responses
- Provider-specific messages

### 2. Automatic Recovery
When rate limit detected:
1. Pause agent activity
2. Call: caam switch <provider> --next
3. Update environment variables for agent
4. Resume agent

### 3. Robot Mode Commands
- --robot-switch-account: Manually trigger switch
- --robot-account-status: Get current account info
- --robot-accounts-list: List available accounts

### 4. Dashboard Integration
- Show current account per agent
- Show usage/limit percentages
- Alert when approaching 80% of limit

## Considerations
- Security: CAAM handles encryption, NTM just invokes CLI
- Atomicity: Account switch must be atomic (no half-switched state)
- Recovery: If CAAM fails, agent should continue with current account
- Latency: <100ms target for account switch

title: Add ntm context-inject - inject AGENTS.md and README.md content into first prompt automatically
description:
Add ntm context-inject command - inject AGENTS.md and README.md content into first prompt automatically.

## Problem Being Solved

Agents often need project context (AGENTS.md, README.md) to understand the codebase. Manually including this is tedious.

## Command Design

```bash
ntm context-inject SESSION [--files FILE_LIST] [--max-tokens N]
```

### Behavior
1. Reads AGENTS.md and README.md from project root
2. Formats content with clear section headers
3. Sends to pane 1 (controller) or all panes with --all

### Default Files
- AGENTS.md (if exists)
- README.md (if exists)
- .claude/project_context.md (if exists)

### Options
- --files: Comma-separated list of files to inject
- --max-tokens: Truncate if content exceeds N tokens
- --all: Inject to all panes, not just pane 1

## Robot Mode API
ntm --robot-context-inject=SESSION [--files=FILE_LIST]

Returns JSON:
```json
{
  "session": "my_session",
  "injected_files": ["AGENTS.md", "README.md"],
  "total_tokens": 1500,
  "panes_injected": [1]
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria

1. ntm context-inject command exists and shows in help
2. Reads AGENTS.md and README.md by default
3. Content formatted with ### headers for each file
4. --files flag overrides default file list

title: Task: Add --robot-mail-check flag
description:
## Overview

Add `--robot-mail-check` flag for AI orchestrators to check agent inboxes via Agent Mail integration.

## IMPORTANT: API Design Consistency

This command follows the **harmonized** robot mode patterns for tool bridges:
- **Naming**: `--robot-mail-check` (no inline value)
- **Project param**: `--project=PROJ` (standard modifier flag)
- **Agent param**: `--agent=ID` (optional filter modifier)
- **Shared modifiers**: `--limit=N`, `--offset=N`, `--since=DATE`, `--until=DATE` (global flags)
- Consistent with `--robot-xf-search --query=Q`, `--robot-dcg-check --command=CMD`

## Command Interface

```bash
# Check all agent inboxes for a project
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject

# Check specific agent inbox
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --agent=cc_1

# Include full message bodies
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --include-bodies

# Limit and paginate results
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --limit=10 --offset=20

# Only urgent messages
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --urgent-only

# Filter by read status
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --status=unread

# Filter by date range
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --since=2024-01-01 --until=2024-06-30

# Check specific thread
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --thread=TKT-api-design

# Verbose output with extra details
ntm --robot-mail-check --project=myproject --verbose
```

## Output Schema

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "timestamp": "2026-01-22T10:30:00Z",
  "project": "myproject",
  "agent": "cc_1",
  "filters": {
    "status": "all",
    "urgent_only": false,
    "thread": null,
    "since": null,
    "until": null
  },
  "unread": 2,
  "urgent": 1,
  "total_messages": 45,
  "offset": 0,
  "count": 10,
  "messages": [
    {
      "id": "msg-123",

      "subject": "Re: API endpoint design",
      "preview": "I think we should use...",
      "body": null,
      "thread_id": "TKT-api-design",
      "importance": "normal",
      "read": false,
      "timestamp": "2026-01-22T10:25:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "has_more": true,
  "_agent_hints": {
    "suggested_action": "Reply to agent-cc-2 about API design",
    "unread_summary": "2 unread messages, 1 urgent",
    "next_offset": 10,
    "pages_remaining": 4,
    "oldest_unread": "2026-01-22T08:15:00Z"
  }
}
```

## Error Response

```json
{
  "success": false,
  "timestamp": "2026-01-22T10:30:00Z",
  "error": "Agent Mail not available",
  "error_code": "TOOL_NOT_FOUND",
  "hint": "Start Agent Mail server: am start"
```

title: Feature: CLI Commands - ntm ensemble command family
description:
# Feature: CLI Commands - Ensemble-first interface

**Users pick goals, not modes.** The primary CLI interface is ensemble selection.

## Primary Commands

### ntm ensemble [ensemble-name] [problem]
Run a named ensemble:
```bash
ntm ensemble project-diagnosis 'What are the main issues with this codebase?'
ntm ensemble idea-forge 'What features should we add next?'
ntm ensemble spec-critique 'Review the API specification'
ntm ensemble safety-risk 'Analyze security concerns'
```

### ntm ensemble list
Show available ensembles with descriptions:
```
Available Ensembles:

project-diagnosis   Systems analysis, red-team, failure modes
idea-forge          Divergent brainstorming, innovation
spec-critique       Requirements review, edge cases
safety-risk         Threat modeling, compliance
architecture-review Multi-perspective arch analysis
tech-debt-triage    Dependency analysis, prioritization
bug-hunt            Multi-angle bug detection
root-cause          Causal + counterfactual analysis
strategic-planning  Long-term planning under uncertainty

Use 'ntm ensemble [name] --help' for details
```

### ntm ensemble [name] --help
Show ensemble details (modes, strategy, typical budget).

### ntm ensemble status [session]
Check running ensemble status (uses existing status patterns).

### ntm ensemble synthesize [session]
Trigger synthesis for completed ensemble.

## Advanced Commands (Power Users)

### Custom modes
```bash
# Explicit mode list by id or code
ntm ensemble --modes=A1,B13,F43 --question 'Analyze the auth system'
```
- If any **advanced tier** modes are included, require explicit flag: `--allow-advanced`.
- Print a warning when advanced modes are used.

### ntm ensemble modes
Browse the mode catalog:
```bash
ntm ensemble modes                    # List core modes (default)
ntm ensemble modes --all              # Include advanced
ntm ensemble modes --category formal  # Filter by category
ntm ensemble modes --verbose          # Full mode details
```

### ntm ensemble presets
Alias for `ntm ensemble list` (shared implementation).

## Flags (CLI)
Common flags across ensemble commands:
```
--agents string      Override agent distribution (cc=3,cod=2,gmi=1)
--assignment string  round-robin|affinity|explicit
--allow-advanced     Explicit opt-in for advanced/experimental modes
--tier string        core|advanced|experimental|all (list/modes only)
--format string      table|json|yaml (list/modes/presets/status/synthesize)
--output string      Write synthesis to file (synthesize only)
--no-questions       Skip targeted questions (use auto-context only)
--no-cache           Bypass context pack cache
--budget-total int   Override total tokens
--budget-per-agent int Override per-agent cap
```

## Automation (Robot API)
Automation uses **robot flags**, not a `--robot` flag on the CLI:
- `ntm --robot-ensemble=SESSION`
- `ntm --robot-ensemble-spawn=SESSION`
- `ntm --robot-ensemble-synthesize=SESSION`
- `ntm --robot-ensemble-modes`
- `ntm --robot-ensemble-presets`

## Files
- internal/cli/ensemble.go - Main ensemble command
- internal/cli/ensemble_list.go - List ensembles
- internal/cli/ensemble_status.go - Status command
- internal/cli/ensemble_synthesize.go - Synthesis trigger
- internal/cli/ensemble_modes.go - Mode browser

## What It Does
Intelligent timing of agent spawns and prompts to avoid hitting provider rate limits.

- Currently: Simultaneous spawns can trigger rate limits
- After: Staggered launches prevent limit hits
- Critical for large swarms

## Features
- Configurable stagger delay (default 30s)
- Per-provider timing awareness
- Adaptive delays based on rate limit history

3. Adaptive delays based on rate limit tracker
4. ntm spawn --stagger DURATION flag works
5. Rate limit events reduce stagger automatically
6. Unit tests for stagger logic (80% coverage)
7. E2E tests verify no rate limits hit with staggering

title: Implement hard kill fallback using kill -9
description:
Implement hard kill fallback when soft exit fails.

## When to Use
When soft exit (Ctrl-C) doesn't work after 3 seconds, need to kill -9 the child process.

## Implementation
1. Get shell PID from tmux list-panes
2. Get child PID via pgrep -P <shell_pid>
3. kill -9 <child_pid>
4. Wait for shell to return to prompt

## Code Pattern
pane_pid=$(tmux list-panes -t session:1 -F '#{pane_index} #{pane_pid}' | grep '^N ' | awk '{print $2}')
child_pid=$(pgrep -P $pane_pid | head -1)
kill -9 $child_pid

## Error Handling
- If no child process: already exited, proceed
- If permission denied: return error with diagnostic info
- If shell doesn't return after kill: serious issue, return detailed error

title: Support external tmux sessions not created by ntm
description:
## Problem

When users create tmux sessions manually (not via `ntm spawn`), ntm commands like `ntm send`, `ntm list`, `ntm status` have issues:
- `ntm send` tries to use pane numbering that assumes ntm's convention (session:N)
- Session metadata is missing (agent types, project mapping)
- Cannot properly target panes by agent type (--cc, --cod, --gmi)

## Example

User creates sessions manually:
```bash
tmux new-session -d -s cc_agents_1
# ... creates 12 panes with cc running in each
```

Then tries to use ntm:
```bash
ntm send cc_agents_1 --cc 'Hello'  # Doesn't work properly
```

## Proposed Solution

1. Add `ntm adopt <session>` command to register external sessions
2. Allow specifying agent type mapping during adoption
3. Store metadata in a way that persists across restarts
4. Make `ntm list` show adopted sessions with a marker
5. Full functionality (send, status, copy, etc.) should work with adopted sessions

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `ntm adopt <session> [--cc=PANES] [--cod=PANES] [--gmi=PANES]` command
- [ ] Adopted sessions appear in `ntm list`
- [ ] `ntm send` works correctly with adopted sessions
- [ ] `ntm status` shows pane details for adopted sessions
- [ ] Documentation updated

title: Fix Fleet count inconsistency (0/17 vs 17 panes)
description:
## Problem
The dashboard shows inconsistent fleet counts: "Fleet: 0/17" in status bar vs "17 panes" in the stats bar.

## Screenshot Evidence
- Status bar: "Fleet: 0/17 (C:16)"
- Stats bar badge: "17 panes"

This suggests 0 active agents out of 17 panes, with 16 Claude instances - but the "0" is likely incorrect.

## Code Locations
- internal/tui/dashboard/dashboard.go:2112-2180 - renderStatsBar()
- internal/tui/dashboard/panels/ticker.go - Fleet count in ticker
- Model fields: panes, claudeCount, codexCount, geminiCount

## Possible Causes
1. **Different data sources** - Stats bar uses len(m.panes), ticker uses different count
2. **Async update race** - Pane count updated but agent count not yet
3. **Filter mismatch** - Active vs total panes counted differently
4. **Status detection lag** - Agent status not yet determined for some panes

## Investigation
\`\`\`go
// Check these fields are consistent:
log.Debug("fleet counts",
    "total_panes", len(m.panes),
    "claude_count", m.claudeCount,
    "codex_count", m.codexCount,
    "gemini_count", m.geminiCount,
    "user_count", m.userCount,
    "agent_statuses", len(m.agentStatuses))
\`\`\`

## Fix Pattern
\`\`\`go
// Ensure consistent counting
func (m *Model) updateCounts() {
    m.claudeCount = 0
    m.codexCount = 0
    m.geminiCount = 0
    m.userCount = 0
    
    for _, pane := range m.panes {
        switch pane.AgentType {
        case "claude":
            m.claudeCount++
        case "codex":
            m.codexCount++
        case "gemini":
            m.geminiCount++
        default:
            m.userCount++
        }
    }
    
    // Active = has known status
    m.activeCount = 0
    for _, pane := range m.panes {
        if status, ok := m.agentStatuses[pane.ID]; ok && status.State != "unknown" {
            m.activeCount++
        }
    }
}

// Ticker should use same source
func (t *TickerPanel) SetFleetData(active, total int) {
    t.activeAgents = active
    t.totalAgents = total
}
\`\`\`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Fleet count shows consistent X/Y across all UI locations
- [ ] "X" represents agents with known status
- [ ] "Y" represents total panes
- [ ] Counts update atomically (no partial updates visible)

## Unit Tests
1. TestFleetCount_Consistent - stats bar and ticker show same totals
2. TestFleetCount_ActiveDefinition - active = has non-unknown status
3. TestFleetCount_UpdateAtomic - counts update together
4. TestFleetCount_AgentTypes - Claude/Codex/Gemini counts sum correctly

## Logging
- DEBUG: Log count calculations with breakdown
- INFO: Log fleet count changes
- WARN: Log inconsistencies between counts

title: EPIC: Agent Activity Timeline Visualization
description:
## Overview
Add a Gantt-chart style timeline visualization showing agent state transitions over time. This provides crucial historical context for understanding what agents did and when, enabling better debugging and optimization.

## Problem Statement
Current NTM status shows only instantaneous state. Users can't see:
- When an agent started/stopped working
- How long tasks took
- Overlapping activity patterns
- Idle time vs busy time
- Historical state for debugging

## Key Features
1. Timeline panel in dashboard showing horizontal bars per agent
2. Color-coded states: idle (gray), working (green), waiting (yellow), error (red)
3. Scrollable time window with zoom controls
4. Event markers for prompts sent, errors, completions
5. Export timeline to SVG/PNG for reports

## Technical Design
1. State tracking:
   - Record state transitions with timestamps
   - Store in memory during session
   - Optionally persist to file for post-session analysis

2. Timeline rendering:
   - Use lipgloss for colored blocks
   - Calculate time scale based on window width
   - Support minute/hour/day scales

3. Data model:
   type AgentEvent struct {
     AgentID   string
     State     AgentState  // idle, working, waiting, error
     Timestamp time.Time
     Details   string      // prompt sent, error message, etc.
   }

## Success Criteria
- Timeline panel shows agent activity over time
- States are clearly color-coded
- Time scale adapts to session duration
- Can scroll through history
- Export works for offline analysis

## Behavior

When --fix is provided:

- Only fix auto_fixable=true items

title: Add ntm send --randomize - randomize order of individualized prompts to avoid thundering herd on same files
description:
## Overview
Add --randomize flag to ntm send to randomize the order of individualized prompts, avoiding thundering herd problems when multiple agents start working on overlapping files.

## Problem
When sending individualized prompts (e.g., each agent gets a different bead), agents often start simultaneously on related files. This causes:
- Git conflicts when multiple agents edit the same area
- File reservation conflicts in Agent Mail
- Wasted work from merge conflicts

## Solution
`ntm send myproject --randomize` shuffles the order of prompts before sending.

## Implementation
```go
func randomizePrompts(prompts []Prompt) []Prompt {
    shuffled := make([]Prompt, len(prompts))
    copy(shuffled, prompts)
    rand.Shuffle(len(shuffled), func(i, j int) {
        shuffled[i], shuffled[j] = shuffled[j], shuffled[i]
    })
    return shuffled
}
```

## CLI Examples
```bash
# Randomize prompt order
ntm send myproject --randomize

# Combine with batch
ntm send myproject --batch prompts.txt --randomize

# Combine with delay for extra staggering  
ntm send myproject --randomize --delay 2s
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Prompts shuffled before sending
- [ ] Deterministic seed option for reproducibility (--seed=N)
- [ ] Works with --batch and --distribute
- [ ] Logging shows shuffle order
- [ ] No effect if only one prompt

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Shuffle produces different order
- Unit test: Seed produces reproducible order
- E2E test: Randomized batch send
notes:
## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests: core logic, error paths, edge cases.
- E2E scripts: full CLI/robot flow with detailed log/slog prefixes (e.g., [E2E-<AREA>]) and include session/agent/bead IDs.
- If structured outputs are affected, assert schema stability + deterministic ordering.

title: Test: Mock tmux client for testing
description:
## Purpose
End-to-end integration test script for the complete swarm orchestration workflow, from scanning to agent launch to limit detection and respawn.

## Test Script Structure

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
# scripts/test_swarm_e2e.sh
# End-to-end test for weighted multi-project agent swarm orchestration
#
# Prerequisites:
# - ntm binary built and in PATH
# - tmux installed
# - br (beads_rust) installed
# - Test project directories set up

set -euo pipefail

# ============================================================================
# Configuration
# ============================================================================
TEST_DIR="${TEST_DIR:-/tmp/ntm_e2e_test_$$}"
LOG_FILE="${TEST_DIR}/e2e_test.log"
VERBOSE="${VERBOSE:-1}"

# Colors for output
RED="\033[0;31m"
GREEN="\033[0;32m"
YELLOW="\033[1;33m"
NC="\033[0m" # No Color

# ============================================================================
# Logging Functions
# ============================================================================
log() {
    local level=$1
    shift
    local msg="$*"
    local timestamp=$(date "+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%3N")
    echo -e "[$timestamp] [$level] $msg" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
}

log_info()  { log "INFO " "$@"; }
log_warn()  { log "WARN " "${YELLOW}$*${NC}"; }
log_error() { log "ERROR" "${RED}$*${NC}"; }
log_pass()  { log "PASS " "${GREEN}$*${NC}"; }
log_fail()  { log "FAIL " "${RED}$*${NC}"; }

log_section() {
    echo "" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    echo "============================================================" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    echo "  $1" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    echo "============================================================" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
}

# ============================================================================
# Setup Functions
# ============================================================================
setup_test_environment() {
    log_section "Setting up test environment"
    
    mkdir -p "$TEST_DIR"
    log_info "Test directory: $TEST_DIR"
    log_info "Log file: $LOG_FILE"
    
    # Create test projects with different bead counts
    log_info "Creating test projects..."
    
    # Tier 1 project (400+ beads)
    create_test_project "tier1-project" 450
    
    # Tier 2 project (100-399 beads)
    create_test_project "tier2-project" 200
    
    # Tier 3 project (<100 beads)
    create_test_project "tier3-project" 50
    
    # Project without beads (should be skipped)
    mkdir -p "$TEST_DIR/no-beads-project"
    log_info "Created no-beads-project (should be skipped)"
    
    log_pass "Test environment setup complete"
}

create_test_project() {
    local name=$1
    local bead_count=$2
    local project_dir="$TEST_DIR/$name"
    
    mkdir -p "$project_dir/.beads"
    
    # Create mock beads
    for i in $(seq 1 $bead_count); do
        echo "{\"id\":\"bd-$i\",\"status\":\"open\",\"title\":\"Test bead $i\"}" >> "$project_dir/.beads/issues.jsonl"
    done
    
    log_info "Created $name with $bead_count beads"
}

# ============================================================================
# Test Cases
# ============================================================================
test_dry_run() {
    log_section "Test: Dry Run Mode"
    
    log_info "Running: ntm swarm --scan-dir $TEST_DIR --dry-run"
    
    local output
    output=$(ntm swarm --scan-dir "$TEST_DIR" --dry-run 2>&1) || {
        log_fail "Dry run command failed"
        log_error "Output: $output"
        return 1
    }
    
    log_info "Dry run output:"
    echo "$output" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    
    # Verify expected output
    if echo "$output" | grep -q "tier1-project"; then
        log_pass "Tier 1 project detected"
    else
        log_fail "Tier 1 project NOT detected"
        return 1
    fi
    
    if echo "$output" | grep -q "tier2-project"; then
        log_pass "Tier 2 project detected"
    else
        log_fail "Tier 2 project NOT detected"
        return 1
    fi
    
    if echo "$output" | grep -q "no-beads-project"; then
        log_fail "No-beads project should NOT appear"
        return 1
    else
        log_pass "No-beads project correctly excluded"
    fi
    
    if echo "$output" | grep -q "Dry-run complete"; then
        log_pass "Dry run completed without execution"
    else
        log_fail "Dry run indicator not found"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log_pass "Dry run test PASSED"
}

test_plan_output() {
    log_section "Test: Plan JSON Output"
    
    local plan_file="$TEST_DIR/swarm_plan.json"
    
    log_info "Running: ntm swarm --scan-dir $TEST_DIR --dry-run --output $plan_file"
    
    ntm swarm --scan-dir "$TEST_DIR" --dry-run --output "$plan_file" 2>&1 | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    
    if [[ \! -f "$plan_file" ]]; then
        log_fail "Plan file not created"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log_info "Plan file created: $plan_file"
    log_info "Plan contents:"
    cat "$plan_file" | tee -a "$LOG_FILE"
    
    # Validate JSON structure
    if \! jq -e . "$plan_file" > /dev/null 2>&1; then
        log_fail "Plan file is not valid JSON"
        return 1
    fi
    log_pass "Plan file is valid JSON"
    
    # Check required fields
    local total_agents
    total_agents=$(jq -r ".total_agents" "$plan_file")
    log_info "Total agents in plan: $total_agents"
    
    if [[ "$total_agents" -gt 0 ]]; then
        log_pass "Plan contains agent allocations"
    else
        log_fail "Plan has no agent allocations"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log_pass "Plan output test PASSED"
}

test_session_creation() {
    log_section "Test: Session Creation (requires tmux)"
    
    # Skip if tmux not available
    if \! command -v tmux &> /dev/null; then
        log_warn "tmux not available, skipping session creation test"
        return 0
    fi
    
    # Clean up any existing test sessions
    tmux kill-session -t "cc_agents_1" 2>/dev/null || true
    
    log_info "Running swarm with single session for test..."
    log_info "ntm swarm --scan-dir $TEST_DIR --sessions-per-type 1 --dry-run"
    
    # For actual execution (commented out for safety):
    # ntm swarm --scan-dir "$TEST_DIR" --sessions-per-type 1
    
    # Verify sessions would be created
    local plan_file="$TEST_DIR/session_test_plan.json"
    ntm swarm --scan-dir "$TEST_DIR" --sessions-per-type 1 --dry-run --output "$plan_file"
    
    local session_count
    session_count=$(jq -r ".sessions | length" "$plan_file")
    log_info "Sessions in plan: $session_count"
    
    if [[ "$session_count" -ge 3 ]]; then
        log_pass "Plan includes expected session count (3 types)"
    else
        log_fail "Unexpected session count: $session_count"
        return 1
    fi
    
    # Check session naming
    local cc_session
    cc_session=$(jq -r ".sessions[] | select(.agent_type==\"cc\") | .name" "$plan_file" | head -1)
    log_info "CC session name: $cc_session"
    
    if [[ "$cc_session" == "cc_agents_1" ]]; then
        log_pass "Session naming is correct"
    else
        log_fail "Session naming mismatch: expected cc_agents_1, got $cc_session"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log_pass "Session creation test PASSED"
}

test_allocation_tiers() {
    log_section "Test: Allocation Tier Calculations"
    
    local plan_file="$TEST_DIR/tier_test_plan.json"
    ntm swarm --scan-dir "$TEST_DIR" --dry-run --output "$plan_file"
    
    # Check tier 1 allocation
    local tier1_cc
    tier1_cc=$(jq -r ".allocations[] | select(.project.name==\"tier1-project\") | .cc_agents" "$plan_file")
    log_info "Tier 1 (450 beads) CC allocation: $tier1_cc"
    
    # Check tier 2 allocation  
    local tier2_cc
    tier2_cc=$(jq -r ".allocations[] | select(.project.name==\"tier2-project\") | .cc_agents" "$plan_file")
    log_info "Tier 2 (200 beads) CC allocation: $tier2_cc"
    
    # Check tier 3 allocation
    local tier3_cc
    tier3_cc=$(jq -r ".allocations[] | select(.project.name==\"tier3-project\") | .cc_agents" "$plan_file")
    log_info "Tier 3 (50 beads) CC allocation: $tier3_cc"
    
    # Verify tier hierarchy
    if [[ "$tier1_cc" -gt "$tier2_cc" ]] && [[ "$tier2_cc" -ge "$tier3_cc" ]]; then
        log_pass "Tier allocation hierarchy is correct"
    else
        log_fail "Tier allocation hierarchy violated: T1=$tier1_cc, T2=$tier2_cc, T3=$tier3_cc"
        return 1
    fi
    
    log_pass "Allocation tier test PASSED"
}

# ============================================================================
# Cleanup
# ============================================================================
cleanup() {
    log_section "Cleanup"
    
    # Kill any test tmux sessions
    tmux kill-session -t "cc_agents_1" 2>/dev/null || true
    tmux kill-session -t "cod_agents_1" 2>/dev/null || true
    tmux kill-session -t "gmi_agents_1" 2>/dev/null || true
    
    if [[ "${KEEP_TEST_DIR:-0}" == "0" ]]; then
        log_info "Removing test directory: $TEST_DIR"
        rm -rf "$TEST_DIR"
    else
        log_info "Keeping test directory: $TEST_DIR"
    fi
    
    log_info "Cleanup complete"
}

# ============================================================================
# Main
# ============================================================================
main() {
    log_section "NTM Swarm E2E Test Suite"
    log_info "Starting at $(date)"
    log_info "Test directory: $TEST_DIR"
    
    trap cleanup EXIT
    
    local failed=0
    
    setup_test_environment
    
    test_dry_run || ((failed++))
    test_plan_output || ((failed++))
    test_allocation_tiers || ((failed++))
    test_session_creation || ((failed++))
    
    log_section "Test Summary"
    if [[ $failed -eq 0 ]]; then
        log_pass "All tests PASSED"
        exit 0
    else
        log_fail "$failed test(s) FAILED"
        exit 1
    fi
}

main "$@"
```

title: Add ntm assign command - combines bv triage with ntm send in one step
description:
## Overview
Canonical work distribution command: `ntm assign`. Combines BV triage with ntm send.

## Supported Strategies
- **balanced** (default): Balance workload across idle agents, consider current assignment counts
- **speed**: Prioritize agents with low context usage for fast completion
- **quality**: Match agent type to bead type using capability matrix
- **dependency**: Prioritize beads that unblock the most downstream work (high PageRank/betweenness)
- **round-robin**: Deterministic even distribution (bead[i] -> agent[i % N])

## Command Design
```bash
# Preview assignments (default - no sending)
ntm assign myproject

# Execute assignments immediately
ntm assign myproject --auto

# With strategy
ntm assign myproject --strategy=quality --auto

# Limit number of assignments
ntm assign myproject --limit=5 --auto

# Assign specific beads
ntm assign myproject --beads=bd-123,bd-456 --auto

# Filter agent types (two naming styles for convenience)
ntm assign myproject --cc-only --auto
ntm assign myproject --agent=claude --auto    # Equivalent
ntm assign myproject --agent=codex --auto
ntm assign myproject --agent=gemini --auto
```

## Common Flags (all ntm commands)
```bash
--json           # Machine-readable JSON output
-v, --verbose    # Show detailed scoring/decision logs
-q, --quiet      # Suppress non-essential output
--timeout=30s    # Timeout for external calls (bv, br, Agent Mail)
--dry-run        # Alias for no --auto (preview mode)
--no-color       # Disable colored output
```

## Prompt Template System
Built-in templates:
- **impl**: "Work on bead {BEAD_ID}: {TITLE}. Check dependencies first with br dep tree {BEAD_ID}."
- **review**: "Review and verify bead {BEAD_ID}: {TITLE}. Run tests if applicable."
- **custom**: User provides template file

Variables available: {BEAD_ID}, {TITLE}, {DESCRIPTION}, {PRIORITY}, {TAGS}, {BLOCKED_BY}

## Agent Capability Matrix (for quality strategy)
```go
var AgentCapabilities = map[string]map[string]float64{
    "claude": {
        "refactoring": 0.95, "architecture": 0.95, "analysis": 0.90,
        "documentation": 0.85, "bug_fix": 0.85, "feature": 0.85,
        "testing": 0.75,
    },
    "codex": {
        "feature": 0.90, "bug_fix": 0.90, "testing": 0.85,
        "refactoring": 0.75, "documentation": 0.70,
    },
    "gemini": {
        "documentation": 0.90, "analysis": 0.85, "review": 0.90,
        "feature": 0.80, "testing": 0.80,
    },
}
```

## Algorithm
1. Get idle agents (context < 80%, no active assignment)
2. Get actionable beads from BV (not blocked)
3. Apply strategy scoring:
   - balanced: score = 1.0 / (current_assignments + 1)
   - speed: score = 1.0 - (context_usage / 100)
   - quality: score = capability_matrix[agent_type][bead_type]
   - dependency: score = unblocks_count * 0.5 + pagerank * 0.5
   - round-robin: deterministic index assignment
4. Generate (bead, agent) pairs sorted by score
5. If --auto: Send prompts, update assignment store
6. Emit JSON output

## Output Format
```json
{
  "strategy": "balanced",
  "assigned": [
    {
      "bead_id": "bd-abc1",
      "bead_title": "Implement feature X",
      "pane": 2,
      "agent_type": "claude",
      "agent_name": "GreenCastle",
      "score": 0.85,
      "prompt_sent": true
    }
  ],
  "skipped": [
    {
      "bead_id": "bd-def2",
      "reason": "blocked_by bd-abc1"
    }
  ],
  "summary": {
    "total_beads": 10,
    "assigned": 4,
    "skipped": 6,
    "idle_agents": 4
  }
}
```

## Error Handling
- No idle agents: Return with "no_idle_agents" in output, suggest wait or spawn more
- No actionable beads: Return with "no_ready_beads" in output
- BV unavailable: Fall back to br ready list, warn user
- Send failure: Mark as failed in assignment store, include in output

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All 5 strategies work correctly
- [ ] --auto sends prompts via ntm send
- [ ] --limit caps assignments
- [ ] --beads allows explicit bead list
- [ ] Agent type filters work (--cc-only and --agent=claude)
- [ ] Prompt templates expand correctly
- [ ] Assignment store updated
- [ ] JSON output is complete and stable
- [ ] Clear error messages for edge cases
- [ ] Logging shows scoring decisions (with --verbose)
- [ ] Common flags implemented (--json, --verbose, --quiet, --timeout)

## Tests Required
- Unit test: Each strategy scoring algorithm
- Unit test: Agent filtering logic (both styles)
- Unit test: Prompt template expansion
- Unit test: Output JSON format
- Unit test: Common flags (--json, --verbose, --quiet)
- E2E test: Full assign workflow with real agents
- E2E test: Error cases (no agents, no beads)
notes: Canonical assignment entry. Strategy list must stay in sync with code: balanced|speed|quality|dependency (+ round-robin if added). Supersedes send --distribute, swarm, and YAML swarm config.

title: EPIC: Context Continuity System - Compound Dont Compact
description:
## Philosophy: "Compound, Don't Compact"

This EPIC implements a context management system inspired by [Continuous-Claude-v3](https://github.com/parcadei/Continuous-Claude-v3). The core insight: **each compaction is lossy compression**‚Äîafter several compactions, agents work with degraded context. Instead of fighting compaction, we:

1. **Extract state before compaction** - Pre-compact hook captures context
2. **Clear and reload fresh** - Start new session with full signal from handoff
3. **Use token-efficient YAML** - ~400 tokens vs ~2000 markdown
4. **Show status in real-time** - Dashboard displays goal/now from latest handoff

## Why This Approach Is Superior

**Current approach problems:**
- Agents suddenly hit context limits, lose mid-work context
- Each compaction degrades signal quality
- No structured way to preserve decisions, learnings, next steps
- Users never know "where did we leave off?"

**CC-v3 approach benefits:**
- Handoffs preserve 100% of key information
- Fresh context = full signal, no degradation
- Structured format ensures nothing is lost
- Status line shows current goal/now at a glance
- Works with multiple concurrent sessions

## YAML Handoff Format (~400 tokens)

```yaml
---
session: {session-name}
date: YYYY-MM-DD
status: complete|partial|blocked
outcome: SUCCEEDED|PARTIAL_PLUS|PARTIAL_MINUS|FAILED
---

goal: {What this session accomplished - shown in statusline}
now: {What next session should do first - shown in statusline}
test: {Command to verify this work}

done_this_session:
  - task: {First completed task}
    files: [{file1.go}, {file2.go}]

blockers: [{any blocking issues}]
questions: [{unresolved questions for next session}]

decisions:
  - {decision_name}: {rationale}

findings:
  - {key_finding}: {details}

worked: [{approaches that worked}]
failed: [{approaches that failed and why}]

next:
  - {First next step}
  - {Second next step}

files:
  created: [{new files}]
  modified: [{changed files}]
```

## Key Fields

- **goal + now**: REQUIRED, shown in status line/dashboard
- **done_this_session**: What was accomplished with file references
- **decisions**: Important choices and rationale for "future self"
- **findings**: Key learnings discovered
- **worked/failed**: What to repeat vs avoid
- **next**: Action items for resuming

## Directory Structure

```
.ntm/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ handoffs/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ {session-name}/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2026-01-19_14-30_auth-complete.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ auto-handoff-{timestamp}.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ general/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ledgers/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CONTINUITY_{session}.md
```

## Lifecycle Hooks Integration

1. **Pre-Compact Hook**: When agent approaches context limit (70%+) or manual /clear
   - Parse recent output/transcript
   - Generate YAML handoff automatically
   - Save to handoffs directory

2. **Session-Start Hook**: When spawning new session
   - Find most recent handoff for this session
   - Extract goal/now fields
   - Inject into initial agent context

3. **Session-End Hook**: On kill/exit
   - Prompt for handoff creation if work in progress

## CLI Commands

- `ntm handoff [session]` - Create manual handoff for session
- `ntm resume [session|path]` - Resume from handoff
- `ntm context status` - Show context and handoff status

## Integration Points

- **Dashboard**: Show goal/now/context% in top status bar
- **BV**: Include active bead IDs in handoffs
- **Agent Mail**: Thread IDs for related conversations
- **CM**: Query relevant memories on resume

## Success Criteria

- Agents can be cleared and resumed with zero context loss
- Status line shows current goal/now from latest handoff
- Automatic handoffs triggered before context exhaustion
- YAML format uses ~400 tokens (95% reduction from raw)
- Works with multiple concurrent sessions

## Relationship to Existing Beads

This EPIC subsumes and improves upon:
- bd-ljrn (Proactive Context Window Management)
- bd-2i44 (Structured Handoff Protocol)
- bd-3dxk (End-of-Session Summarization)

Complements:
- bd-38kx (Smart Session Recovery) - provides handoff data
- bd-2n9s (Cross-Session Memory via CM) - procedural memory
notes:

## Problem Being Solved

Agents sometimes hang or get stuck. Currently requires manual detection and restart.

## Command Design

```bash
ntm health SESSION --auto-restart-stuck [--threshold DURATION] [--dry-run]
```

### Behavior
1. Monitors all agent panes for output activity
2. Detects panes with no output for threshold duration
3. Automatically restarts stuck panes

### Detection Logic
- Track last output timestamp per pane
- Pane is 'stuck' if no output for threshold (default: 5m)
- Ignore panes that are intentionally idle (awaiting user input)

- --threshold: Duration before considering stuck (default: 5m)
- --dry-run: Report stuck panes without restarting

title: EPIC: Proactive Context Window Management with Predictive Compaction
description:
**IDEA #4 - ELIMINATES SURPRISES (88% confidence)**

## What It Does
Instead of reacting when an agent hits context exhaustion (80-95% full), NTM predicts when exhaustion will occur and proactively triggers compaction before the agent's work is interrupted.

## Why This Matters
- Currently: Agents suddenly hit context limits, lose mid-work context
- After: NTM handles it proactively; work continues smoothly
- Users never see 'Conversation compacted - lost context' mid-task
- Transforms context limits from a constant worry to a non-issue

## How It Works
Continuous monitoring:
1. Track token velocity: Characters per minute ‚Üí estimated tokens per minute
2. Model context growth: Based on recent velocity, project time-to-exhaustion
3. Predict exhaustion: 'At current rate, agent will exhaust context in 12 minutes'
4. Proactive action: At 70% + high velocity, suggest compaction; at 75% with continued high velocity, trigger automatically

## Prediction Model
tokens_remaining = context_limit - current_tokens
time_to_exhaustion = tokens_remaining / token_velocity_per_minute

if time_to_exhaustion < threshold_minutes:
    trigger_proactive_compaction()

## Flywheel Alignment
- Enhances existing context rotation feature
- Pairs perfectly with Smart Session Recovery
- Compaction + recovery = seamless context management

## Technical Implementation
- New file: internal/context/predictor.go
- ContextPredictor struct with velocity sampling
- Dashboard integration for context status display
- Config under [context_rotation.prediction] section

## Dependencies
Depends on: Smart Session Recovery (for post-compaction context restoration)

description:
Integrate process_triage (pt) for detecting stuck, abandoned, or zombie agents.

## Project Location
/dp/process_triage (Rust CLI)

## Problem Being Solved

Agents can become unresponsive:
- Waiting for API response that never comes
- Stuck in infinite loop
- Process crashed but pane still open
- Wedged on user input prompt

## What process_triage Does

Bayesian classification of process state:

### Classification Categories
- **useful**: Actively working, CPU/IO activity
- **waiting**: Legitimately waiting (network, user input)
- **idle**: Finished work, waiting for new task
- **stuck**: No progress for extended period
- **zombie**: Process exists but not running

### Signals Used
- CPU usage over time
- IO activity (read/write)
- Network activity (from rano integration)
- Output activity (pane output changes)
- Process state (running, sleeping, stopped)

EPIC for Tier 1 integrations focused on immediate safety and reliability improvements.

## Why Tier 1 is Highest Priority

These three integrations address the most critical pain points in multi-agent workflows:

title: Feature: Prompt Engine - Mode-specific preambles and injection
description:
# Feature: Prompt Engine - Mode-specific preambles with schema enforcement

Each mode agent receives a structured prompt with three mandatory components:
1. Base instructions (tone, structure, constraints)
2. Mode preamble (the reasoning 'lens')
3. **Output schema contract** (mandatory structured output)

## Prompt Structure

### 1. Base Instructions
```
You are participating in a reasoning ensemble analyzing: {problem_statement}

Context Pack:
{context_pack}

Your role: Apply your assigned reasoning mode rigorously.

Constraints:
- Stay within your reasoning mode's strengths
- Be explicit about confidence levels (numeric or high|medium|low)
- Reference specific evidence (file:line)
- Flag your mode's known failure modes
- DO NOT exceed {token_cap} tokens
```

### 2. Mode Preamble (The Lens)
```
## Your Reasoning Mode: {mode_name}

{mode_description}

What you excel at:
{best_for}

How you differ from other modes:
{differentiator}

Common failure modes to avoid:
{failure_modes}
```

### 3. Output Schema Contract (MANDATORY)
```
## REQUIRED OUTPUT FORMAT

You MUST structure your response as valid YAML with these exact fields:

mode_id: {mode_id}           # optional; system will inject if missing
thesis: |
  Your one-sentence main insight
confidence: 0.0-1.0           # numeric or high|medium|low

top_findings:
  - finding: Description of finding
    impact: critical|high|medium|low
    confidence: 0.0-1.0        # numeric or high|medium|low
    evidence_pointer: path/to/file.go:142
    reasoning: How you reached this

risks:
  - risk: Description of risk
    impact: critical|high|medium|low
    likelihood: 0.0-1.0        # numeric or high|medium|low
    mitigation: Suggested mitigation
    affected_areas: [string]

recommendations:
  - recommendation: What to do
    priority: critical|high|medium|low
    effort: low|medium|high
    rationale: Why this helps
    related_findings: [int]    # indices into top_findings (0-based)

questions_for_user:
  - question: What needs clarification?
    context: Why this matters
    blocking: false
    suggested_answers: [string]

failure_modes_to_watch:
  - mode: Potential failure of my analysis
    description: What could go wrong
    indicators: [string]
    prevention: How to guard against it

NON-COMPLIANT OUTPUTS WILL BE REJECTED.
```

## Schema Validation

PromptInjector validates all outputs:
- Parse YAML structure
- Check required fields present
- Validate enum values (impact/priority/etc.)
- Accept numeric or qualitative likelihood/confidence values
- Ensure evidence_pointers are valid file references
- Validate list fields when present (affected_areas, related_findings, suggested_answers, indicators)
- Inject mode_id if missing (warn)
- Flag non-compliant outputs for human review

## Testing Coverage
- Unit: bd-xkrnc (preamble rendering + schema contract fields)
- Unit: bd-qeoex (schema validator exhaustive cases)
- E2E: bd-18ds7 (full pipeline includes preamble injection + schema validation)

## Files
- internal/ensemble/preamble.go - Template structure
- internal/ensemble/preambles/ - Mode-specific content
- internal/ensemble/schema_validator.go - Output validation
- internal/swarm/prompt_injector.go - Injection logic

## Logging Requirements
- Log prompt assembly start with mode_id, mode_code, pane, agent_type, token_cap
- Log schema contract version/hash and missing required fields
- Log validation summary (valid/invalid counts, first error per mode)
- Log injection outcome per pane (success/failure + error)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Prompt assembly deterministic for same inputs (stable ordering)
- [ ] Output schema contract matches OutputSchema types (no drift)
- [ ] Schema validation rejects non-compliant outputs and reports errors
- [ ] Logging captures per-mode injection and validation status

## Goal
Reduce user confusion by providing **one** canonical assignment flow and **one** convenience entry point.

## Decision
- **Keep**: `ntm assign` as the only assignment command.
- **Keep**: `ntm spawn --assign` as the only convenience entry (spawn + assign).
- **Expose**: `--strategy=balanced|speed|quality|dependency|round-robin` on `ntm assign`.
- **Drop/Merge**: `ntm swarm`, `ntm send --distribute`, YAML swarm config, and from‚Äëfile assignments.

## Why
Multiple entry points doing the same thing (assign work to agents) multiplies docs, tests, and code paths and will confuse users. The project benefits from a single, well‚Äëdesigned path.

## Scope
- Keep existing strategies (`balanced`, `speed`, `quality`, `dependency`) intact and documented.
- Add `round‚Äërobin` as an **optional** additional strategy (no renaming of existing ones).
- Implement assignment tracking + reporting so `balanced` can be truly load‚Äëaware.
- Implement `ntm spawn --assign` as a thin wrapper over `ntm assign`.
- Update docs/help to emphasize canonical flow.

## Non‚ÄëGoals
- No new orchestration commands outside `assign` + `spawn --assign`.
- No YAML swarm config or additional CLI entry points.

## Success Criteria
- `ntm assign` is the only path for distributing work.
- `ntm spawn --assign` works end‚Äëto‚Äëend with clear output.

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
```

title: Implement global animation tick source for synchronized animations
description:
## Problem
Multiple animated components with independent tick counters can cause visual noise.

## Code Review Findings (2026-01-19)

### Good News: Dashboard Already Uses Global Tick

**Central tick source exists:**
- `dashboard.go:42-43` - `DashboardTickMsg` message type  
- `dashboard.go:224` - `animTick int` in Model
- `dashboard.go:745` - Single 100ms tick: `tea.Tick(time.Millisecond*100, ...)`
- `dashboard.go:1599-1600` - Handler increments `m.animTick++`

**All animations use the global tick:**
```go
// dashboard.go:2618 - progress bar uses m.animTick
barContent := styles.ShimmerProgressBar(percent/100.0, barWidth, "‚ñà", "‚ñë", m.animTick, colors...)

// dashboard.go:2142 - ticker panel receives animTick
m.tickerPanel.SetAnimTick(m.animTick)

// layout.go:238 - layout functions receive tick parameter
bar := styles.ShimmerProgressBar(percent/100, width-4, "‚ñà", "‚ñë", tick, ...)

// dashboard.go:2718 - spinner uses animTick
statusIcon = WorkingSpinnerFrame(m.animTick)
```

### Orphaned Code in components/progress.go

The `components/progress.go` file has UNUSED independent tick mechanisms:
- Line 132: 50ms tick for ProgressBar
- Line 166: 50ms tick for IndeterminateBar
- Line 224: 50ms tick for IndeterminateBar.Init()

**These are NOT used by the dashboard.** The dashboard uses `styles.ShimmerProgressBar()` directly, which takes a tick parameter.

## Updated Fix Approach

### 1. Clean Up Orphaned Code
```go
// components/progress.go - Consider deprecating or removing the independent tick
// since dashboard uses styles.ShimmerProgressBar() with global tick instead

// Option A: Deprecate
// Deprecated: Use styles.ShimmerProgressBar() with global tick instead
func (p ProgressBar) Init() tea.Cmd { ... }

// Option B: Remove entirely if unused
```

### 2. Document Global Tick Pattern
Add to CONTRIBUTING.md:
```markdown
## Animation Synchronization

All animations in the dashboard use a global tick source:

1. The dashboard maintains `animTick int` incremented every 100ms
2. Pass `animTick` to all animated rendering functions
3. Never create independent tea.Tick sources in subcomponents
4. Use `styles.Shimmer()`, `styles.ShimmerProgressBar()` with tick parameter

Example:
\`\`\`go
// Good: use global tick
bar := styles.ShimmerProgressBar(percent, width, "‚ñà", "‚ñë", m.animTick, colors...)

// Bad: independent tick in subcomponent
func (m MyModel) Init() tea.Cmd {
    return tea.Tick(time.Millisecond*50, ...) // Creates separate timer
}
\`\`\`
```

### 3. Add Test for Tick Synchronization
```go
func TestAllAnimationsUseGlobalTick(t *testing.T) {
    // Verify that styles.Shimmer produces deterministic output for given tick
    result1 := styles.Shimmer("test", 42, "#FF0000", "#00FF00")
    result2 := styles.Shimmer("test", 42, "#FF0000", "#00FF00")
    
    if result1 != result2 {
        t.Error("Shimmer should be deterministic for same tick value")
    }
    
    // Different ticks produce different results
    result3 := styles.Shimmer("test", 43, "#FF0000", "#00FF00")
    if result1 == result3 {
        t.Error("Different ticks should produce different shimmer effects")
    }
}
```

## Verification Checklist
- [x] Dashboard uses single DashboardTickMsg source (100ms)
- [x] animTick passed to all animated components  
- [ ] Remove/deprecate orphaned tick code in components/progress.go
- [ ] Document global tick pattern in CONTRIBUTING.md
- [ ] Verify NTM_REDUCE_MOTION=1 disables all animation

## Priority Adjustment
Changed to P3 - cleanup/documentation task. The core implementation is already correct.
close_reason: Verification complete: Dashboard uses global animTick (100ms), all animated functions (Shimmer, ShimmerProgressBar, WorkingSpinnerFrame) receive tick parameter. Added deterministic test for same tick value. components/progress.go is a valid standalone component, not orphaned - can be used outside dashboard context.

description:
## LimitDetector: Core Interface for Usage Limit Detection

### Purpose
Implement the LimitDetector that monitors agent panes for usage limit patterns. This component detects when agents hit rate limits by watching their terminal output.

### IMPORTANT: Leverage Existing Code
NTM already has `internal/ratelimit/tracker.go` for tracking rate limits and `internal/agent/parser.go` for parsing agent output. LimitDetector should:
1. Use RateLimitTracker for recording and learning from limit events
2. Use agent parser patterns where applicable
3. Extend rather than duplicate existing functionality

### Implementation Details

**File:** `internal/swarm/limit_detector.go`

**Interface:**
```go
// LimitDetector monitors panes for usage limit patterns.
type LimitDetector struct {
    // Config holds limit patterns per agent type
    Config *config.SwarmConfig
    
    // Tracker records limit events (reuse existing ratelimit.RateLimitTracker)
    Tracker *ratelimit.RateLimitTracker
    
    // tmuxClient for capturing pane output
    tmuxClient *tmux.Client
    
    // eventChan emits detected limit events
    eventChan chan LimitEvent
    
    // cancel stops all monitoring goroutines
    cancel context.CancelFunc
}

// LimitEvent represents a detected usage limit.
type LimitEvent struct {
    SessionPane string    `json:"session_pane"`
    AgentType   string    `json:"agent_type"`
    Pattern     string    `json:"pattern"`        // Which pattern matched
    RawOutput   string    `json:"raw_output"`     // Last N lines
    DetectedAt  time.Time `json:"detected_at"`
}
```

**Default Patterns (from EPIC):**
```go
var DefaultLimitPatterns = map[string][]string{
    "cc": {
        "You've hit your limit",
        "You have hit your limit",
        "usage limit",
        "Rate limit exceeded",
        "Please wait",
    },
    "cod": {
        "You've hit your usage limit",
        "You have reached your usage limit",
        "Rate limit exceeded",
    },
    "gmi": {
        "quota exceeded",
        "rate limit",
    },
}
```

**Core Methods:**

title: Feature: Robot Bulk Assign Command (--robot-bulk-assign)
description:
## Overview

Add `ntm --robot-bulk-assign <session>` command that intelligently allocates
beads to agent panes in a single operation based on bv triage output.

## Background

Current bead allocation workflow is tedious:
1. Run `bv --robot-triage` to get prioritized beads
2. Parse the recommendations manually
3. For each pane, decide which bead to assign
4. Construct and send individual prompts to each pane
5. Track the allocation mentally

This should be one command that does it all.

## Proposed Interface

```bash
# Auto-fetch bv triage and allocate
ntm --robot-bulk-assign myproject --from-bv

# Provide explicit allocation
ntm --robot-bulk-assign myproject --allocation='{"2":"bd-92e1","3":"bd-55pm"}'

# Dry run - show plan without executing
ntm --robot-bulk-assign myproject --from-bv --dry-run
```

## Proposed Output

```json
{
  "session": "myproject",
  "strategy": "impact",
  "timestamp": "2026-01-19T23:16:00Z",
  "assignments": [
    {
      "pane": 2,
      "bead": "bd-92e1",
      "bead_title": "Add assignment tracking",
      "reason": "highest_unblocks (9 items)",
      "agent_type": "claude",
      "status": "assigned",
      "prompt_sent": true
    },
    {
      "pane": 3,
      "bead": "bd-55pm",
      "bead_title": "Direct bv integration",
      "reason": "high_unblocks (7 items)",
      "agent_type": "claude",
      "status": "assigned",
      "prompt_sent": true
    },
    // ... more assignments
  ],
  "summary": {
    "total_panes": 15,
    "assigned": 15,
    "skipped": 0,
    "failed": 0
  },
  "unassigned_beads": ["bd-xyz"],  // More beads than panes
  "unassigned_panes": []           // More panes than beads (if any)
}
```

## Allocation Strategies

When using `--from-bv`, use these strategies:

| Strategy | Logic |
|----------|-------|
| impact (default) | Highest `unblocks_count` first |
| ready | Only `ready` status beads, by priority |
| stale | `in_progress` with no recent activity first |
| balanced | Mix of blockers, ready, and stale |

## Flags

- `--from-bv`: Fetch bv triage and auto-allocate
- `--strategy=<S>`: Allocation strategy (impact, ready, stale, balanced)
- `--allocation=<JSON>`: Explicit pane-to-bead mapping
- `--dry-run`: Show plan without executing
- `--skip-panes=<N,N>`: Skip specific panes (e.g., leave them on current work)
- `--prompt-template=<FILE>`: Custom prompt template for assignments

## Integration with BV

This command should:
1. Call `bv --robot-triage` internally (or accept piped input)
2. Parse recommendations
3. Apply allocation strategy
4. Consider existing ntm assign infrastructure (bd-9tbv)

## Prompt Template

Default template for bead assignment:
```
Read AGENTS.md, register with Agent Mail. Work on: {bead_id} - {bead_title}.
Use br show {bead_id} for details. Mark in_progress when starting. Use ultrathink.
```

## Why This Matters

Reduces "spawn and allocate" from a 15-minute manual process to a 5-second command.
Intelligent allocation based on graph topology ensures high-impact work gets done first.

title: AccountRotator: Detect current account state
description:
## Purpose
Detect when an agent hits usage limits by monitoring pane output and trigger account rotation through caam integration.

## Implementation Details

```go
// AccountRotator manages caam-based account switching on limit detection
type AccountRotator struct {
    caamPath       string           // Path to caam binary
    limitDetector  *LimitDetector
    rotationState  map[string]*RotationState // pane -> state
    mu             sync.RWMutex
    logger         *slog.Logger
}

type RotationState struct {
    CurrentAccount   string
    PreviousAccounts []string
    RotationCount    int
    LastRotation     time.Time
}

// OnLimitHit is called when LimitDetector detects a rate limit
func (ar *AccountRotator) OnLimitHit(event LimitHitEvent) error {
    ar.mu.Lock()
    defer ar.mu.Unlock()
    
    state := ar.getOrCreateState(event.SessionPane)
    
    ar.logger.Info("limit hit detected, initiating account rotation",
        "pane", event.SessionPane,
        "agent_type", event.AgentType,
        "pattern", event.Pattern,
        "current_account", state.CurrentAccount,
        "rotation_count", state.RotationCount)
    
    // Get next available account from caam
    newAccount, err := ar.getNextAccount(event.AgentType)
    if err != nil {
        ar.logger.Error("failed to get next account",
            "agent_type", event.AgentType,
            "error", err)
        return fmt.Errorf("get next account: %w", err)
    }
    
    // Track rotation
    state.PreviousAccounts = append(state.PreviousAccounts, state.CurrentAccount)
    state.CurrentAccount = newAccount
    state.RotationCount++
    state.LastRotation = time.Now()
    
    ar.logger.Info("account rotation prepared",
        "pane", event.SessionPane,
        "old_account", state.PreviousAccounts[len(state.PreviousAccounts)-1],
        "new_account", newAccount,
        "total_rotations", state.RotationCount)
    
    return nil
}
```

## Integration with caam
- Invoke `caam switch <provider> --next` to get next available account
- Parse caam JSON output for account details
- Handle case when no accounts are available

## Logging Requirements
- Log limit detection trigger with full event context
- Log current account before rotation
- Log new account after rotation
- Track total rotation count per pane
- Error logging with caam command details

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Detect limit hits from LimitDetector events
- [ ] Invoke caam CLI for account switching
- [ ] Track rotation history per pane
- [ ] Handle caam errors gracefully
- [ ] Prevent rapid rotation loops (cooldown)
- [ ] Structured logging at each rotation step

```go
// layout.go

func TierForWidthWithHysteresis(width int, currentTier Tier) Tier {
    newTier := TierForWidth(width)
    if newTier == currentTier {
        return currentTier
    }
    // Only switch if we've moved 5+ cols past threshold
    // ...implementation details...
}
```

### 2. Add Debounce to Resize Handler
Delay applying resize by 100ms to batch rapid events.

```go
    // Start at narrow, resize to just past threshold
    // At 120 exactly, should still be narrow (hysteresis)
    // At 125, should switch to split

}
```

title: Implement confidence scoring and recommendations
description:
Implement confidence scoring and recommendations.

## Confidence Levels

### high
- Clear response to probe
- Content visibly changed
- Latency measurable (<5s)

### medium
- Minor change detected
- May be coincidental (background activity)
- Response timing unclear

### low
- No response to probe
- But process shows CPU/IO activity
- May be deeply thinking (ultrathink)

## Recommendation Logic

| Confidence | Response | Recommendation |
|------------|----------|----------------|
| high | yes | healthy |
| high | no | definitely_stuck |
| medium | yes | healthy |
| medium | no | likely_stuck |
| low | yes | healthy |
| low | no | possibly_stuck |

## Implementation

```go
type ProbeResult struct {
    Responsive      bool
    LatencyMs       int64
    OutputDelta     int
    Confidence      string  // high, medium, low
    Recommendation  string  // healthy, likely_stuck, etc.
    Reasoning       string  // Human-readable explanation
}

func scoreConfidence(result *ProbeResult, processActivity bool) {
    if result.Responsive && result.LatencyMs < 1000 {
        result.Confidence = "high"
    } else if result.Responsive {
        result.Confidence = "medium"
    } else if processActivity {
        result.Confidence = "low"
    } else {
        result.Confidence = "high"  // Definitely not responsive
    }
}
```

Added 4 comprehensive tests: TestConfidenceRecommendationMatrix, TestConfidenceLevelValues, TestRecommendationValues, TestConfidenceExplanation. All tests pass.

## What

End-to-end tests verifying status enrichments work with actual tmux sessions.

## Test Scenarios

### Scenario 1: Healthy Agent
1. Spawn session with single Claude agent

3. Call --robot-status
4. Verify:
   - child_pid is valid PID
   - process_state is R or S
   - rate_limit_detected is false
   - memory_mb is reasonable (< 1000)
   - last_output_ts is recent

   - rate_limit_detected is true

   - seconds_since_output > 300
   - last_output_ts is stale

1. Spawn session with agent
2. Kill agent process directly
3. Call --robot-status

   - child_pid is null or process_state is Z

title: Implement rate limit backoff for agents
description:
Detect rate limit errors and notify users (do not auto-retry).

## What This Task Does

Detect when agents hit rate limits and notify users. This is simpler
and safer than auto-retry, which can cause more problems than it solves.

## Why Detection Only (No Auto-Retry)

Auto-retry is complex and error-prone:
- Can't reliably capture the 'last command' to replay
- Agent state may be corrupted after rate limit
- Infinite retry loops are possible
- Users should decide if/when to retry

Instead: Detect, notify, let user handle it.

## Detection

Rate limit patterns in agent output:
- 'rate limit exceeded'
- 'too many requests'
- '429'
- 'quota exceeded'
- 'try again in X seconds'

## Response

When rate limit detected:
1. Mark agent as 'rate_limited' in health status
2. Fire notification event (desktop, webhook, shell)
3. Include wait time if parseable from error
4. Show in 'ntm health' output with clear indicator

Example notification:
'Agent cc_1 hit rate limit. Suggested wait: 60s'

## Integration

- Uses health check infrastructure (ntm-239) for detection
- Uses notification system (ntm-gcv) for alerts
- Shows in 'ntm status' with rate_limited indicator

title: Feature: Policy Engine
description:
# Policy Engine (internal/policy/)

## Why This Is Critical
The .ntm/policy.yaml file is referenced by MULTIPLE features but there's no dedicated engine to parse and enforce it:
- Destructive Command Protection (blocked/allowed patterns)
- BD Daemon Mode (auto-push policy gate)
- File Reservation Lifecycle (force-release approval)
- SLB Safety Gates (approval_required operations)

Without a unified Policy Engine, each feature reimplements policy checking, leading to inconsistencies and bugs.

## Policy File Structure
```yaml
# .ntm/policy.yaml
version: 1

# Commands that are always blocked
blocked:
  - pattern: "git reset --hard"
    reason: "Hard reset loses commits"
  - pattern: "git checkout --"
    reason: "Discards uncommitted changes"

# Commands that require approval
approval_required:
  - pattern: "git push --force"
    reason: "Force push rewrites history"
    slb: true  # Requires SLB two-person rule
  - pattern: "force_release"
    reason: "Releases another agent's reservation"
    slb: false  # Just needs any approval

# Commands that bypass checks
allowed:
  - pattern: "git checkout -b"
    reason: "Create branch is safe"

# Automation settings
automation:
  auto_push: false
  auto_commit: true
  force_release: approval
```

## Implementation (internal/policy/engine.go)

### Policy Engine Interface
```go
type PolicyEngine struct {
    policyPath string
    policy     *Policy
    mu         sync.RWMutex
}

type Policy struct {
    Version          int              `yaml:"version"`
    Blocked          []PatternRule    `yaml:"blocked"`
    ApprovalRequired []PatternRule    `yaml:"approval_required"`
    Allowed          []PatternRule    `yaml:"allowed"`
    Automation       AutomationConfig `yaml:"automation"`
}

type PatternRule struct {
    Pattern    string   `yaml:"pattern"`
    Reason     string   `yaml:"reason"`
    SLB        bool     `yaml:"slb,omitempty"`
    Exceptions []string `yaml:"exceptions,omitempty"`
}
```

### Key Methods
```go
func (e *PolicyEngine) Load(path string) error
func (e *PolicyEngine) Reload() error  // Watch for file changes
func (e *PolicyEngine) IsBlocked(command string) (bool, string)
func (e *PolicyEngine) NeedsApproval(action string) (bool, *PatternRule)
func (e *PolicyEngine) IsAllowed(command string) bool
func (e *PolicyEngine) AutomationEnabled(feature string) bool
```

### File Watching
Policy file is watched for changes and automatically reloaded:
```go
func (e *PolicyEngine) StartWatcher(ctx context.Context) {
    watcher, _ := fsnotify.NewWatcher()
    watcher.Add(e.policyPath)
    // Reload on change
}
```

### Default Policy
If .ntm/policy.yaml doesn't exist, use sensible defaults (block dangerous patterns, require approval for force operations).

## Integration Points
- Destructive Command Protection: Uses IsBlocked(), IsAllowed()
- BD Daemon: Uses AutomationEnabled("auto_push")
- File Reservation: Uses NeedsApproval("force_release")
- SLB: Uses NeedsApproval() with SLB flag check

## New Commands
```bash
ntm policy show           # Display current policy
ntm policy validate       # Check policy file syntax
ntm policy reset          # Reset to defaults
ntm policy edit           # Open in editor
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Policy file parsed correctly
- [ ] Default policy used when file missing
- [ ] File watching with auto-reload
- [ ] IsBlocked/NeedsApproval/IsAllowed work
- [ ] AutomationEnabled checks work
- [ ] Validation command catches syntax errors
close_reason: Policy engine complete with: Policy struct (Version, Blocked, ApprovalRequired, Allowed, Automation), AutomationConfig (auto_commit, auto_push, force_release), SLB support, CLI commands (show, validate, reset, edit, automation), comprehensive tests. File watching deferred to future enhancement.

title: Integrate routing with Agent Mail file reservations
description:
When routing work, consider Agent Mail file reservations as a signal for task affinity.

RATIONALE:
If an agent has reserved files via Agent Mail, they're likely the best agent to handle work related to those files. This creates natural task affinity.

INTEGRATION POINTS:

1. RESERVATION QUERY:
   - Query Agent Mail for active reservations in project
   - Cache results (refresh every 30s or on routing request)
   - Map: pane_id -> []reserved_paths

2. AFFINITY SCORING:
   - Extract file paths from prompt (patterns like "src/auth.go", "internal/")
   - Check if any agent has matching reservations
   - Add affinity bonus (configurable, default 30) to matching agent

3. CONFLICT PREVENTION:
   - If prompt mentions file reserved by another agent:
     - Warning in response: "File reserved by {agent}"
     - Option: --respect-reservations to skip reserved files

CONFIGURATION:
```toml
[routing.agent_mail]
enabled = true
reservation_bonus = 30
respect_reservations = false  # warn only vs enforce
cache_ttl = "30s"
```

DEPENDENCY:
- Requires Agent Mail MCP to be available
- Graceful degradation if unavailable

LOCATION: internal/robot/routing.go (extend existing)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- File reservations queried from Agent Mail
- Matching reservations boost agent score
- Warning when sending to non-reserving agent
- Works gracefully without Agent Mail

# Implement ntm mail send Command

## Purpose

Allow users to send messages between agents in a session, or broadcast coordination messages.

## Command Syntax

```bash
# Send to specific agent panes
ntm mail send myproject --to cc_1 "Please review the API changes"

# Send to all agents of a type
ntm mail send myproject --cc "Stop current work and focus on tests"

# Send to all agents
ntm mail send myproject --all "Checkpoint: sync and report status"

# With options
ntm mail send myproject --to cc_1 --subject "API Review" --urgent --ack-required "Review needed ASAP"

# From file
ntm mail send myproject --to cc_1 --file ./message.md
```

## Flag Mapping

| Flag | Agent Mail Parameter |
|------|---------------------|
| --to | to[] (specific agent) |
| --cc | cc[] |
| --subject | subject |
| --urgent | importance="urgent" |
| --important | importance="high" |
| --ack-required | ack_required=true |
| --thread | thread_id |
| --file | body_md from file |

## Agent Resolution

The --to flag accepts:
1. **Pane identifiers**: cc_1, cod_2 ‚Üí resolve to agent names
2. **Agent names**: GreenCastle ‚Üí use directly
3. **Agent type filters**: --cc, --cod, --gmi ‚Üí expand to all agents of type

Resolution requires querying both tmux (for pane names) and Agent Mail (for registered agents).

## Message Composition

If no message body provided:
1. Open $EDITOR with template
2. Parse subject from first line (# heading)
3. Validate non-empty before sending

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Can send to specific agents by pane ID or name
- [ ] Can broadcast to agent type groups
- [ ] Subject auto-derived or manually specified
- [ ] Importance and ack_required flags work
- [ ] Thread ID support for conversations
- [ ] File input for long messages
- [ ] Editor mode for composition

description:
# Implement ntm mail ack and read Commands

## Purpose

Allow marking messages as read or acknowledged, which signals to senders that the message was received and processed.

## Command Syntax

```bash
# Mark message as read
ntm mail read myproject 42

# Mark message as acknowledged
ntm mail ack myproject 42

# Acknowledge all urgent messages
ntm mail ack myproject --urgent

# Acknowledge all from specific agent
ntm mail ack myproject --from cc_1
```

## Semantics

- **Read**: Message was seen but not necessarily acted upon
- **Acknowledged**: Message was seen AND the recipient has taken action or committed to action

Agent Mail tracks both timestamps separately:
- read_ts: When mark_message_read was called
- ack_ts: When acknowledge_message was called

## Batch Operations

```bash
# Mark multiple messages
ntm mail read myproject 42 43 44

# Mark all unread as read
ntm mail read myproject --all

# Acknowledge all pending
ntm mail ack myproject --all
```

## Output

```
‚úì Message #42 marked as read
‚úì Message #42 acknowledged (ack_ts: 2025-12-10T15:35:00Z)
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Single message read/ack by ID
- [ ] Batch operations by ID list
- [ ] Filter-based batch: --urgent, --from, --all
- [ ] Proper error handling for already-read/acked
- [ ] JSON output mode for scripts
