title: Feature: E2E agent lifecycle tests (spawn/send/kill)
description:
## Overview
E2E tests for the complete agent lifecycle: spawn, send, monitor, and kill.

## Test Scenarios

### Spawn -> Work -> Kill Lifecycle
```bash
# Test: Full lifecycle with single agent
test_single_agent_lifecycle() {
    # Spawn
    ntm spawn myproject --cc=1
    assert_pane_exists myproject cc_1

    # Send work
    ntm send myproject --msg "echo hello" --agent cc_1
    sleep 5

    # Monitor progress
    status=$(ntm status myproject --format json | jq -r '.agents[0].state')
    log_e2e "lifecycle" "status_check" "$status"

    # Kill
    ntm kill myproject cc_1
    assert_pane_not_exists myproject cc_1
}

# Test: Multi-agent parallel lifecycle
test_multi_agent_lifecycle() {
    ntm spawn myproject --cc=2 --cod=1

    # Send to all
    ntm send myproject --msg "Review codebase" --broadcast

    # Monitor all
    ntm status myproject

    # Kill one, keep others
    ntm kill myproject cc_1
    assert_pane_count myproject cc 1
    assert_pane_count myproject cod 1

    # Kill rest
    ntm kill myproject --all
}
```

### Error Recovery
```bash
# Test: Agent crash recovery
test_agent_crash_recovery() {
    ntm spawn myproject --cc=1

    # Simulate crash (kill tmux pane externally)
    tmux kill-pane -t $(ntm status myproject --format json | jq -r '.agents[0].pane_id')

    # Status should detect dead agent
    status=$(ntm status myproject --format json)
    echo "$status" | jq -e '.agents[0].state == "dead"'
}

# Test: Session cleanup on kill
test_session_cleanup() {
    ntm spawn myproject --cc=3
    ntm kill myproject --all --cleanup

    # Verify no orphan panes
    assert_no_orphan_panes myproject
}
```

### State Transitions
```bash
# Test: All valid state transitions
test_state_transitions() {
    # idle -> working (send prompt)
    # working -> waiting (prompt for input)
    # waiting -> working (user input)
    # working -> idle (task complete)
    # any -> dead (crash/kill)
}
```

## Logging Format
```bash
log_e2e() {
    echo "[E2E-LIFECYCLE] test=$1 action=$2 result=$3 timestamp=$(date -Iseconds)"
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Single agent lifecycle works end-to-end
- [ ] Multi-agent spawn and kill works
- [ ] Crash detection works
- [ ] Session cleanup removes all panes
- [ ] State transitions are correct
- [ ] No orphan processes after cleanup

title: [EPIC] Robot Command Reliability
description:
# Epic: Robot Command Reliability

## Goal
Make robot commands bulletproof for AI agent consumption. This is the CRITICAL PATH for AI coding agents using NTM programmatically.

## Background
NTM serves two user personas: human operators (TUI) and AI coding agents (robot commands). AI agents are programmatic consumers - they parse JSON, check exit codes, and make decisions based on command output. Any inconsistency or ambiguity causes bugs in agent workflows.

Currently, robot commands have several reliability issues:
1. **Timeout units are inconsistent** - spawn uses seconds, others use milliseconds
2. **Error output location varies** - some to stderr, some to stdout JSON
3. **Agent type naming differs** - cc vs claude vs claude_code
4. **Unimplemented features return errors** - breaks agent error handling

## Success Criteria
- AI agents can reliably parse ALL robot command output
- No ambiguity in timeout values, error locations, or agent naming
- Unimplemented features don't break agent workflows
- All changes are backwards compatible with deprecation warnings

## Beads in this Epic
- R1: Duration string support for timeouts
- R2: Standardized JSON error responses
- R3: Agent type aliasing
- R4: Graceful unimplemented feature handling

## Architecture Considerations
- Use Go's `time.ParseDuration` for flexible timeout parsing
- Define `RobotResponse` base struct for all JSON outputs
- Create `resolveAgentType()` helper for consistent normalization
- Define `error_code` enum for programmatic error handling

## Testing Strategy
- Unit tests for each fix
- Integration tests for common robot workflows
- Validate JSON against documented schema

title: Fallback asset discovery for upgrade resilience
description:
# Fallback Asset Discovery for Upgrade Resilience

## Problem Statement
If the preferred asset name pattern doesn't match exactly, upgrade currently fails hard.
A more resilient approach would try progressively looser matching before giving up.

## Current Behavior
```go
// Try exact versioned archive
if asset.Name == archiveAssetName { ... }

// Try raw binary name
if asset.Name == binaryAssetName { ... }

// Try prefix matching as fallback
if strings.HasPrefix(name, binaryAssetName) { ... }

// Give up
return fmt.Errorf("no suitable release asset found...")
```

## Proposed Fallback Chain

### Strategy 1: Exact Archive Match (Current)
Pattern: `ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz`
Confidence: 100%

### Strategy 2: Exact Binary Match (Current)
Pattern: `ntm_darwin_all`
Confidence: 90%

### Strategy 3: Prefix Match (Current)
Pattern: `strings.HasPrefix(name, "ntm_darwin_all")`
Confidence: 70%

### Strategy 4: Fuzzy Same-OS Match (NEW)
For darwin/arm64, also try darwin/amd64, darwin/all
Confidence: 50%
Rationale: macOS Rosetta 2 can run amd64 binaries on arm64

### Strategy 5: Legacy Naming Patterns (NEW)
Try old dash-separator convention: `ntm-darwin-arm64`
Confidence: 30%
Rationale: Handle upgrades from very old versions

### Strategy 6: Smart Selection (NEW)
If multiple assets for same OS exist, pick most compatible
Confidence: Variable based on match quality

## Benefits
1. **Graceful Degradation**: Download SOMETHING rather than fail completely
2. **Forward Compatibility**: Handle future naming changes without code updates
3. **Backward Compatibility**: Handle upgrades from old releases with different naming
4. **Better UX**: Users less likely to hit dead ends

## Concerns & Mitigations

### Concern: Downloading Wrong Asset
**Risk**: Fuzzy match picks incompatible binary
**Mitigation**: 
- NEVER match cross-OS (linux asset won't be offered for darwin target)
- Warn loudly for cross-arch
- macOS arm64‚Üíamd64 is safe (Rosetta 2)
- Verify binary after download (run `ntm version`)

### Concern: Masking Real Problems
**Risk**: Fallback succeeds but hides naming issues from maintainers
**Mitigation**:
- Always log warning when using non-exact match
- CI tests use --strict mode (exact match only)
- Include fallback usage in upgrade success message
- Analytics/telemetry could track fallback usage (optional)

### Concern: Increased Complexity
**Risk**: More code paths = more potential bugs
**Mitigation**:
- Comprehensive test coverage for each strategy
- Clear logging of which path was taken
- --strict flag for CI and testing
- Fallback only in interactive mode by default

title: Implement scrollback capture for checkpoints
description:
## Overview
Capture tmux pane scrollback as part of checkpoint for complete conversation history.

## Location
Create `internal/checkpoint/scrollback.go`

## Scrollback Capture
```go
type ScrollbackCapture struct {
    PaneID      string
    Lines       int
    Content     string
    Compressed  []byte
    Size        int64
}

func CaptureScrollback(session, paneID string, lines int) (*ScrollbackCapture, error) {
    // Use tmux capture-pane
    cmd := exec.Command("tmux", "capture-pane",
        "-t", fmt.Sprintf("%s:%s", session, paneID),
        "-p",      // Print to stdout
        "-S", fmt.Sprintf("-%d", lines), // Start N lines back
        "-E", "-1", // End at current line
    )
    
    output, err := cmd.Output()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    
    // Compress with gzip
    compressed := gzipCompress(output)
    
    return &ScrollbackCapture{
        PaneID:     paneID,
        Lines:      lines,
        Content:    string(output),
        Compressed: compressed,
        Size:       int64(len(compressed)),
    }, nil
}
```

## Storage
```
checkpoint-dir/
  checkpoint.json
  scrollback/
    cc_1.txt.gz
    cc_2.txt.gz
    user_pane.txt.gz
```

## Configuration
```toml
[checkpoints]
scrollback_lines = 5000      # Default lines to capture
scrollback_compress = true   # Always gzip
scrollback_max_size_mb = 10  # Skip if too large
```

## Considerations
- Large scrollbacks can be slow to capture
- Compression is essential for storage
- Some panes may have very little scrollback
- Binary output (rare) should be handled

title: Implement file conflict detection
description:
Detect when multiple agents may have modified same files. Essential for parallel agent coordination.

DETECTION APPROACH:

1. GIT-BASED DETECTION:
   - Run `git status --porcelain` to get modified files
   - For each modified file, get modification time via `stat`
   - Correlate modification times with agent activity windows
   - If file modified during window when 2+ agents were GENERATING: flag as conflict

2. NEWLY CREATED FILES:
   - Track files created during session (not in initial git status)
   - If same file path touched by multiple agents: definite conflict
   - Use inotify/fsnotify for real-time tracking (optional enhancement)

3. AGENT MAIL INTEGRATION:
   - Query Agent Mail file reservations
   - If file reserved by Agent A but modified while Agent B active: flag
   - Confidence boost: reservation + activity = high confidence

CONFLICT CLASSIFICATION:
```go
type FileConflict struct {
    Path         string
    LikelyModifiers []string  // pane IDs
    GitStatus    string       // M, A, D, ??
    Confidence   float64      // 0.0-1.0
    Reason       string       // "concurrent_activity", "reservation_violation"
}
```

CONFIDENCE LEVELS:
- 0.9+: High confidence (reservation violation, overlapping edits)
- 0.7-0.9: Medium confidence (concurrent activity window)
- 0.5-0.7: Low confidence (possibly unrelated)

ACTIVITY WINDOW TRACKING:
- For each pane, track: last_activity_start, last_activity_end
- Activity = state was GENERATING for continuous period
- Overlap = two panes' windows intersect

LIMITATIONS:
- Cannot know exactly which agent wrote which bytes
- Best effort heuristic based on timing
- False positives possible with fast sequential edits

LOCATION: internal/robot/synthesis.go (new file)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Git status correctly parsed
- File modification times captured
- Activity windows tracked per pane
- Conflicts flagged with confidence scores
- Agent Mail reservations considered
- Handles newly created files

# Task: Implement Health Monitoring

Add health check loop with exponential backoff restart.

## Files to Create/Update

## Health Check Loop
```go
func (s *Supervisor) healthCheckLoop(ctx context.Context) {
    ticker := time.NewTicker(5 * time.Second)
    for {
        select {
        case <-ctx.Done():
            return
        case <-ticker.C:
            for _, d := range s.daemons {
                s.checkHealth(d)
            }
        }
    }
}
```

## Exponential Backoff
```go
func (d *ManagedDaemon) nextRestartDelay() time.Duration {
    base := 2 * time.Second
    delay := base * time.Duration(1<<d.restarts)
    if delay > 5*time.Minute {
        delay = 5 * time.Minute
    }
    return delay
}
```

## Health Check Method
- HTTP GET to daemon.spec.HealthURL
- Timeout: 2 seconds
- Mark unhealthy after 3 consecutive failures
- Trigger restart on unhealthy

- Test restart with backoff
- Test max backoff cap

title: T9: Standardized truncation using single-character ellipsis
description:
# T9: Standardized Truncation Using Single-Character Ellipsis

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Dashboard Visual Polish (ntm-af32)

## Problem Statement
Truncation is inconsistent across the codebase:

\`\`\`go
// Some places use three periods:
title = title[:maxLen-3] + "..."

// Some use single ellipsis:
title = layout.TruncateRunes(title, maxLen, "‚Ä¶")

// Some use custom suffixes:
title = truncate(title, maxLen, ">>")
\`\`\`

This inconsistency:
- Looks unprofessional
- Uses different character counts (3 vs 1)
- Makes width calculations inconsistent

## Solution
Standardize on single-character ellipsis "‚Ä¶" everywhere:

- Unicode: U+2026 HORIZONTAL ELLIPSIS
- Takes 1 character width
- Looks cleaner than "..."
- More precise truncation

## Implementation Details

### Standard Truncation Function
\`\`\`go
// internal/tui/layout/truncate.go

// TruncateRunes truncates string to maxLen runes, adding suffix if truncated.
// Always use this function for truncation - never manual string slicing.
func TruncateRunes(s string, maxLen int, suffix string) string {
    runes := []rune(s)
    if len(runes) <= maxLen {
        return s
    }
    if maxLen <= len(suffix) {
        return suffix[:maxLen]
    }
    return string(runes[:maxLen-len([]rune(suffix))]) + suffix
}

// Truncate is a convenience wrapper using "‚Ä¶" suffix.
func Truncate(s string, maxLen int) string {
    return TruncateRunes(s, maxLen, "‚Ä¶")
}
\`\`\`

### Search and Replace Pattern
Find all instances of:
- \`+ "..."\`
- \`+ ">>"\`
- Manual truncation without TruncateRunes

Replace with:
\`\`\`go
layout.Truncate(text, maxLen)
// or if custom suffix needed:
layout.TruncateRunes(text, maxLen, "‚Ä¶")
\`\`\`

### Files to Audit
\`\`\`bash
rg '\.\.\."|>\">|\"\.\.\"' --type go
rg '\[:[0-9]+\].*\+.*"' --type go  # Manual slice + concat
\`\`\`

### Files to Modify
- All dashboard panels
- Layout helpers
- Robot output formatters (if any)
- Any file using manual truncation

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All truncation uses TruncateRunes or Truncate
- [ ] All truncation uses "‚Ä¶" (not "...")
- [ ] No manual string slicing for truncation
- [ ] Width calculations account for 1-char ellipsis
- [ ] Visual consistency across all panels

## Examples

### Before (Inconsistent)
\`\`\`
Files:  src/authentication/handlers/login...
Beads:  Implement user registration flow>>
CASS:   Previous discussion about auth‚Ä¶
\`\`\`

### After (Consistent)
\`\`\`
Files:  src/authentication/handlers/login‚Ä¶
Beads:  Implement user registration flow‚Ä¶
CASS:   Previous discussion about auth‚Ä¶
\`\`\`

## Testing Notes
1. Resize terminal to trigger truncation
2. Verify all truncated text uses "‚Ä¶"
3. Verify truncation happens at correct length
4. Test with Unicode text (emojis, CJK characters)

# Implement ntm lock/unlock File Reservation Commands

## Purpose

Expose Agent Mail's file reservation system as NTM commands, allowing agents to declare intent before editing files and avoid conflicts.

## Command Syntax

```bash
# Reserve files for editing
ntm lock myproject "src/api/**" --reason "Implementing user endpoints"

# Reserve multiple patterns
ntm lock myproject "src/api/**" "tests/api/**"

# With TTL (default 1 hour)
ntm lock myproject "config/*.json" --ttl 2h

# Shared (read) vs exclusive (write) lock
ntm lock myproject "docs/**" --shared

# Release specific locks
ntm unlock myproject "src/api/**"

# Release all locks for session

# Show current locks
```

description:
AI-assisted work assignment suggestions based on current state.

## Rationale
With N agents and M ready beads, optimal assignment is non-trivial. This flag analyzes current state and recommends which agent should work on what, considering:
- Agent types and their strengths
- Current workload balance  
- Bead dependencies and priorities
- Recent activity patterns

## Usage
```bash
ntm --robot-assign myproject
ntm --robot-assign myproject --beads=ntm-abc,ntm-def  # specific beads
ntm --robot-assign myproject --strategy=balanced      # or: speed, quality
```


# Enhanced Upgrade Error Messages with Diagnostics

## Problem Statement
When upgrade fails to find an asset, the current error message shows:

### 2. Troubleshooting Hints

```
  ‚Ä¢ .goreleaser.yaml (how assets are built)
  ‚Ä¢ internal/cli/upgrade.go (how assets are found)

  2. Check: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/ntm/releases/latest
```

title: Implement pre/post command hooks
description:
Run user scripts before and after NTM commands.

## What This Task Does

Enable users to define hooks that run before or after specific
NTM commands. Hooks can log, notify, validate, or transform.

## Configuration

# ~/.config/ntm/config.toml

[hooks]
# Run before any send command
pre_send = "~/.config/ntm/hooks/log-prompt.sh"

# Run after spawn completes
post_spawn = "notify-send 'NTM' 'Session created'"

# Run before dangerous commands
pre_kill = "~/.config/ntm/hooks/confirm-kill.sh"

## Hook Interface

Hooks receive command context as JSON on stdin:
{
  "command": "send",
  "args": ["myproject", "--all", "hello"],
  "session": "myproject",
  "flags": {"all": true},
  "timestamp": "2025-12-10T10:00:00Z"
}

Post hooks also receive result:
{
  "command": "spawn",
  "result": "success",
  "session": "myproject",
  "panes_created": 4,
  "duration_ms": 1234
}

## Hook Execution

Pre hooks:
- Run synchronously before command
- Non-zero exit blocks the command
- Stdout captured but not displayed (log only)
- Stderr shown to user

Post hooks:
- Run asynchronously after command
- Exit code doesn't affect NTM
- Good for notifications, logging

## Disabling Hooks

For scripting or sensitive operations:
$ ntm send --no-hooks myproject 'message'

## Example Hooks

Log all prompts:
#\!/bin/bash
jq -c '{time: .timestamp, session: .session, prompt: .args[2]}' >> ~/.ntm-prompts.jsonl

Confirm before kill:
#\!/bin/bash
session=$(jq -r '.session' -)
read -p "Really kill $session? [y/N] " confirm
[[ "$confirm" == "y" ]] || exit 1

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Hooks defined in config
- [ ] Pre hooks run before command
- [ ] Pre hook failure blocks command
- [ ] Post hooks run after command
- [ ] Command context passed as JSON
- [ ] --no-hooks flag disables hooks

title: Implement stdin and --file support for ntm send
description:
Enable sending prompts from files and stdin pipes.

## What This Task Does

Extend ntm send to accept prompt content from:
1. --file flag: Read prompt from a file
2. stdin: When piped/redirected and no prompt argument given

## Use Cases

From file:
$ ntm send myproject --all --file prompts/review.md

From stdin (pipe):
$ cat error.log | ntm send myproject --cc 'Analyze this error:'
$ git diff | ntm send myproject --all 'Review these changes'

From stdin (redirect):
$ ntm send myproject --all < prompt.txt

Combined with prefix:
$ cat code.py | ntm send myproject --cc --prefix 'Review this code:\n'

## Technical Details

Detection logic:
1. If --file specified, read from file
2. Else if stdin is not a TTY, read from stdin
3. Else use positional prompt argument

Implementation:
func getPromptContent(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) (string, error) {
    if file != "" {
        content, err := os.ReadFile(file)
        return string(content), err
    }
    
    if !isatty.IsTerminal(os.Stdin.Fd()) {
        content, err := io.ReadAll(os.Stdin)
        return string(content), err
    }
    
    if len(args) > 1 {
        return args[1], nil
    }
    
    return "", errors.New("no prompt provided")
}

## The Problem
Smaller-context agents (Codex, Gemini) waste tokens on verbose JSON output.

## The Solution


```go
func GetTriageMarkdown(ctx context.Context, compact bool) (string, error) {
    args := []string{"-robot-markdown"}
    if compact {
        args = append(args, "--md-compact")
    }
    cmd := exec.CommandContext(ctx, "bv", args...)
    return string(out), nil
}
```

### Format Selection by Agent Type
```go
func getAgentContext(agentType string) (string, error) {
    if agentType == "claude" {
        // Claude has large context - use JSON
        triage, _ := GetTriage(ctx)
        return json.Marshal(triage)
    }
    // Codex/Gemini - use markdown (50% savings)
    return GetTriageMarkdown(ctx, true)
}
```

```go
budgets := map[string]int{
    "claude": 180000,
    "codex":  120000,
    "gemini": 100000,
}
```

```bash
ntm --robot-triage --format=markdown
```

title: CI upgrade compatibility check job
description:
# CI Upgrade Compatibility Check Job

## What This Accomplishes
Runs `ntm upgrade --check` on every push/PR to validate that the current code can successfully find assets from the latest published release.

## Implementation Details
**File**: .github/workflows/ci.yml:327-388 (68 lines added)
**Job Name**: upgrade-check
**Matrix**: ubuntu-latest, macos-latest

**Workflow**:
1. Checkout repository
2. Setup Go 1.25
3. Build ntm from current source
4. Run `ntm upgrade --check`
5. Check output for "no suitable release asset" error
6. If found ‚Üí FAIL with prominent error message

## Why This Catches Bugs That Tests Don't
The contract tests validate the LOGIC is correct (naming convention matches expectations).
The CI check validates the logic WORKS against REAL published releases.

**Scenario this catches**:
1. Contract tests pass (logic matches expected convention)
2. But latest release used a DIFFERENT convention than expected
3. CI check fails because ntm can't find the actual asset

This happens when:
- GoReleaser config was changed without updating tests
- Previous release had manual naming overrides
- Edge cases in template rendering

## Error Display
```

‚ïë  ERROR: Asset naming mismatch detected!                        ‚ïë
‚ïë                                                                 ‚ïë
‚ïë  upgrade.go cannot find assets from the latest release.        ‚ïë
‚ïë  This likely means:                                             ‚ïë
‚ïë  1. upgrade.go naming logic was changed, OR                     ‚ïë
‚ïë  2. .goreleaser.yaml naming template was changed                ‚ïë
‚ïë                                                                 ‚ïë
‚ïë  Review: TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract in cli_test.go          ‚ïë
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïù
```

## Graceful Handling
- "no releases found" is acceptable (dev builds, new forks)
- Only "no suitable release asset" is a hard failure
- Exit 0 if upgrade check passes OR no releases exist

## Dependency Chain
Added to ci-success job's needs array, making it a required check.

## Design Decision: Why Not Windows?
Windows is excluded because:
1. ntm requires tmux which is Unix-only
2. Windows users use WSL anyway
3. The naming contract is validated via contract tests for Windows

title: Add spawn order to agent context
description:
Communicate spawn position to each agent so they can self-coordinate if needed.

## Problem

Even with staggered prompts, agents may benefit from knowing their spawn order:
- Agent can adapt behavior (first agent explores more, later agents rely on prior work)
- Agent can self-stagger if prompt arrives simultaneously (network/timing variance)
- Agent can reference siblings ("I'm agent 2 of 4")

## Implementation Options

### Option A: Environment Variable (Recommended)

Set AGENT_SPAWN_ORDER before prompt:

```bash
export NTM_SPAWN_ORDER=2
export NTM_SPAWN_TOTAL=4
export NTM_SPAWN_BATCH_ID=spawn-abc123
```

Agent's shell inherits these, agent can read them.

Implementation in tmux:
```go
func (s *Spawner) setSpawnContext(pane Pane, order int, total int, batchID string) {
    s.tmux.SendKeys(pane.ID, fmt.Sprintf(
        "export NTM_SPAWN_ORDER=%d NTM_SPAWN_TOTAL=%d NTM_SPAWN_BATCH_ID=%s\n",
        order, total, batchID,
    ))
}
```

### Option B: Prompt Injection

Include spawn order in the prompt:

```
[NTM Context]
You are agent 2 of 4 in this spawn batch.
Batch ID: spawn-abc123
Stagger: 90s (your prompt was delayed by 90s)

[Your Task]
{original prompt}
```

Pros: Agent definitely sees it
Cons: Uses tokens, clutters prompt

### Option C: File-Based

Write spawn context to file agent can read:

```bash
# .ntm/spawn-context.json
{
  "batch_id": "spawn-abc123",
  "agents": [
    {"pane": "proj__cc_1", "order": 1, "prompt_at": "..."},
    {"pane": "proj__cc_2", "order": 2, "prompt_at": "..."}
  ]
}
```

Agent can cat this file to understand context.

## Recommended: Hybrid

1. Environment variables for programmatic access
2. Brief prompt note for agent awareness
3. File for detailed batch context

## Prompt Addition (Minimal)

When stagger is enabled, prepend to prompt:

```
[Spawn context: Agent 2/4, batch spawn-abc123]

{original prompt}
```

Just one line, minimal tokens.

## Use Cases for Agents

1. **Self-stagger backup**: If agent detects NTM_SPAWN_ORDER > 1, wait a bit extra before selecting work
2. **Work coordination**: "I'm agent 2, let me pick something different than agent 1 might have picked"
3. **Reporting**: "Agent 2 completed task X" in Agent Mail messages

## Location

internal/robot/spawn.go

## Depends On

- ntm-gnqg: Add --stagger flag to spawn command

## Acceptance Criteria

- Environment variables set for each agent
- Minimal prompt annotation when stagger enabled
- Batch ID unique per spawn invocation
- Context accessible to agents
- No regression when stagger disabled

title: Implement agent type detection from pane content
description:
Improve agent type detection beyond pane title parsing.

## Current State
detectAgentType() in robot.go only checks pane title. This is unreliable because:
- Pane titles may not be set
- Users may use custom titles
- Agent type may not be in title

## Improved Detection
1. **Pane Title**: Check for 'claude', 'codex', 'gemini', etc.
2. **Process Name**: Check running process (claude, codex-cli, etc.)
3. **Pane Content**: Look for characteristic prompts/output:
   - Claude: '>' prompt, 'Claude' mentions
   - Codex: 'codex>' prompt, OpenAI references
   - Gemini: Gemini-specific formatting
   - Cursor: Cursor AI patterns
   - Windsurf: Windsurf patterns
   - Aider: 'aider>' prompt
4. **Environment**: Check for agent-specific env vars

## Detection Priority
Process name > Pane content > Pane title > Unknown

## Caching
Cache detected type per pane to avoid repeated content parsing. Invalidate on session reload.

## Output
```go
type AgentDetection struct {
    Type       string  // claude, codex, etc.
    Confidence float64 // 0.0-1.0
    Method     string  // how detected: process, content, title
}
```

comments.author: jemanuel
comments.text:
## Detection Strategies

### Priority Order
1. **Process-based** (highest confidence)
   - ps aux | grep for process names: claude, codex-cli, gemini-cli
   - Check /proc/{pid}/cmdline on Linux
   - Most reliable but requires shell execution

2. **Environment-based**
   - Check for CLAUDE_*, OPENAI_*, GOOGLE_* env vars in pane
   - Can infer agent type from env configuration

3. **Content-based**
   - Scan last N lines of pane output
   - Look for characteristic patterns:
     - Claude: '>' prompt, 'Claude' in output, tool use XML
     - Codex: 'codex>' prompt, OpenAI references
     - Gemini: 'gemini>' prompt
     - Aider: 'aider>' or '/help' in prompt
   
4. **Title-based** (lowest confidence)
   - Current implementation - fallback only

### Caching Strategy
```go
type AgentTypeCache struct {
    cache map[string]CachedDetection // key: session:pane
    ttl   time.Duration              // default 60s
    mu    sync.RWMutex
}

type CachedDetection struct {
    Type       string
    Confidence float64
    Method     string
    DetectedAt time.Time
}
```

### Confidence Scores
- Process match: 0.95
- Env match: 0.85
- Content match: 0.70
- Title match: 0.50
- Unknown: 0.0

description:
# BD Daemon Mode Integration

## The Problem
NTM requires manual `bd sync` calls to keep beads in sync. Developers must remember to run this.

## The Solution
BD has a daemon mode that NTM ignores:
```bash
bd daemon --start --auto-commit --interval 5s --health --metrics --json
```

Use Daemon Supervisor to manage it.

## Implementation (internal/bd/daemon.go)

### BD Daemon
```go
type BDDaemon struct {
    cmd       *exec.Cmd
    port      int
    isRunning bool
    autoPush  bool  // DANGEROUS: disabled by default
}

type BDDaemonOptions struct {
    AutoCommit bool
    AutoPush   bool  // Requires policy approval
    Interval   time.Duration
}

func (d *BDDaemon) Start(ctx context.Context) error {
    args := []string{"daemon", "--start", "--auto-commit", "--interval", "5s"}
    // --auto-push only if policy allows
    if d.autoPush && policyAllows("auto_push") {
        args = append(args, "--auto-push")
    }
}
```

### Policy Control
--auto-push is:
- Disabled by default
- Requires policy.yaml permission
- Requires explicit CLI flag
- Logged for audit

### Auto-Start on Spawn
```go
func spawnSession(ctx, opts) {
    if opts.BDDaemon {
        bdDaemon := bd.NewBDDaemon(bd.BDDaemonOptions{
            AutoCommit: true,
            AutoPush:   opts.AllowAutoPush && policyAllows("auto_push"),
        })
        bdDaemon.Start(ctx)
    }
}
```

## New Commands
```bash
ntm beads daemon start
ntm beads daemon stop
ntm beads daemon status
ntm beads daemon health
ntm spawn myproject --cc=2 --bd-daemon=true  # Default
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] BD daemon managed by Supervisor
- [ ] Auto-start on spawn (default enabled)
- [ ] Auto-push policy-gated
- [ ] Health monitoring
- [ ] Clean shutdown on session end

description:
# R3: Unify Agent Type Aliasing Across Robot Flags

## Parent Epic
[EPIC] Robot Command Reliability (ntm-0q9o)

## IMPORTANT: Significant Infrastructure Already Exists

### Already Implemented:
- \`detectAgentType(title)\` in robot.go - detects from pane title
- \`DetectAgentTypeEnhanced()\` in detection.go - multi-method detection
- \`agentTypeString()\` in robot.go - converts tmux.AgentType to string
- \`AgentBadge(agentType)\` in styles/badges.go - handles cc/claude/codex/cod/gmi/gemini
- \`AgentBorderColor(agentType)\` in layout.go - handles agent colors
- \`AgentType\` enum in cli/agent_spec.go - defines AgentTypeClaude, AgentTypeCodex, AgentTypeGemini

### The Actual Gap:
Robot flag \`--type\` filter may not accept all alias forms consistently.

## Problem Statement
While most aliasing works internally, the \`--type\` flag for robot commands may not accept all forms:
\`\`\`bash
# Do all these work?
ntm --robot-send=test --type=claude --msg="hi"  # long form
ntm --robot-send=test --type=cc --msg="hi"      # short form
ntm --robot-send=test --type=claude_code --msg="hi"  # underscore form
\`\`\`

## Solution
Ensure \`--type\` flag uses centralized resolution:

### Step 1: Verify/Create Unified Resolver
Check if a single \`resolveAgentType()\` function exists. If not, create one that:
\`\`\`go
// ResolveAgentType normalizes any agent type string to canonical form.
func ResolveAgentType(input string) string {
    normalized := strings.ToLower(strings.TrimSpace(input))
    normalized = strings.ReplaceAll(normalized, "-", "_")
    
    switch normalized {
    case "cc", "claude", "claude_code":
        return "claude"
    case "cod", "codex", "codex_cli":
        return "codex"
    case "gmi", "gemini", "gemini_cli":
        return "gemini"
    // ... other types
    default:
        return normalized // Unknown type passed through
    }
}
\`\`\`

### Step 2: Use in Robot Flag Parsing
In root.go where \`--type\` is parsed:
\`\`\`go
if robotSendType != "" {
    agentTypes = strings.Split(robotSendType, ",")
    for i, t := range agentTypes {
        agentTypes[i] = ResolveAgentType(t)  // Normalize
    }
}
\`\`\`

### Files to Audit/Modify
- \`internal/robot/robot.go\` - Check type filtering logic
- \`internal/cli/root.go\` - --type flag parsing
- May need to create shared resolver if doesn't exist

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] \`--type=cc\` works same as \`--type=claude\`
- [ ] \`--type=cod\` works same as \`--type=codex\`
- [ ] \`--type=gmi\` works same as \`--type=gemini\`
- [ ] JSON output always uses canonical form
- [ ] No new enums/types created (use existing)

## Testing Notes
\`\`\`bash
# Test all alias forms work:
ntm --robot-send=test --type=cc --msg="hi"
ntm --robot-send=test --type=claude --msg="hi"
ntm --robot-send=test --type=claude_code --msg="hi"
# All should target the same panes
\`\`\`

## Integration Note for AI Agents
The canonical forms returned in JSON output are: \`claude\`, \`codex\`, \`gemini\`, \`cursor\`, \`windsurf\`, \`aider\`, \`user\`, \`unknown\`. Agents should use these forms when setting filters, though short forms will work.

title: Feature: Design Invariants Enforcement
description:
# Design Invariants Enforcement

## Purpose
Capture and enforce the 6 non-negotiable design invariants that must ALWAYS hold across all NTM features.

## The 6 Invariants

### 1. No Silent Data Loss
NTM must never cause untracked destructive actions without explicit, recorded approval.
- All destructive commands blocked or require approval
- All force-release operations logged with correlation IDs
- All file operations auditable

### 2. Graceful Degradation
If any external tool is missing/unhealthy, NTM continues with reduced capability and clear warnings.
- Tool Adapter detects missing/broken tools
- Features fallback gracefully (e.g., macros ‚Üí granular calls)
- Clear messaging about degraded functionality

### 3. Idempotent Orchestration
Spawning, reserving, assigning, and messaging should be safe to retry without duplicating work.
- Reservation operations are idempotent
- Agent registration is idempotent (same name = update, not duplicate)
- Message deduplication across channels

### 4. Recoverable State
NTM must be able to re-attach to an existing session after crash/restart.
- State Store persists sessions, agents, tasks
- Event Log enables replay for crash recovery
- tmux sessions survive NTM process death

### 5. Auditable Actions
Critical actions are logged with correlation IDs:
- Reservations, releases, force-releases
- Blocked commands
- Approvals and denials
- Task assignments and completions

### 6. Safe-by-Default
Risky automation is opt-in and policy-gated:
- auto_push: disabled by default, requires policy + approval
- force_release: requires approval by default
- destructive commands: blocked by default

## Implementation
These invariants should be:
1. Documented in code comments
2. Verified in tests (invariant violation = test failure)
3. Checked by `ntm doctor`
4. Enforced by Policy Engine

## Test Coverage
Each invariant has corresponding tests:
- TestNoSilentDataLoss: blocked commands logged
- TestGracefulDegradation: missing tool doesn't crash
- TestIdempotentOperations: safe retries
- TestRecoverableState: crash recovery works
- TestAuditableActions: events logged
- TestSafeByDefault: dangerous ops blocked

title: EPIC: Agent Personas & Roles
description:
# Agent Personas & Roles

## Background & Motivation

Currently, NTM spawns agents with identical configurations. But effective multi-agent workflows require specialization:

- **Architect**: High-level design, system thinking, reviewing others' work
- **Implementer**: Write code, follow specifications, move fast
- **Reviewer**: Find bugs, security issues, suggest improvements
- **Tester**: Write tests, verify edge cases, break things
- **Documenter**: Write docs, comments, explain code

Each role benefits from:
1. **Different models**: Opus for architects, Sonnet for implementers
2. **Different system prompts**: Prime the agent for their role
3. **Different temperature/parameters**: Creative vs precise
4. **Pre-loaded context**: Role-specific instructions

## What Personas Provide

A persona is a reusable agent configuration:
```toml
[personas.architect]
agent_type = "claude"
model = "opus"
system_prompt = """
You are a senior software architect. Focus on:
- System design and high-level structure
- Reviewing and guiding implementation
- Identifying architectural risks
- NOT writing implementation code (delegate that)
"""
temperature = 0.7
context_files = ["ARCHITECTURE.md", "docs/design/*.md"]

[personas.implementer]
agent_type = "claude"
model = "sonnet"
system_prompt = """
You are an implementation engineer. Focus on:
- Writing clean, tested code
- Following the architect's design
- Fast iteration and quick feedback
- NOT architectural decisions (escalate to architect)
"""
temperature = 0.3

[personas.reviewer]
agent_type = "claude"
model = "sonnet"
system_prompt = """
You are a meticulous code reviewer. Focus on:
- Finding bugs, edge cases, security issues
- Suggesting improvements
- Verifying tests exist and are comprehensive
- Being constructive but thorough
"""
temperature = 0.2
```

## Usage Syntax

```bash
# Spawn by persona
ntm spawn myproject --persona=architect --persona=implementer:2

# Add persona agents
ntm add myproject --persona=reviewer

# List available personas
ntm personas list

# Show persona details
ntm personas show architect
```

## Relationship to Recipes

- **Recipes**: Define SESSION layouts (which agents, how many)
- **Personas**: Define AGENT configurations (model, prompt, behavior)

They complement each other:
```toml
[recipes.fullstack]
description = "Full-stack development team"
agents = [
    { persona = "architect", count = 1 },
    { persona = "implementer", count = 2 },
    { persona = "tester", count = 1 }
]
```

## System Prompt Injection

The persona's system_prompt prepended to agent launch:
```bash
# Generated command for persona=architect
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model opus << 'SYSTEM_PROMPT'
You are a senior software architect. Focus on:
- System design and high-level structure
...
SYSTEM_PROMPT
```

Or via Claude Code's prompt file mechanism if available.

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Persona configuration schema defined
- [ ] spawn/add accept --persona flag
- [ ] System prompts injected at agent launch
- [ ] Built-in personas: architect, implementer, reviewer, tester, documenter
- [ ] User-defined personas in config
- [ ] Personas combinable with model specifiers
- [ ] ntm personas list/show commands

title: EPIC: Session Checkpointing & Time Travel
description:
Session checkpointing captures the complete state of a session at a point in time.

## Problem Statement
Multi-agent sessions can run for hours. When something goes wrong:
1. All session state is lost if terminal closes
2. No way to "go back" to a known-good state
3. Experimental changes can't be easily undone
4. Session history is only in tmux scrollback (ephemeral)

## CRITICAL DESIGN CONSIDERATION: Conversation History

**The Challenge:**
A checkpoint that only captures metadata (layout, profiles, git state) is incomplete.
When restoring, agents start fresh with no memory of the conversation.

**Solutions (implement progressively):**

### A. Context Summary Capture (MVP)
At checkpoint time, request each agent to summarize:
\`\`\`
Please provide a complete summary of our conversation including:
1. What we've been working on
2. Key decisions made
3. Current state of tasks
4. Important context to remember
\`\`\`

Store summary in checkpoint. On restore, inject as initial context.
- **Pros**: Works with any agent, reasonable size
- **Cons**: Lossy, depends on agent cooperation

### B. Tmux Scrollback Capture (Better)
Capture tmux pane scrollback:
\`\`\`bash
tmux capture-pane -t session:window.pane -p -S -10000
\`\`\`
Store in checkpoint, optionally compressed.
- **Pros**: Complete raw history
- **Cons**: Can be large, includes noise

### C. CASS Integration (Best)
If CASS is indexing conversations, checkpoint references CASS data:
\`\`\`json
{
  "agents": [{
    "id": "cc_1",
    "cass_conversation_id": "abc123",
    "cass_checkpoint_ts": "2025-01-15T11:45:00Z"
  }]
}
\`\`\`
On restore, query CASS for conversation history and inject.
- **Pros**: Structured, searchable, deduplicated
- **Cons**: Requires CASS dependency

## Solution Overview
1. **Capture**: Save full session state including conversation context
2. **Restore**: Recreate session with agents receiving their prior context
3. **Time Travel**: Browse and restore from checkpoint history
4. **Integrity**: Verify checkpoints are complete and valid

## What Gets Checkpointed

### Agent State
- Pane layout and positions
- Agent type, profile, configuration
- Context summary (from agent)
- Scrollback capture (configurable lines)
- Token usage at checkpoint time
- CASS conversation reference (if available)

### Session Metadata
- Session name, created time
- Recipe used (if any)
- Profiles applied
- Configuration overrides

### Working State
- Files modified since session start (list or diff)
- Git status and current commit
- Active beads/issues being worked on
- Pending tasks in queue

## Checkpoint File Format
\`\`\`json
{
  "version": 2,
  "session_name": "my-project",
  "created_at": "2025-01-15T11:45:00Z",
  "name": "before-refactor",
  "layout": {
    "windows": [...],
    "panes": [...]
  },
  "agents": [
    {
      "id": "cc_1",
      "type": "claude",
      "profile": "architect",
      "context_summary": "Working on API redesign...",
      "scrollback_lines": 5000,
      "scrollback_file": "cc_1_scrollback.txt.gz",
      "cass_conversation_id": "abc123",
      "token_usage": 45000
    }
  ],
  "git_state": {
    "branch": "feature/api",
    "commit": "abc123def",
    "status": "modified: api/routes.go",
    "diff_file": "git_diff.patch"
  },
  "beads_state": {
    "in_progress": ["ntm-1234"],
    "recently_closed": ["ntm-5678"]
  },
  "metadata": {
    "recipe": "standard",
    "project_root": "/path/to/project",
    "relative_root": "./project",  // For cross-machine restore
    "checksum": "sha256:..."
  }
}
\`\`\`

## Checkpoint Storage
\`\`\`
~/.local/share/ntm/checkpoints/
  <session-name>/
    before-refactor/
      checkpoint.json
      cc_1_scrollback.txt.gz
      cc_2_scrollback.txt.gz
      git_diff.patch
    auto-2025-01-15T11-45/
      checkpoint.json
      ...
    latest -> before-refactor/  # Symlink
\`\`\`

## Checkpoint Levels
\`\`\`toml
[checkpoints]
default_level = "standard"

# Levels:
# - light: metadata + summary only (fast, small)
# - standard: metadata + summary + scrollback (default)
# - full: standard + git diff + beads state (complete)
\`\`\`

## Cross-Machine Restore
Store relative paths for portability:
\`\`\`json
{
  "project_root": "/home/alice/projects/app",
  "relative_root": "projects/app",
  "git_remote": "git@github.com:org/app.git"
}
\`\`\`

On restore:
1. Check if project_root exists, use if so
2. Otherwise, try to resolve relative_root from home
3. Otherwise, clone from git_remote
4. Warn if project has diverged from checkpoint commit

## Checkpoint Integrity
\`\`\`go
type CheckpointIntegrity struct {
    Checksum     string   // SHA256 of checkpoint.json
    Files        []string // List of associated files
    FileHashes   map[string]string
    ValidatedAt  time.Time
}

func (c *Checkpoint) Verify() error {
    // Check all files exist
    // Verify checksums
    // Return detailed error if invalid
}
\`\`\`

## CLI Commands (Enhanced)

### ntm checkpoint create
\`\`\`bash
ntm checkpoint create [session]
ntm checkpoint create --name="before-refactor"
ntm checkpoint create --level=full          # Include everything
ntm checkpoint create --scrollback=10000    # Custom scrollback lines
ntm checkpoint create --no-summary          # Skip agent summary request
\`\`\`

### ntm checkpoint restore
\`\`\`bash
ntm checkpoint restore latest
ntm checkpoint restore before-refactor --force
ntm checkpoint restore before-refactor --dry-run
ntm checkpoint restore before-refactor --skip-context  # Don't inject history
ntm checkpoint restore before-refactor --project=/new/path
\`\`\`

### ntm checkpoint verify
\`\`\`bash
ntm checkpoint verify <name>  # Check integrity
ntm checkpoint verify --all   # Check all checkpoints
\`\`\`

### ntm checkpoint export
\`\`\`bash
ntm checkpoint export <name> --output=checkpoint.tar.gz
# For sharing/backup
\`\`\`

## Deliverables
1. Checkpoint capture with context summary and scrollback
2. CASS integration for conversation history (optional)
3. Checkpoint restore with context injection
4. Incremental/differential checkpoints
5. Cross-machine restore support
6. Integrity verification
7. Auto-checkpoint on interval/events
8. CLI commands for checkpoint management
9. Dashboard checkpoint indicator
10. Checkpoint export/import for sharing

## Why This Matters
- Safety net for long-running sessions
- Enables experimentation with rollback
- Disaster recovery from crashes
- Session portability/sharing
- Audit trail of session evolution
- Pre-rotation checkpoints for context continuity

## Dependencies
- Context Rotation EPIC for pre-rotation checkpoints
- CASS EPIC for conversation history (optional enhancement)
- Uses existing session state inspection

title: EPIC: Agent Observability & Status Monitoring
description:
Enable users to understand what their agents are doing without attaching to tmux.

Currently, NTM users have no visibility into agent state without manually attaching to the tmux session and visually inspecting each pane. This creates friction in multi-agent workflows:

## Goals
1. Detect and display agent status (idle/working/error) across all NTM commands
2. Enable real-time monitoring via enhanced dashboard and watch mode

## Success Criteria

- `ntm watch` streams output without requiring tmux attach
- Common errors (rate limits, crashes) are detected and surfaced

## Technical Approach

- Parse captured output for prompt patterns (idle) and error signatures
- Implement polling-based updates with configurable intervals
- Add notification hooks for error conditions

title: Agent Status Detection System
description:
Core infrastructure to detect whether agents are idle, working, or in error state.

## Overview
This is the foundational feature for all observability. It provides the ability to programmatically determine an agent's current state by analyzing tmux pane activity and output patterns.

## States to Detect
1. **IDLE** (‚ö™) - Agent is at a prompt, waiting for input
   - Detection: Last line matches prompt pattern (e.g., `$ `, `> `, `claude>`)
   - No output in last N seconds
   
2. **WORKING** (üü¢) - Agent is actively producing output
   - Detection: Output activity within last N seconds
   - Scrollback is growing
   
3. **ERROR** (üî¥) - Agent encountered a problem
   - Detection: Output matches error patterns (rate limit, crash, etc.)
   - Process may have exited
   
4. **UNKNOWN** (‚ö´) - Cannot determine state
   - Fallback when detection fails

## Technical Implementation

### Pane Activity Detection
```go
// Use tmux's pane_last_activity format
func GetPaneActivity(paneID string) (time.Time, error) {
    out := tmux("display-message", "-p", "-t", paneID, 
                "#{pane_last_activity}")
    return time.Parse(out)
}
```

### Prompt Pattern Matching
Detect idle by matching last line against known prompts:
- Claude: `claude>`, `Claude>`
- Codex: `codex>`, `$ `
- Gemini: `gemini>`
- Shell: `$ `, `% `, `‚ùØ `

### Error Pattern Database
Known error signatures:
- "rate limit" / "429" / "too many requests"
- "error:" / "Error:" / "ERROR"  
- "connection refused" / "timeout"
- "panic:" / "fatal:"

## API Design
```go
type AgentState string
const (
    StateIdle    AgentState = "idle"
    StateWorking AgentState = "working"
    StateError   AgentState = "error"
    StateUnknown AgentState = "unknown"
)

type AgentStatus struct {
    PaneID      string
    Name        string
    State       AgentState
    LastActive  time.Time
    LastOutput  string      // Last N chars of output
    ErrorType   string      // If State==Error, what kind
}

func DetectAgentStatus(pane Pane) AgentStatus
```

## Files to Create/Modify
- NEW: internal/status/detector.go - Core detection logic
- NEW: internal/status/patterns.go - Prompt/error patterns
- MOD: internal/tmux/session.go - Add activity queries

## Testing Strategy
- Unit tests with mock tmux output
- Integration tests with real tmux panes
- Edge cases: empty panes, binary output, unicode

title: Implement prompt pattern matching for idle detection
Implement error pattern detection
description:
Create pattern matchers to detect error conditions in agent output.

## Error Categories

### Rate Limiting
```
Patterns to match:
- "rate limit" (case insensitive)
- "429"
- "Too Many Requests"
- "quota exceeded"
- "try again later"
- "requests per minute"
```

### Connection Errors
```
Patterns:
- "connection refused"
- "connection reset"
- "connection timed out"
- "ECONNREFUSED"
- "ETIMEDOUT"
- "network error"
```

### Authentication Errors
```
Patterns:
- "401"
- "403"
- "unauthorized"
- "forbidden"
- "invalid.*token"
- "expired.*token"
- "authentication failed"
```

### Crashes/Panics
```
Patterns:
- "panic:"
- "fatal:"
- "segmentation fault"
- "Traceback (most recent"
- "Exception:"
```

## Implementation

### internal/status/errors.go
```go
package status

import (
    "regexp"
    "strings"
)

// ErrorPattern defines a pattern for error detection
type ErrorPattern struct {
    Type    ErrorType
    Regex   *regexp.Regexp
    Literal string
}

var errorPatterns = []ErrorPattern{
    // Rate limiting
    {Type: ErrorRateLimit, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)rate.?limit`)},
    {Type: ErrorRateLimit, Literal: "429"},
    {Type: ErrorRateLimit, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)too many requests`)},
    {Type: ErrorRateLimit, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)quota exceeded`)},
    
    // Connection
    {Type: ErrorConnection, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)connection (refused|reset|timed? ?out)`)},
    {Type: ErrorConnection, Literal: "ECONNREFUSED"},
    {Type: ErrorConnection, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)network error`)},
    
    // Auth
    {Type: ErrorAuth, Literal: "401"},
    {Type: ErrorAuth, Literal: "403"},
    {Type: ErrorAuth, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)unauthorized|forbidden`)},
    {Type: ErrorAuth, Regex: regexp.MustCompile(`(?i)(invalid|expired).{0,10}token`)},
    
    // Crash
    {Type: ErrorCrash, Literal: "panic:"},
    {Type: ErrorCrash, Literal: "fatal:"},
    {Type: ErrorCrash, Literal: "Traceback (most recent"},
}

// DetectErrorInOutput scans output for known error patterns
func DetectErrorInOutput(output string) ErrorType {
    // Check recent output only (last 50 lines)
    lines := strings.Split(output, "\n")
    start := len(lines) - 50
    if start < 0 {
        start = 0
    }
    recent := strings.Join(lines[start:], "\n")
    
    for _, p := range errorPatterns {
        if p.Regex != nil && p.Regex.MatchString(recent) {
            return p.Type
        }
        if p.Literal != "" && strings.Contains(recent, p.Literal) {
            return p.Type
        }
    }
    
    return ErrorNone
}

// ErrorMessage returns a human-readable description
func (e ErrorType) Message() string {
    switch e {
    case ErrorRateLimit:
        return "Rate limited - too many requests"
    case ErrorConnection:
        return "Connection error"
    case ErrorAuth:
        return "Authentication error"
    case ErrorCrash:
        return "Agent crashed"
    case ErrorGeneric:
        return "Error detected"
    default:
        return ""
    }
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Detects rate limit errors
- [ ] Detects connection errors
- [ ] Detects auth errors
- [ ] Detects crashes/panics
- [ ] Prioritizes most specific error type
- [ ] Only scans recent output (performance)

title: Watch Mode - Stream Agent Output
description:
New `ntm watch` command to stream agent output to terminal without tmux attach.

## Use Case
Monitor agent activity in a separate terminal while working elsewhere.
No need to attach to tmux session - output streams directly.

## Command Interface
```bash
ntm watch myproject              # Stream all panes
ntm watch myproject --cc         # Only Claude agents
ntm watch myproject --cod        # Only Codex agents
ntm watch myproject --pane=cc_1  # Specific pane
ntm watch myproject --activity   # Only show when output appears
ntm watch myproject --tail=50    # Start with last 50 lines
```

## Output Format
```
[cc_1 10:32:15] Creating AuthService class...
[cc_1 10:32:16] def authenticate(self, token):
[cc_1 10:32:17]     ...
[cod_1 10:32:18] Running tests...
[cod_1 10:32:19] ‚úì 14 passed, 0 failed
```

## Technical Implementation

### Streaming Architecture
Two approaches:

**Option A: Polling with Diff**
```go
func watchLoop(session string, interval time.Duration) {
    lastOutput := make(map[string]string)
    for {
        for _, pane := range getPanes(session) {
            current := captureOutput(pane, 100)
            if diff := computeDiff(lastOutput[pane.ID], current); diff \!= "" {
                printWithPrefix(pane.Name, diff)
            }
            lastOutput[pane.ID] = current
        }
        time.Sleep(interval)
    }
}
```

**Option B: tmux pipe-pane** (preferred)
```bash
tmux pipe-pane -t "session:pane" "cat >> /tmp/pane.log"
# Then tail -f the log
```

### Diff Detection
Only show NEW output since last check:
1. Hash previous output
2. Find common suffix
3. Print only the delta

### Color Coding
- Each pane gets consistent color
- Errors highlighted in red
- Status changes announced

## Flags
| Flag | Description |
|------|-------------|
| --cc, --cod, --gmi | Filter by agent type |
| --pane | Specific pane name |
| --activity | Only print on new output |
| --tail N | Start with last N lines |
| --no-color | Disable colors |
| --timestamps | Show timestamps (default: on) |

title: Compaction Detection & Auto-Prompt
description:
# Compaction Detection & Auto-Prompt

## Critical Requirement
After AI agent context compaction (especially in Claude Code), NTM MUST:
1. Detect the compaction event ASAP
2. Immediately send a context recovery prompt to the affected agent

## Default Recovery Prompt
```
Reread AGENTS.md so it's still fresh in your mind. Use ultrathink.
```

## Detection Patterns

### Claude Code Compaction
Watch for these patterns in pane output:
- "context window" + "compacted" / "summarized"
- "conversation was summarized"
- "This session is being continued from a previous conversation"
- "ran out of context"

### Codex Compaction  
- "context limit reached"
- "conversation truncated"

### Gemini Compaction
- "context window exceeded"
- "conversation reset"

## Implementation

### Pattern Matcher
```go
type CompactionPattern struct {
    Agent    string   // "claude", "codex", "gemini", "*"
    Patterns []string // regex patterns
}

var compactionPatterns = []CompactionPattern{
    {
        Agent: "claude",
        Patterns: []string{
            `(?i)conversation.*summarized`,
            `(?i)context.*compacted`,
            `(?i)continued from.*previous.*conversation`,
            `(?i)ran out of context`,
        },
    },
    {
        Agent: "codex",
        Patterns: []string{
            `(?i)context limit reached`,
            `(?i)conversation truncated`,
        },
    },
    {
        Agent: "gemini", 
        Patterns: []string{
            `(?i)context window exceeded`,
            `(?i)conversation reset`,
        },
    },
}
```

### Detection Loop
```go
func (d *Detector) checkForCompaction(paneOutput string, paneInfo PaneInfo) {
    for _, cp := range compactionPatterns {
        if cp.Agent != "*" && !strings.Contains(paneInfo.AgentType, cp.Agent) {
            continue
        }
        for _, pattern := range cp.Patterns {
            if matched, _ := regexp.MatchString(pattern, paneOutput); matched {
                d.handleCompaction(paneInfo)
                return
            }
        }
    }
}

func (d *Detector) handleCompaction(pane PaneInfo) {
    // Get recovery prompt from config (or use default)
    prompt := d.config.CompactionRecoveryPrompt
    if prompt == "" {
        prompt = "Reread AGENTS.md so it's still fresh in your mind. Use ultrathink."
    }
    
    // Send immediately
    tmux.SendKeys(pane.SessionName, pane.Index, prompt+"\n")
    
    // Log the event
    log.Printf("Compaction detected in %s, sent recovery prompt", pane.Title)
    
    // Optionally notify user
    if d.config.NotifyOnCompaction {
        notify("Compaction detected in %s - recovery prompt sent", pane.Title)
    }
}
```

### Integration with Watch Mode
Compaction detection should run automatically when:
1. `ntm watch` is active
2. `ntm dashboard` is running  
3. Background monitoring is enabled

### Configuration
```toml
[compaction]
# Enable auto-detection and recovery
enabled = true

# Custom recovery prompt (use %s for AGENTS.md path)
recovery_prompt = "Reread AGENTS.md so it's still fresh in your mind. Use ultrathink."

# Per-project override
# [project.myproject.compaction]
# recovery_prompt = "Reread /path/to/custom/AGENTS.md"

# Notification on compaction
notify = true

# Cooldown between prompts (prevent spam)
cooldown_seconds = 30
```

## Edge Cases

### False Positives
- User discussing compaction in a prompt
- Agent explaining what compaction is
Solution: Look for system-generated patterns, not user text

### Multiple Compactions
- Cooldown timer to prevent sending recovery prompt repeatedly
- Track last compaction time per pane

### AGENTS.md Not Found
- Check if file exists before referencing
- Fall back to generic "reread context" prompt

## Files to Create
- internal/status/compaction.go - Detection patterns and logic
- internal/status/recovery.go - Recovery prompt handling
- Add to internal/config/config.go - Compaction settings

## Priority: P0 (Critical)
This feature is essential for maintaining agent effectiveness during long sessions.

# Contract Tests for Upgrade Asset Naming Validation

## What This Accomplishes
Validates that upgrade.go's getAssetName() and getArchiveAssetName() functions produce asset names that match GoReleaser's actual output for all supported platforms.

## Implementation Details
**File**: internal/cli/cli_test.go:649-796 (147 lines added)
**Test Function**: TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract

**Platform Coverage**:
| Platform | Expected Archive | Expected Binary |
|----------|-----------------|-----------------|
| darwin/arm64 | ntm_VERSION_darwin_all.tar.gz | ntm_darwin_all |
| darwin/amd64 | ntm_VERSION_darwin_all.tar.gz | ntm_darwin_all |
| linux/amd64 | ntm_VERSION_linux_amd64.tar.gz | ntm_linux_amd64 |
| linux/arm64 | ntm_VERSION_linux_arm64.tar.gz | ntm_linux_arm64 |
| windows/amd64 | ntm_VERSION_windows_amd64.zip | ntm_windows_amd64 |
| freebsd/amd64 | ntm_VERSION_freebsd_amd64.tar.gz | ntm_freebsd_amd64 |

**Key Naming Insights Validated**:
1. macOS uses "all" (universal binary) not architecture-specific names
2. Underscore separators (_), not dashes (-)
3. Version is embedded in archive names but not raw binary names
4. Windows uses .zip extension, all others use .tar.gz

## How Bugs Are Caught
Test fails immediately with clear diagnostic:
```
Archive name mismatch for darwin/arm64:
  got:  "ntm-darwin-arm64"
  want: "ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz"
  This likely means upgrade.go is out of sync with .goreleaser.yaml
```

## Design Decision: Why Hardcoded Expectations?
We use hardcoded expected values rather than parsing .goreleaser.yaml because:
1. Simple to understand and maintain
2. Fast test execution (no YAML parsing)
3. GoReleaser template syntax is complex (Go templates with custom funcs)
4. Changes to naming convention are rare and intentional

Trade-off accepted: Manual updates needed when convention changes.
Mitigated by: CI upgrade-check validates against real releases.

description:
# ntm approve Command

## Purpose
Command to approve pending dangerous operations (force-release, force-push, etc.) that require human sign-off.

## What It Does
```bash
ntm approve <token>              # Approve a pending operation
ntm approve list                 # List pending approvals
ntm approve deny <token>         # Deny a pending operation
ntm approve history              # Show approval history
```

## Workflow
1. Agent/coordinator attempts dangerous operation
2. Policy engine blocks it and creates approval request
3. Log shows: "Force-release of reservation 123 requires approval (run: ntm approve abc123)"
4. Human reviews and runs `ntm approve abc123`
5. Operation proceeds with audit trail

## Implementation (internal/cli/approve.go)
```go
type ApprovalCommand struct {
    approvalStore *approval.Store
}

func (c *ApprovalCommand) Approve(ctx context.Context, token string) error {
    req, err := c.approvalStore.GetByToken(token)
    if err != nil {
        return fmt.Errorf("approval request not found: %w", err)
    }
    
    if req.Status != approval.StatusPending {
        return fmt.Errorf("request already %s", req.Status)
    }
    
    // Mark approved
    req.Status = approval.StatusApproved
    req.ApprovedBy = getCurrentUser()
    req.ApprovedAt = time.Now()
    c.approvalStore.Update(req)
    
    // Emit event for waiting goroutines
    events.Emit("approval.granted", req)
    
    return nil
}
```

## Integration
- Works with Approval Workflow Engine
- Used by File Reservation force-release
- Used by SLB Safety Gates
- All approvals logged to event log for audit

Implement agent scoring system
description:
Score agents by suitability for new work. Enables intelligent work distribution.

SCORING FORMULA (Configurable):
```
Score = (context_weight √ó context_score) 
      + (state_weight √ó state_score) 
      + (recency_weight √ó recency_score)
      + (affinity_bonus)  # if task matches agent's current work

Default weights: context=0.4, state=0.4, recency=0.2
```

COMPONENT SCORES:

1. CONTEXT SCORE (0-100):
   - context_score = 100 - context_usage_percent
   - Uses --robot-context data
   - Empty context = 100, 80% full = 20

2. STATE SCORE (-100 to 100):
   ```
   WAITING:    100  # Ready for work
   THINKING:    50  # May become available
   GENERATING:   0  # Currently busy
   STALLED:    -50  # May need restart
   ERROR:     -100  # Excluded
   rate_limited: -75  # In backoff
   ```

3. RECENCY SCORE (0-100):
   - Based on time since last activity
   - Recent activity (< 1m): 20 (agent is "hot")
   - Medium (1-5m): 10
   - Idle (> 5m): 5

4. AFFINITY BONUS (0-20):
   - If prompt contains keywords matching agent's recent work
   - Encourages sending related tasks to same agent
   - Optional, disabled by default

EXCLUSION RULES:
- health == unhealthy: Score = -100 (excluded)
- health == rate_limited: Score = -75 (excluded unless only option)
- State == ERROR: Score = -100 (excluded)

CONFIGURATION:
```toml
[routing.scoring]
context_weight = 0.4
state_weight = 0.4
recency_weight = 0.2
affinity_enabled = false
affinity_bonus = 20

# Thresholds
exclude_context_above = 85  # Skip agents > 85% context
exclude_if_generating = true  # Skip busy agents
```

LOCATION: internal/robot/routing.go (new file)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All score components calculated correctly
- Weights configurable via config
- Exclusion rules enforced
- Affinity bonus works when enabled
- Scores normalized to 0-100 (after exclusions)
- Unhealthy/rate-limited agents excluded

description:
# Multi-Model Support

## Background & Motivation

Currently, NTM treats agent types as monolithic:
- `--cc` spawns Claude with a fixed command
- `--cod` spawns Codex with a fixed command
- `--gmi` spawns Gemini with a fixed command

But in practice, power users need model flexibility:
- Use Claude Opus for architecture decisions (expensive, powerful)
- Use Claude Sonnet for implementation (cheaper, fast)
- Use GPT-4 for one task, o1 for reasoning-heavy tasks
- Mix Gemini Pro and Flash based on complexity

## The Problem

Real-world multi-agent workflows look like:
```
Architect (Opus) ‚Üí Designer (Sonnet) ‚Üí Implementer (Codex) ‚Üí Reviewer (Opus)
```

NTM should enable this naturally without manual agent configuration.

## Proposed Syntax

### Spawn with model specifiers
```bash
# Basic: 2 Opus, 1 Sonnet
ntm spawn myproject --cc=2:opus --cc=1:sonnet

# Full model names
ntm spawn myproject --cc=1:claude-opus-4 --cc=2:claude-sonnet-4

# Codex variants
ntm spawn myproject --cod=1:gpt4 --cod=1:o1

# Gemini variants
ntm spawn myproject --gmi=1:pro --gmi=1:flash
```

### Add with model specifiers
```bash
ntm add myproject --cc=1:haiku  # Add cheap agent for simple tasks
```

## Model Aliases

Short aliases mapped to full model names in config:
```toml
[models.claude]
opus = "claude-opus-4"
sonnet = "claude-sonnet-4"
haiku = "claude-haiku"

[models.codex]
gpt4 = "gpt-4"
o1 = "o1"

[models.gemini]
pro = "gemini-pro"
flash = "gemini-flash"
```

## Pane Naming Enhancement

Current: `myproject__cc_1`
Enhanced: `myproject__cc_opus_1` or `myproject__cc_1_opus`

This enables filtering by model:
```bash
ntm send myproject --cc:opus "Architecture review needed"
```

title: Create SSH wrapper for tmux commands
description:
Enable tmux commands to execute on remote hosts via SSH.

## What This Task Does

Create an abstraction layer that allows all tmux operations to run
either locally or on a remote host via SSH.

## Interface

$ ntm spawn myproject --ssh devbox --cc=4
$ ntm list --ssh devbox
$ ntm attach myproject --ssh devbox

## Technical Approach

Modify internal/tmux package to support remote execution:

type TmuxClient struct {
    Remote string // empty for local, "user@host" for remote
}

func (c *TmuxClient) Run(args ...string) (string, error) {
    if c.Remote == "" {
        return exec.Command("tmux", args...).Output()
    }
    sshArgs := append([]string{c.Remote, "tmux"}, args...)
    return exec.Command("ssh", sshArgs...).Output()
}

## SSH Configuration

Support SSH config hosts:
- $ ntm list --ssh devbox   # Uses ~/.ssh/config host
- $ ntm list --ssh user@192.168.1.100

Respect SSH options:
- ControlMaster for connection reuse
- Identity files
- Proxy jumps

## Error Handling

Connection failures:
- Clear error message with SSH exit code
- Suggest checking SSH connectivity
- Timeout handling

Auth failures:
- Detect auth errors
- Suggest ssh-add for key issues

## Session Context

Store remote host in tmux environment variable:
$ tmux set-environment -t myproject NTM_REMOTE_HOST devbox

When operating on existing session, detect remote host:
- If --ssh provided, use it
- Else check NTM_REMOTE_HOST
- Else assume local

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] TmuxClient abstraction supports local and remote
- [ ] All existing tmux functions work with remote
- [ ] SSH config hosts supported
- [ ] Connection errors handled gracefully
- [ ] Remote host stored with session

title: EPIC: Agent Organization & Filtering
description:
Enable logical grouping and filtering of agents via tags.

## Problem Statement

Current agent organization is limited to sessions:
- All agents in a session are treated as one group
- Can't target subsets like 'all frontend agents' across sessions
- Can't filter ntm list to show only certain agent types
- No way to apply operations to logical groups

As agent counts grow, this becomes unwieldy. Users run 10+ agents across
multiple sessions and need better organization primitives.

## Goals

1. Add tagging system for agents (multiple tags per agent)
2. Filter all operations by tag (send, list, kill, status)
3. Tags persist across restarts (stored in pane title metadata)
4. Support tag expressions (AND, OR, NOT)

## Why This Matters

Tags provide a flexible, user-defined organization layer:
- Group by concern: frontend, backend, database, tests
- Group by purpose: refactor, bugfix, feature, research
- Group by priority: critical, background, experimental
- Group by lifecycle: temporary, persistent

This enables workflows like:
- 'Send status update to all backend agents'
- 'Kill all experimental agents'
- 'List only agents working on the auth feature'

## Success Criteria

- ntm spawn myproject --cc=2 --tags=frontend,ui
- ntm add myproject --cod=1 --tags=backend,api
- ntm send --tag=frontend 'Update the navbar'
- ntm list --tag=backend
- ntm kill --tag=experimental
- Tags visible in ntm status output

## Technical Approach

Tags stored in tmux pane title:
- Current format: session__cc_1
- New format: session__cc_1[frontend,ui]

Tag operations:
- Parse tags from pane title during list operations
- Match tags using simple OR logic (any match = included)
- Future: Support expressions like 'frontend AND NOT experimental'

Config for default tags:
[agents.claude]
default_tags = ["ai", "code"]

## Interaction with Other Features

- JSON Output: Tags included in --json output
- Notifications: Can filter notifications by tag
- Health Checks: Can check health of tagged subset
- Remote Sessions: Tags work across remote sessions

## Design Decisions

Why pane titles for storage?
- Already using pane titles for agent type info
- Survives session detach/reattach
- Visible in tmux list-panes
- No external state to sync

Why not a separate database?
- Adds complexity
- Requires syncing with tmux state
- Pane titles are the source of truth anyway

```go
// In spawn logic, after pane is created:
```

title: Feature: Durable State Store
description:
# Durable State Store (internal/state/)

## Purpose
SQLite-backed storage for all orchestration state: sessions, agents, tasks, reservations, messages. Enables crash recovery, re-attach, and event-driven UIs.

## Why This Matters
- **Crash recovery**: Without state store, crash = total context loss
- **Re-attach**: Can't reconnect to existing session
- **Polling**: TUI/web must poll repeatedly without stored state
- **Audit**: No history of what happened

## Schema
```sql
CREATE TABLE sessions (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    name TEXT NOT NULL,
    project_path TEXT NOT NULL,
    created_at TIMESTAMP NOT NULL,
    status TEXT NOT NULL  -- active, paused, terminated
);

CREATE TABLE agents (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    session_id TEXT REFERENCES sessions(id),
    name TEXT NOT NULL,  -- e.g., "GreenLake"
    type TEXT NOT NULL,  -- cc, cod, gmi
    model TEXT,
    tmux_pane_id TEXT,
    last_seen TIMESTAMP,
    status TEXT NOT NULL  -- idle, working, error, crashed
);

CREATE TABLE tasks (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    session_id TEXT REFERENCES sessions(id),
    agent_id TEXT REFERENCES agents(id),
    bead_id TEXT,
    correlation_id TEXT,
    status TEXT NOT NULL,
    created_at TIMESTAMP,
    completed_at TIMESTAMP
);

CREATE TABLE reservations (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
    session_id TEXT REFERENCES sessions(id),
    agent_id TEXT REFERENCES agents(id),
    path_pattern TEXT NOT NULL,
    exclusive BOOLEAN NOT NULL,
    correlation_id TEXT,
    expires_at TIMESTAMP,
    released_at TIMESTAMP,
    force_released_by TEXT
);

CREATE TABLE tool_health (
    tool TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    version TEXT,
    capabilities TEXT,
    last_ok TIMESTAMP,
    last_error TEXT
);
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] SQLite database created at .ntm/state.db
- [ ] All tables created with correct schema
- [ ] CRUD operations for all entities
- [ ] Correlation IDs link tasks ‚Üí reservations
- [ ] Re-open after crash recovers all state
close_reason: Implementation complete: internal/state/ package with SQLite-backed Store, full CRUD for all entities (Session, Agent, Task, Reservation, Approval, ContextPack, ToolHealth), migration system, WAL mode, thread-safe mutex, and ReplayEvents for crash recovery

# T7: Error Recovery Feedback with Retry State Indication

The base error state component already exists: \`components.ErrorState(message, hint, width)\`

Current error flow shows static error with "Press r to retry" but:

func ErrorState(message, hint string, width int) string {

}

func RetryState(message string, attempt int, maxAttempts int, width int) string {
    return RenderState(StateOptions{
        Kind:       StateRetrying, 
        Message:    message,
        Attempt:    attempt,
        MaxAttempt: maxAttempts,
        Width:      width,
    })
}
\`\`\`

const (
    StateEmpty StateKind = iota

# Tool Adapter Framework (internal/tools/)

## Purpose
Provides a consistent interface for interacting with all ecosystem tools (bv, bd, am, cm, cass, s2p). Without this, every integration duplicates tool detection, version checking, and capability detection logic.

## Why This Matters
- **Schema drift**: Tool JSON output can change between versions, breaking NTM
- **Missing tools**: Graceful degradation needs capability detection
- **Caching**: Repeated tool calls waste resources
- **Fallbacks**: When macros unavailable, fall back to granular calls

## Interface
```go
type ToolAdapter interface {
    Name() string
    Detect() bool
    Version() (semver.Version, error)
    Capabilities() ([]string, error)
    Health() (*HealthStatus, error)
}
```

## Key Behaviors
- Version parsing from --version output

- JSON schema validation with golden tests
- Results cached per session (invalidated on tool upgrade)

title: EPIC: Scriptability & Automation Foundation
description:
Enable NTM to be scripted, piped, and composed with other Unix tools.

## Problem Statement

NTM is currently a human-interactive tool. All output is formatted for human reading, and input must come from command-line arguments. This severely limits:

1. **Scripting**: Can't parse ntm list output reliably in shell scripts
2. **CI/CD Integration**: No machine-readable output for automation pipelines  
3. **Composition**: Can't pipe NTM into jq, grep, awk, or other Unix tools
4. **Complex Prompts**: Can't send multi-line prompts, file contents, or piped data
5. **Reproducibility**: Hard to replay exact workflows programmatically

## Goals

1. Add --json flag to all commands producing structured, parseable output
2. Support stdin and --file for prompt input to ntm send
3. Establish consistent JSON schemas across all commands
4. Maintain human-friendly defaults while enabling machine mode

## Why This Matters

The Unix philosophy: tools should do one thing well and compose with others. NTM orchestrates agents, but without scriptability, users can't build on top of it.

Real-world scenarios this enables:
- ntm list --json | jq '.[] | select(.agents.claude > 0) | .name'
- ntm status myproject --json | jq '.panes[] | select(.status == "idle")'
- cat requirements.txt | ntm send myproject --all "Implement these features"
- git diff HEAD~5 | ntm send myproject --cc "Review these changes"
- CI pipelines that spawn agents, send prompts, and verify outputs

## Success Criteria

- Every command that produces output supports --json
- JSON schemas are documented and consistent
- ntm send accepts --file and reads from stdin when not a TTY
- Scripts can reliably parse NTM output without fragile text parsing
- Exit codes are meaningful (0=success, 1=error, 2=partial)

## Technical Considerations

- JSON output should include all data, not just what's shown in text mode
- Timestamps should be ISO 8601
- Nested structures where appropriate (e.g., panes within sessions)
- Schema versioning for future compatibility
- Streaming JSON (JSON lines) for long-running commands

title: EPIC: Context Window Intelligence
description:
# Context Window Intelligence

## Background & Motivation

AI coding agents have finite context windows. As agents work, their context fills up. When context approaches limits:
- Agent performance degrades
- Responses become confused or repetitive
- Critical context may be lost

**Problem**: Users have no visibility into context usage.

## CRITICAL: Honest About Limitations

**We cannot measure actual context usage.** The agent CLIs don't expose this data.

What we CAN do:
1. **Estimate** based on visible output (scrollback)
2. **Detect patterns** that suggest context exhaustion
3. **Show relative usage** (low/medium/high/critical)
4. **Warn** when estimates suggest problems

**What we show is an ESTIMATE, not actual usage.**

## Estimation Approach

### Method 1: Scrollback-Based Estimate
- Capture pane scrollback (visible conversation)
- Apply overhead multiplier (system prompts, tool calls, hidden context)
- This gives a rough LOWER BOUND on usage

### Method 2: Heuristic Detection
Detect behavioral patterns suggesting context exhaustion:
- Repeated identical tool calls
- "I apologize" / confusion patterns
- Forgetting recent context
- Circular reasoning

### Display Philosophy
Instead of precise percentages, use qualitative indicators:
```
cc_1 (opus)    [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë] Low      (~50k est.)
cc_2 (sonnet)  [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë] Medium   (~120k est.)
cod_1 (gpt4)   [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë] High     (~100k est.) ‚ö†Ô∏è
gmi_1 (pro)    [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë] Low      (~100k est.)
```

The "est." suffix reminds users these are estimates.

## Technical Details

### Token Estimation
Use character-based heuristic (~3.5 chars/token for English):
```go
func EstimateTokens(text string) int {
    return len(text) * 10 / 35  // ~3.5 chars per token
}
```

Simpler and more honest than pretending to have accurate tokenizers.

### Overhead Multiplier
Visible scrollback is only part of context. Apply 2-3x multiplier:
- System prompts: ~2-5k tokens
- Tool definitions: ~5-15k tokens
- Hidden conversation: varies

Conservative default: 2.5x multiplier

### Context Limits
```go
var ApproxContextLimits = map[string]int{
    "opus":   200000,
    "sonnet": 200000,
    "haiku":  200000,
    "gpt4":   128000,
    "o1":     128000,
    "pro":    1000000,
    "flash":  1000000,
}
```

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Scrollback-based estimation implemented
- [ ] Qualitative display (Low/Medium/High/Critical)
- [ ] Clear "estimate" labeling throughout
- [ ] Heuristic exhaustion detection (patterns)
- [ ] Configurable warning threshold
- [ ] Dashboard integration with context bars
- [ ] Honest about what we don't know

# Implement Model-Based Filtering in send Command

## Purpose

Allow targeting specific models when sending prompts.

## Current Syntax

```bash
ntm send myproject --cc "message"     # All Claude agents
ntm send myproject --all "message"    # All agents
```

## Enhanced Syntax

```bash
ntm send myproject --cc:opus "message"     # Only Opus agents
ntm send myproject --cc:sonnet "message"   # Only Sonnet agents
ntm send myproject --cod:gpt4 "message"    # Only GPT-4 agents
ntm send myproject --cc:opus --cc:sonnet "message"  # Opus + Sonnet
```

## Flag Parsing

Parse colon-separated type:model:
```go
type SendTarget struct {
    Type  AgentType
    Model string  // Empty = all models of type
}

func ParseSendTarget(flag string) SendTarget {
    parts := strings.SplitN(flag, ":", 2)
    target := SendTarget{Type: AgentType(parts[0])}
    if len(parts) > 1 {
        target.Model = parts[1]
    }
    return target
}
```

## Pane Matching

```go
func MatchesSendTarget(pane Pane, target SendTarget) bool {
    if pane.Type != target.Type {
        return false
    }
    if target.Model != "" && pane.Model != target.Model {
        return false
    }
    return true
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] --cc:model syntax parsed correctly
- [ ] Multiple model filters can be combined
- [ ] Works with panes using new naming format
- [ ] Error if model filter matches no panes
- [ ] Backwards compatible with --cc (no model)
