description:
# Checkpoint & Rollback System

## Background & Motivation

AI agents sometimes go off track. By the time users notice, significant work may be wasted.

Checkpoints provide quick recovery:
1. Create named save points before risky operations
2. Roll back to known-good state when things go wrong

## What Gets Checkpointed

### Captured (for restoration)
- **Git state**: Uncommitted changes saved as patch
- **Session layout**: Pane configuration, agent types

### Captured (for reference only)
- **Pane scrollback**: What agents were doing (NOT restored)
- **Timestamp and description**: Human context

### NOT Captured
- Agent internal state (we can't access it)
- API conversation history (we can't access it)

## IMPORTANT: What Rollback Does

Rollback restores GIT STATE, not agent state.

```bash
ntm rollback myproject "before-refactor"
```

This will:
1. ‚úÖ Stash current uncommitted changes
2. ‚úÖ Apply checkpoint's git patch
3. ‚úÖ Interrupt all agents (Ctrl+C)
4. ‚ö†Ô∏è Agents restart with FRESH context (no memory of pre-rollback work)

**Critical understanding**: Agents don't "remember" the checkpoint. They start fresh. The checkpoint restores FILES, not agent memory.

## Command Interface

```bash
# Create checkpoint
ntm checkpoint myproject "before-refactor"
# Captures: git diff, session layout, scrollback (for reference)

# List checkpoints
ntm checkpoints myproject
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ Checkpoints: myproject                                      ‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§
‚îÇ before-refactor    ‚îÇ 15 min ago ‚îÇ 3 files ‚îÇ 4 agents      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ api-working        ‚îÇ 2 hrs ago  ‚îÇ 1 file  ‚îÇ 4 agents      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ auto-20251210-1400 ‚îÇ 3 hrs ago  ‚îÇ 8 files ‚îÇ 4 agents      ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

# Preview rollback
ntm rollback myproject "before-refactor" --dry-run

# Execute rollback
ntm rollback myproject "before-refactor"
# Warning: This will reset files and interrupt agents.
# Current changes will be stashed. Continue? [y/N]

# Quick rollback to last checkpoint
ntm rollback myproject --last
```

## Storage Format

```
~/.config/ntm/checkpoints/myproject/before-refactor/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ metadata.json         # Timestamp, description, session info
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ git-state.patch       # git diff output
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ session-layout.json   # Pane configuration
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ scrollback/           # Reference only (not restored)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ cc_1.txt
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ cod_1.txt
```

## Auto-Checkpoints

Configurable automatic checkpoints:
```toml
[checkpoints]
auto_enabled = true
auto_events = ["broadcast_send"]  # Before ntm send --all
max_auto_checkpoints = 10
retention_days = 7
```

## Validation

Before rollback:
- Check if checkpoint exists
- Warn if checkpoint is old (>24h)
- Warn if git state has diverged significantly
- Validate patch can apply

## Success Criteria

- [ ] ntm checkpoint creates named checkpoints
- [ ] Git state (uncommitted) captured as patch
- [ ] Session layout captured for reference
- [ ] Scrollback captured for reference (not restored)
- [ ] ntm rollback restores git state
- [ ] Agents interrupted on rollback (fresh start)
- [ ] Auto-checkpoint on configurable events
- [ ] Retention policy with rotation
- [ ] Clear user messaging about what rollback does/doesn't do

description:
Automatically restart agents that crash or exit unexpectedly.

## What This Task Does

Add --auto-restart flag to ntm spawn that monitors agents and restarts
them if they crash. This builds on the health check infrastructure.

## Interface

$ ntm spawn myproject --cc=2 --auto-restart
Starting agents with auto-restart enabled...
[Agent cc_1 crashed, restarting in 30s...]
[Agent cc_1 restarted successfully]

Configuration:
[resilience]
auto_restart = true
max_restarts = 3
restart_delay_seconds = 30

## Technical Approach

Option 1: Background goroutine
- Spawn launches a monitor goroutine
- Periodically checks health
- Restarts crashed agents
- Exits when session ends

Option 2: Separate daemon
- ntm spawn --auto-restart starts a background process
- Process monitors and restarts
- Survives terminal close

Recommendation: Start with Option 1 (simpler), evolve to Option 2 if needed.

## Restart Logic

1. Detect crash via health check (exit code != 0, process gone)
2. Check restart count for this agent
3. If under max_restarts:
   a. Wait restart_delay_seconds
   b. Get agent type from pane title
   c. Re-run agent command in same pane
   d. Increment restart count
4. If over max_restarts:
   a. Log failure
   b. Send notification (if enabled)
   c. Stop monitoring this agent

## State Tracking

Need to track per-agent:
- Restart count since session start
- Last restart time
- Original agent command

Store in:
- Memory (simple, lost on ntm exit)
- Tmux environment variable (persists)
- File (overkill for now)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] --auto-restart flag enables monitoring
- [ ] Crashed agents are detected and restarted
- [ ] Restart delay is configurable
- [ ] Max restart limit is enforced
- [ ] Restart count shown in health output
- [ ] Works with existing spawn command

title: EPIC: Automation, Pipelines & Integration
description:
Advanced automation including agent pipelines, webhooks, and external integrations.

## Problem Statement
NTM is currently manual and reactive:
- Each prompt requires explicit user action
- No way to chain agent outputs as inputs to other agents
- No notifications when agents finish or error
- No integration with external tools (CI, Slack, etc.)
- File content must be manually copied into prompts

## Goals
1. Enable pipeline mode (chain agents sequentially)
2. Support webhook/notification on events
3. Easy file content injection into prompts
4. Token/cost estimation before sending expensive prompts

## Success Criteria
- `ntm pipeline` chains agent stages with output passing
- Config supports on_error, on_complete webhooks
- `ntm send --file=path` injects file content
- `ntm send --estimate` shows token/cost estimate

## Pipeline Mode
```bash
ntm pipeline myproject \
  --stage="cc: Design the authentication module" \
  --stage="cod: Implement the design from previous stage" \
  --stage="gmi: Write tests for the implementation"
```

Each stage:
1. Sends prompt to specified agent type
2. Waits for completion (detect idle state)
3. Captures output
4. Passes output as context to next stage

## Webhook Config
```toml
[notifications]
on_error = "curl -X POST https://slack.webhook/..."
on_complete = "terminal-notifier -message 'Done'"
on_rate_limit = "echo 'Rate limited' >> ~/ntm-alerts.log"
```

## File Context
```bash
ntm send myproject --all \
  --file=src/auth.py \
  --file=src/models.py:10-50 \
  "Refactor these files to use dependency injection"
```

Injects files with formatting:
```
# File: src/auth.py
\`\`\`python
<file contents>
\`\`\`
```

## Cost Estimation
- Count tokens in prompt using tiktoken or similar
- Estimate based on known pricing (Claude, Codex, Gemini)
- Show estimate, ask for confirmation on expensive prompts

## User Value
- Sophisticated multi-stage workflows
- Stay informed without constant monitoring
- Faster prompt construction with file injection
- Budget awareness for API-heavy usage

title: File Context Injection (--file flag)
description:
Add --file flag to ntm send to inject file contents into prompts.

## Use Case
Instead of manually copying file contents, specify files to include:
```bash
ntm send myproject --all \
  --file=src/auth.py \
  --file=src/models.py \
  "Refactor these to use dependency injection"
```

## Prompt Injection Format
Files are prepended to prompt with clear formatting:
```
# File: src/auth.py
\`\`\`python
<contents of src/auth.py>
\`\`\`

# File: src/models.py
\`\`\`python
<contents of src/models.py>
\`\`\`

---

Refactor these to use dependency injection
```

## Extended Syntax
```bash
--file=path                    # Entire file
--file=path:10-50              # Lines 10-50
--file=path:10-                # Line 10 to end
--file=path:-50                # First 50 lines
--file=path:func:my_function   # Extract function (future)
```

## Implementation
```go
type FileSpec struct {
    Path      string
    StartLine int  // 0 = from beginning
    EndLine   int  // 0 = to end
}

func ParseFileSpec(spec string) (FileSpec, error) {
    // Parse "path:start-end" format
}

func InjectFiles(specs []FileSpec, prompt string) (string, error) {
    var parts []string
    
    for _, spec := range specs {
        content, err := readFileRange(spec)
        if err != nil {
            return "", fmt.Errorf("failed to read %s: %w", spec.Path, err)
        }
        
        lang := detectLanguage(spec.Path)
        header := fmt.Sprintf("# File: %s", spec.Path)
        if spec.StartLine > 0 || spec.EndLine > 0 {
            header += fmt.Sprintf(" (lines %d-%d)", spec.StartLine, spec.EndLine)
        }
        
        parts = append(parts, fmt.Sprintf("%s\n```%s\n%s\n```", 
            header, lang, content))
    }
    
    parts = append(parts, "---\n\n"+prompt)
    return strings.Join(parts, "\n\n"), nil
}
```

## Language Detection
Map file extensions to markdown language tags:
```go
var langMap = map[string]string{
    ".py":   "python",
    ".go":   "go",

## Integration with Templates
Templates can reference {{file}} and {{files}}:
```markdown
---
name: review
variables:

---
Review the following file for issues:

{{file}}

Focus on security and performance.

| Flag | Description |
|------|-------------|
| -f, --file | File to include (repeatable) |
| --file-format | Format: markdown (default), raw, xml |
| --no-file-header | Omit file path headers |

## Edge Cases
- File not found: Error with clear message
- Binary files: Skip with warning
- Very large files: Warn if > 50KB, --force to override
- Relative vs absolute paths: Resolve relative to cwd

description:
# Premium UX Polish (Stripe-level Terminal UX)

## Goal
Make NTM feel calm, obvious, and premium ‚Äî like a best-in-class product ‚Äî while staying true to terminal constraints.

This is a **polish program epic**: it coordinates UX improvements across CLI + TUI, emphasizing:
- Clear information hierarchy (less visual noise)
- Predictable navigation (stable keymaps + help overlays)
- Actionable copy (every error tells you what to do next)
- Smoothness (minimal flicker/jitter, fast refresh, responsive interactions)
- Accessibility (reduced motion, icon fallbacks, contrast)

## Target User Journeys
1. **First run**: install ‚Üí `ntm deps` ‚Üí `ntm tutorial` ‚Üí `ntm spawn` ‚Üí `ntm palette` ‚Üí `ntm dashboard`
2. **Daily loop**: attach ‚Üí palette ‚Üí send ‚Üí dashboard ‚Üí copy/save ‚Üí detach
3. **Remote over SSH**: sessions persist, minimal surprises, no brittle quoting, clear "where am I" context

## Scope
- CLI: copywriting, error remediation, progress affordances
- Palette: search + target selection clarity + recents/favorites
- Dashboard: stable layout + help/legend + better empty/loading/error states
- Theme/accessibility: reduced motion + safe icon fallbacks + contrast
- Performance: refresh budgets, caching, graceful degradation
- Docs alignment (update existing docs; avoid new doc sprawl)

## Out of Scope (tracked elsewhere)
- New major product surfaces (e.g., VS Code extension) ‚Üí see `ntm-97c5`
- New data sources/panels already covered under dashboard program ‚Üí see `ntm-jpp1`
- Large config discovery work ‚Üí see `ntm-bke.1`

## Related / Dependencies (foundations)
- Dashboard foundation: `ntm-jpp1`, `ntm-im5l`, `ntm-p99w`, `ntm-amou`
- Width + layout primitives: `ntm-ci35`
- Refresh cadence: `ntm-0c8q`
- Theme system: `ntm-ed5`, `ntm-ube`
- Context/session inference: `ntm-4ji`, `ntm-bke.1`

design:
## Why this matters
A ‚ÄúStripe-level‚Äù feel in terminal comes from **consistency** more than effects. If every screen invents its own spacing, borders, and help hints, the product feels noisy and amateur.

## Guidance
- Prefer shared helpers over one-off lipgloss styles.
- Design for **width tiers** and **icon sets** from day 1.
- Keep overlays minimal: show the top 10% of keys that drive 90% of usage.

## Downstream impact
Palette/dashboard polish tasks should reuse these primitives rather than re-implementing per-screen versions.

## Error copy contract
Every error should include:
1) **What failed** (command + target)
2) **Why** (root cause in plain language)

- Prefer deterministic inference (cwd ‚Üí project/session mapping).
- If ambiguous, show an interactive chooser.
- Always echo the chosen session explicitly.

## Avoid
- One-off flags per command.
- Huge stack traces by default.

design:
## Terminal constraints
We can‚Äôt rely on:
- Nerd Fonts
- good color support
- wide panes
- low-latency refresh

description:
# IDE Integration (VS Code Extension)

## Background & Motivation

Most developers work primarily in VS Code. IDE integration reduces context switching and enables unique value that terminal-only can't provide.

## CRITICAL: Focus on Unique IDE Value

The terminal TUI is already excellent. Don't rebuild it in VS Code.

**Unique IDE value:**
1. **Editor context injection**: Send selected code/current file to agents
2. **Quick access**: Status bar for at-a-glance info
3. **File decorations**: Show lock status in explorer

**NOT prioritized:**
- Full dashboard webview (duplicates TUI)
- Complex session management (use terminal)

## What the Extension Provides

### 1. Status Bar (High Value, Low Effort)
```
[NTM: myproject ‚óè 4 agents]
```
- Click to open command palette
- Shows session name, agent count
- Color indicates status (green=ok, yellow=warning)

### 2. Commands (High Value, Medium Effort)
```
NTM: Send Selection to Agent
NTM: Send Current File to Agent
NTM: Spawn Agents for Project
NTM: Show Session Status
NTM: Open Terminal (attach to session)
```

### 3. Context Injection (Killer Feature)
```typescript
// When user invokes "Send Selection"
const selection = editor.selection;
const text = editor.document.getText(selection);
const filePath = editor.document.fileName;

// Construct context-aware prompt
const prompt = `
File: ${filePath}
Selected code:
\`\`\`
${text}
\`\`\`

[User's instruction here]
`;

// Send via ntm send
await ntm.send(session, target, prompt);
```

### 4. File Decorations (Medium Value, Medium Effort)
Show lock status in file explorer:
- üîí icon for locked files
- Tooltip: "Locked by GreenCastle (cc_1)"
- Requires Agent Mail integration

### 5. Simple Session View (Optional)
Activity bar panel with:
- List of sessions
- Agent count per session
- Quick actions (attach, kill)

NOT a full dashboard - just navigation.

## What We're NOT Building

- ‚ùå Full webview dashboard (use terminal TUI)
- ‚ùå Inline agent chat (complex, scope creep)
- ‚ùå Custom editor for prompts (overkill)

## Technical Approach

### CLI Wrapper
```typescript
class NtmClient {
    async getStatus(): Promise<RobotStatus> {
        const result = await exec('ntm --robot-status');
        return JSON.parse(result.stdout);
    }
    
    async send(session: string, target: string, prompt: string): Promise<void> {
        await exec(`ntm send ${session} ${target} ${quote(prompt)}`);
    }
}
```

### Extension Activation
Activate when:
- Workspace contains .ntm/ directory
- User runs NTM command
- NTM status bar clicked

## Priority Order

1. **P2**: Status bar + basic commands (NTM: Spawn, Send)
2. **P2**: Context injection (Send Selection)
3. **P3**: File decorations (requires Agent Mail)
4. **P3**: Session tree view
5. **P4**: Webview (if ever)

## Success Criteria

- [ ] Status bar shows current session
- [ ] Commands in palette for common actions
- [ ] "Send Selection to Agent" works with context
- [ ] Extension published to marketplace
- [ ] Minimal dependencies, fast activation
- [ ] Degrades gracefully if ntm not installed

Implement variable substitution
description:
Substitute variables in prompts and parse step outputs. Enables dynamic workflows.

VARIABLE TYPES:

1. USER VARIABLES (${vars.X}):
   - Provided at runtime: --var name=value
   - From variable file: --var-file vars.yaml
   - Default values from workflow definition

2. STEP OUTPUTS (${steps.X.output}):
   - Raw captured output from step
   - Trimmed (leading/trailing whitespace removed)
   
3. STEP METADATA (${steps.X.field}):
   - .pane: pane ID used
   - .duration: execution time
   - .status: completed/failed/skipped
   - .agent: agent type used

4. ENVIRONMENT (${env.X}):
   - From environment variables
   - Fail if not set (unless default provided)

5. CONTEXT:
   - ${session}: session name
   - ${timestamp}: current ISO8601 time
   - ${run_id}: pipeline run identifier
   - ${workflow}: workflow name

OUTPUT PARSING (Computed Variables):
```yaml
- id: get_count
  prompt: Return the count as a JSON object
  output_var: data
  output_parse: json  # parse as JSON
  
- id: use_count
  prompt: Process ${vars.data.count} items  # access JSON field!
```

PARSING MODES:
- none: raw string (default)
- json: parse as JSON, access fields with dot notation
- yaml: parse as YAML
- lines: split into array by newlines
- first_line: first line only (trim rest)
- regex: extract with named groups

REGEX PARSING:
```yaml
output_parse: 
  type: regex
  pattern: "Count: (?P<count>\\d+)"
  
# Access: ${vars.result.count}
```

DEFAULT VALUES:
```yaml
vars:
  env:
    default: "development"
    
# Usage with fallback
${vars.undefined_var | "fallback_value"}
```

ESCAPING:
To use literal ${}, escape with backslash: \${not.a.var}

IMPLEMENTATION:
```go
func (s *Substitutor) Substitute(template string, state *ExecutionState) (string, error) {
    // Find all ${...} patterns
    pattern := regexp.MustCompile(`\$\{([^}]+)\}`)
    
    return pattern.ReplaceAllStringFunc(template, func(match string) string {
        varPath := extractPath(match)
        value, err := s.resolveVar(varPath, state)
        if err != nil {
            // Check for default: ${var | "default"}
            if default := extractDefault(match); default != "" {
                return default
            }
            return match // leave unsubstituted, will error later
        }
        return fmt.Sprint(value)
    })
}

func (s *Substitutor) resolveVar(path string, state *ExecutionState) (interface{}, error) {
    parts := strings.Split(path, ".")
    
    switch parts[0] {
    case "vars":
        return state.Variables[parts[1:]]
    case "steps":
        return state.Steps[parts[1]].Get(parts[2:])
    case "env":
        return os.Getenv(parts[1]), nil
    // ... other types
    }
}
```

LOCATION: internal/pipeline/variables.go (new file)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- All variable types resolve correctly
- JSON/YAML parsing works with field access
- Regex parsing with named groups works
- Default values applied
- Escaping works
- Clear errors for undefined variables
- Nested field access works (${vars.data.nested.field})

description:
# Dynamic GoReleaser Config Parsing for Test Expectations

## Overview
Currently, TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract uses hardcoded expected values:
```go
{goos: "darwin", goarch: "arm64", wantArchive: "ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz"}
```

A more robust approach would parse .goreleaser.yaml at test time and generate expected asset names dynamically, creating a single source of truth.

## How It Would Work
1. Read .goreleaser.yaml at test time
2. Parse the archives.name_template field
3. Parse universal_binaries config for macOS "all" handling
4. Render template with test values (Version, Os, Arch)
5. Compare rendered output against getAssetName()/getArchiveAssetName()

## Technical Challenges

### 1. Template Parsing Complexity
GoReleaser uses Go text/template with custom functions:
```yaml
name_template: >-
  {{ .ProjectName }}_
  {{- .Version }}_
  {{- .Os }}_
  {{- .Arch }}
  {{- if .Arm }}v{{ .Arm }}{{ end }}
```

We'd need to:
- Parse YAML structure
- Extract template string (may span multiple lines)
- Replicate GoReleaser's template context variables
- Handle custom template functions (if any used)

### 2. Universal Binary Detection
The "all" arch for macOS comes from a separate config section:
```yaml
universal_binaries:
  - id: ntm-universal
    replace: true
```

Need to detect this and adjust arch expectations accordingly.

### 3. Format Override Handling
Windows uses .zip instead of .tar.gz via format_overrides:
```yaml
format_overrides:
  - goos: windows
    formats:
      - zip
```

### 4. Edge Cases
- Multiple archive definitions with different IDs
- ARM version suffixes (armv7)
- Future GoReleaser template syntax changes
- YAML parsing edge cases (multi-line strings, anchors)

## Trade-off Analysis

### Current Approach (Hardcoded)
**Pros**:
+ Simple to understand and debug
+ Fast test execution (no YAML parsing overhead)
+ No external dependencies beyond Go stdlib
+ Explicit about what's expected (serves as documentation)
+ Changes require conscious update (catches unintended changes)

**Cons**:
- Manual updates when convention changes
- Could drift from actual config (mitigated by CI checks)
- New platforms require test updates

### Dynamic Approach
**Pros**:
+ Auto-adapts to config changes
+ Single source of truth (DRY)
+ New platforms auto-covered if config updated

**Cons**:
- Complex implementation (~200+ lines)
- Slower tests (YAML parsing, template rendering)
- Fragile if GoReleaser template syntax changes
- Harder to debug when tests fail (which source is wrong?)
- Requires yaml dependency (go-yaml/yaml)

## Recommendation
**Keep on backlog (P4)**. The current approach is "good enough" because:

1. Contract tests catch logic errors at development time
2. CI upgrade-check validates against real published releases
3. Post-release verification catches edge cases
4. Naming convention changes are rare and intentional (maybe 1x/year)
5. The explicit hardcoded values serve as documentation

**When to implement**:
- If naming convention changes frequently (>2x/year)
- If team grows and knowledge transfer becomes critical
- If GoReleaser adds features that make parsing simpler
- If someone has spare cycles and wants the elegance

## Priority: P4 (Backlog)
Nice-to-have optimization. Current protection is sufficient.

Implement error handling
description:
Handle step failures per configuration. Enables robust, recoverable workflows.

ERROR DETECTION:
1. Timeout exceeded - step didn't complete in time
2. ERROR state detected - agent hit an error (from Activity Detection)
3. Agent crashed - process exited
4. Output validation failed - expected pattern not found
5. Condition evaluation error - invalid expression

ERROR HANDLING MODES:

1. FAIL (default):
   - Stop pipeline immediately
   - Mark pipeline as failed
   - Trigger error notification
   - Persist state for potential resume

2. CONTINUE:
   - Log error
   - Mark step as failed
   - Continue to next step
   - Skip steps that depend on failed step
   - Pipeline completes with partial success

3. RETRY:
   - Retry step N times with delay
   - Configurable: count, delay, backoff
   - After max retries: fall back to on_error

RETRY CONFIGURATION:
```yaml
steps:
  - id: flaky_step
    prompt: Call external API
    on_error: retry
    retry_count: 3
    retry_delay: 10s
    retry_backoff: exponential  # linear, exponential, none
    retry_max_delay: 2m
```

ERROR ESCALATION:
```yaml
settings:
  # Escalation for critical failures
  escalate_errors: true
  escalate_webhook: https://pagerduty...
  escalate_mail: "on-call-agent"
  escalate_after: 2  # after 2 failed retries
```

ERROR CONTEXT:
Capture rich error context for debugging:
```go
type StepError struct {
    StepID      string
    Type        ErrorType  // timeout, agent_error, crash, validation
    Message     string
    Details     string     // full error output
    Attempt     int        // which retry attempt
    Timestamp   time.Time
    AgentState  AgentState
    PaneOutput  string     // last N lines of pane
}
```

PARTIAL ROLLBACK (Future):
Not in scope for v1, but design for future:
- Define rollback steps per step
- On failure, execute rollback in reverse order

NOTIFICATION INTEGRATION:
- On step failure (with retry): notify if configured

title: Implement --robot-ack for send confirmation
description:
Track and confirm message receipt by agents.

## Rationale
After --robot-send, I need to know:
1. Did the agent receive the message?
2. Did the agent acknowledge understanding?
3. Is the agent actively working on it?

Without this, I'm blind after sending - I have to poll tail output and parse for confirmation patterns.

## Proposal: Ack Tracking
When sending with --robot-send --track, ntm:
1. Watches pane output for acknowledgment patterns
2. Returns structured confirmation

## Output Structure
```json
{
  "session": "myproject",
  "sent_at": "ISO8601",
  "confirmations": [
    {
      "pane": "0.1",
      "ack_type": "prompt_returned",  // agent showed ready prompt
      "ack_at": "ISO8601",
      "latency_ms": 234
    },
    {
      "pane": "0.2",
      "ack_type": "echo_detected",    // agent echoed input
      "ack_at": "ISO8601",
      "latency_ms": 156
    }
  ],
  "pending": ["0.3"],  // still waiting
  "failed": []
}
```

## Ack Detection Patterns
- prompt_returned: Agent shows ready prompt after processing
- echo_detected: Input echoed in pane (basic confirmation)
- explicit_ack: Agent responds with understood/acknowledged
- output_started: Agent begins producing output

## Timeout Handling
--timeout=30s - wait up to 30s for acks
Returns partial result with pending list if timeout

## Overview

## Routing Logic Enhancement

### Current Routing (from Smart Distribution)
Routes based on:
- Agent type capability
- Current load
- Activity state

### Enhanced Routing with Profiles
Add profile tag matching:
```go
type RoutingContext struct {
    Task        string   // task description
    TaskTags    []string // extracted task tags (from analysis)
    Preferences RoutePreferences
}

func (r *Router) FindBestAgent(ctx RoutingContext) (*Agent, float64) {
    candidates := r.GetAvailableAgents()
    
    for _, agent := range candidates {
        score := r.baseScore(agent, ctx)
        
        // Boost score for profile tag matches
        if agent.Profile != nil {
            tagMatch := computeTagOverlap(ctx.TaskTags, agent.Profile.Tags)
            score += tagMatch * r.config.ProfileBoostWeight
        }
        
        // Focus pattern matching (if task mentions files)
        if agent.Profile != nil && len(agent.Profile.FocusPatterns) > 0 {
            fileMatch := computePatternMatch(ctx.MentionedFiles, agent.Profile.FocusPatterns)
            score += fileMatch * r.config.PatternBoostWeight
        }
    }
    
    return bestCandidate, bestScore
}
```

### Task Tag Extraction
Extract likely tags from task description:
- "write tests" -> [test, qa]
- "review the PR" -> [review]
- "design the API" -> [design, architecture, api]
- "update README" -> [docs, documentation]

title: Post-release upgrade verification job
description:
# Post-Release Upgrade Verification Job

## What This Accomplishes
After GoReleaser publishes release assets, tests `ntm upgrade --check` on ALL target platforms to verify assets are discoverable before announcing the release.

## Implementation Details
**File**: .github/workflows/release.yml:160-217 (61 lines added)
**Job Name**: upgrade-verify

**Matrix** (all platforms GoReleaser builds for):
| Runner | GOOS | GOARCH | Notes |
|--------|------|--------|-------|
| ubuntu-latest | linux | amd64 | Primary Linux target |
| macos-latest | darwin | arm64 | Apple Silicon |
| macos-13 | darwin | amd64 | Intel Mac |
| windows-latest | windows | amd64 | WSL users |

**Workflow**:
1. Wait for `release` job to complete
2. Checkout, setup Go
3. Build ntm from release tag source
4. Run `ntm upgrade --check`
5. Verify no "no suitable release asset" error
6. If pass on all platforms ‚Üí proceed to announce

## Why This Is The Last Line of Defense
Even if contract tests and CI pass, this catches:
1. GoReleaser template rendering issues (variables resolve differently in release context)
2. Asset upload failures (asset exists locally but upload failed or wrong name)
3. Platform-specific edge cases (case sensitivity differences between OS)
4. GitHub API issues (asset uploaded but not immediately visible via API)
5. Race conditions between upload and verification

## Dependency Chain Impact
```yaml
announce:
  needs: [release, verify, upgrade-verify]  # Added upgrade-verify
```

**What this means**:
- Release IS published (users CAN find it manually on GitHub)
- But announcement is blocked until upgrade verified
- Gives maintainers time to fix before broad awareness
- Balances "release early" with "verify before announce"

## Failure Handling Strategy
If upgrade-verify fails:
1. Release exists on GitHub (NOT rolled back - too dangerous)
2. Announce job is skipped (no tweets, no notifications)
3. Maintainer notified via GitHub Actions failure email
4. Can publish fix release and re-run workflow
5. Or manually announce after investigation

## Design Decision: Why Not Rollback?
We don't rollback failed releases because:
1. Some users may have already downloaded
2. Rollback is a destructive, irreversible operation
3. Publishing a fix is safer and creates audit trail
4. GitHub Releases don't have great rollback support
5. Fix-forward is the standard approach

## Design Decision: Windows Included Here
Unlike CI check, Windows IS included because:
1. This tests actual release assets, not just build
2. Windows users with WSL use ntm via upgrade command
3. This is the final verification before announce - must be comprehensive

## Commit Reference
7c57a6c ci: add upgrade asset naming contract tests and verification

comments.author: jemanuel
comments.text:
## AI Agent Integration Guidance

**KEY PRINCIPLE**: Flag documentation should be discoverable FROM THE OUTPUT, not just --help.

**SELF-DOCUMENTING ERROR PATTERN**:
When an agent uses a flag incorrectly, the error should teach:
```json
{
  "success": false,
  "error_code": "MISSING_REQUIRED_FLAG",
  "error": "--msg is required when using --robot-send",
  "_flag_docs": {
    "msg": {
      "description": "Message content to send to agents",
      "required_with": ["--robot-send"],
      "optional_with": ["--robot-ack"],
      "example": "--msg=\"Fix the auth bug\""
    }
  },
  "_agent_hints": {
    "suggested_command": "ntm --robot-send=myproject --msg=\"your message\""
  }
}
```

**RATIONALE**: AI agents don't read --help before trying commands. By embedding flag documentation in error responses, we enable agents to self-correct without external documentation lookup.

**DISCOVERABILITY COMMAND**:
Consider adding `ntm --robot-help=send` that returns JSON documentation:
```json
{
  "command": "--robot-send",
  "description": "Send message to agent panes",
  "required_flags": ["--msg"],
  "optional_flags": ["--panes", "--type", "--all"],
  "examples": [...]
}
```

    LastVisible  int  // Index of last visible item

title: Implement graceful degradation before rotation
description:
## Overview
Before rotating an agent, try to extend its useful life by requesting compaction.

## Location
Create `internal/context/compact.go`

## Compaction Strategies

### Strategy 1: Ask Agent to Summarize
Send a special prompt:
```
[System] Your context window is getting full. Please:
1. Summarize the key points of our conversation so far
2. Note any critical context that must be preserved
3. After this summary, I will help you continue with fresh context

Please provide this summary now.
```

### Strategy 2: Trigger Built-in Summarization
If Claude Code supports /compact or similar:
```go
func (c *Compactor) TriggerBuiltinCompact(session, paneID string) error {
    // Send /compact command if supported
    return tmux.SendKeys(session, paneID, "/compact")
}
```

### Strategy 3: Clear Non-Essential History
If Claude Code supports selective history clearing:
- Keep system prompt and recent N messages
- Clear middle history

## Compaction Flow
```go
type CompactionResult struct {
    Success         bool
    TokensReclaimed int64
    NewUsagePercent float64
    Method          string
}

func (c *Compactor) TryCompact(session, agentID string) (*CompactionResult, error) {
    // 1. Check current context usage
    before := c.monitor.GetState(agentID).UsagePercent
    
    // 2. Try built-in compaction if available
    if c.supportsBuiltinCompact(agentID) {
        c.TriggerBuiltinCompact(session, agentID)
        time.Sleep(5 * time.Second)
    }
    
    // 3. If still high, ask for summary
    if c.monitor.GetState(agentID).UsagePercent > c.config.RotateThreshold {
        c.RequestSummarization(session, agentID)
        time.Sleep(10 * time.Second)
    }
    
    // 4. Check result
    after := c.monitor.GetState(agentID).UsagePercent
    
    return &CompactionResult{
        Success:         after < before - 0.1, // At least 10% reduction
        TokensReclaimed: int64((before - after) * float64(c.getLimit(agentID))),
        NewUsagePercent: after,
    }, nil
}
```

## When to Trigger
- At warning_threshold (e.g., 60%)
- User can manually trigger via dashboard
- Before rotation is attempted

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Detect if built-in compact available
- [ ] Summarization request prompt
- [ ] Wait and verify compaction worked
- [ ] Track tokens reclaimed
- [ ] Integration with rotation flow
- [ ] Tests for compaction scenarios

title: Documentation for upgrade naming contract
description:
# Documentation for Upgrade Naming Contract

## Purpose
Create documentation explaining the relationship between .goreleaser.yaml and internal/cli/upgrade.go so future maintainers can safely evolve the naming convention without breaking upgrade.

## Target Audience
1. **Future maintainers** modifying GoReleaser config or upgrade logic
2. **Contributors** adding support for new platforms
3. **Developers** debugging upgrade failures
4. **Reviewers** evaluating naming-related PRs

## Proposed Content Structure

### 1. Overview Section
```markdown
## Release Infrastructure

### Upgrade Command & Asset Naming

The `ntm upgrade` command downloads release assets from GitHub Releases.
For this to work, upgrade.go must know exactly what asset names GoReleaser produces.

This creates a "naming contract" between two files:
- `.goreleaser.yaml`: Defines asset names via templates
- `internal/cli/upgrade.go`: Contains logic to find and match assets

If these drift apart, users get "no suitable release asset found" errors.
The contract is enforced by TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract in cli_test.go.
```

### 2. Naming Convention Reference
```markdown
### Current Naming Convention

**Archives (tar.gz/zip)**:
Pattern: `ntm_{version}_{os}_{arch}.{ext}`

**Raw Binaries**:
Pattern: `ntm_{os}_{arch}`

**Special Cases**:
| Case | Convention | Reason |
|------|-----------|--------|
| macOS | Uses "all" instead of arch | Universal binary (arm64+amd64) |
| Windows | Uses .zip instead of .tar.gz | Native Windows archive format |
| ARM Linux | Uses "armv7" suffix | Distinguish from arm64 |

**Examples**:
| Platform | Archive Name | Binary Name |
|----------|-------------|-------------|
| macOS ARM | ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz | ntm_darwin_all |
| macOS Intel | ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz | ntm_darwin_all |
| Linux x64 | ntm_1.4.1_linux_amd64.tar.gz | ntm_linux_amd64 |
| Windows | ntm_1.4.1_windows_amd64.zip | ntm_windows_amd64 |
```

### 3. Safe Change Checklist
```markdown
### Changing the Naming Convention

Before making ANY changes to asset naming:

1. **Understand the contract**:
   - Read this document fully
   - Review TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract in cli_test.go

2. **Update both files together**:
   - [ ] .goreleaser.yaml: Update name_template
   - [ ] internal/cli/upgrade.go: Update getAssetName()/getArchiveAssetName()
   - [ ] internal/cli/cli_test.go: Update TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract expected values

3. **Verify locally**:
   ```bash
   go test -v -run TestUpgradeAsset ./internal/cli/
   ```

4. **CI will validate**:
   - upgrade-check job tests against latest release
   - If naming changed, expect CI to fail until new release with new naming

5. **After release**:
   - upgrade-verify job confirms all platforms can find assets
```

### 4. Troubleshooting Guide
```markdown
### Troubleshooting Upgrade Failures

**Error: "no suitable release asset found for X/Y"**

This means upgrade.go couldn't find a matching asset. Common causes:

1. **Naming convention mismatch**: 
   - Check actual names on https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/ntm/releases/latest
   - Compare against TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract expectations

2. **GoReleaser config changed**:
   - Check recent changes to .goreleaser.yaml
   - Verify archives.name_template matches upgrade.go logic

3. **New platform not supported**:
   - Add platform to getAssetName()/getArchiveAssetName()
   - Add test case to TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract

**Error: CI upgrade-check failing**
- Current code can't find assets from latest release
- Either roll back code change or cut new release with compatible naming
```

## Why Documentation Matters
Without docs, future maintainers might:
- Remove "unnecessary" tests that protect against regressions
- Change one file without updating the other
- Not understand CI failures
- Re-introduce bugs we've already fixed and protected against

## Priority: P2 (Medium)
High maintainability value. Low implementation effort (~1-2 hours).
design:

[Table with examples]

### Making Changes Safely
[Step-by-step checklist]

### Troubleshooting

## Keep In Sync Strategy
- Docs live close to code (same repo)
- Reference specific test names so docs stay testable
- Annual review reminder (can be a bead)

title: EPIC: Session Persistence & Recovery
description:
Sessions survive reboots and can be recreated from saved state.

## Problem Statement
Tmux sessions are ephemeral - a reboot or accidental kill loses everything:
- Agent counts, types, and arrangements must be manually recreated
- Working directory and project context is lost
- No way to 'bookmark' a useful session configuration
- Users avoid rebooting to preserve valuable sessions

## Goals
1. Capture complete session state (agents, layout, cwd, env)
2. Enable session recreation from saved state
3. Support periodic auto-snapshots for safety
4. Make session configs portable across machines

## Success Criteria
- `ntm session save` captures full session state to disk
- `ntm session restore` recreates session exactly
- Auto-snapshot on session creation (optional)
- `ntm session list --saved` shows available saved sessions

## Technical Approach
- Session state stored as JSON in ~/.local/share/ntm/sessions/
- Capture: session name, cwd, agent types/counts, layout, pane titles
- Restore: create session, spawn agents, apply layout
- Handle conflicts (session already exists) gracefully

## State Schema
```json
{
  "name": "myproject",
  "cwd": "/path/to/project",
  "agents": {"cc": 2, "cod": 1, "gmi": 1},
  "layout": "tiled",
  "panes": [{"title": "myproject__cc_1", "command": "claude"}],
  "created": "2025-12-10T10:00:00Z",
  "saved": "2025-12-10T12:00:00Z"
}
```

## User Value
- Fearless reboots - sessions are recoverable
- Consistent project setups across machines
- Reduced friction starting work each day
- Backup for accidental session kills

title: Session State Capture
description:
Capture complete session state to JSON for later restoration.

## State to Capture
```go
type SessionState struct {
    // Identity
    Name      string    `json:"name"`
    SavedAt   time.Time `json:"saved_at"`
    
    // Context
    WorkDir   string    `json:"cwd"`
    GitBranch string    `json:"git_branch,omitempty"`
    GitRemote string    `json:"git_remote,omitempty"`
    
    // Agent Configuration
    Agents    AgentSpec `json:"agents"`  // {cc: 2, cod: 1, gmi: 1}
    
    // Pane Details (for exact recreation)
    Panes     []PaneState `json:"panes"`
    
    // Layout
    Layout    string    `json:"layout"`  // "tiled", "even-horizontal", etc.
    
    // Metadata
    CreatedAt time.Time `json:"created_at"`  // Original session creation
    Version   int       `json:"version"`     // Schema version for migrations
}

type PaneState struct {
    Title     string `json:"title"`      // e.g., "myproject__cc_1"
    Index     int    `json:"index"`
    AgentType string `json:"agent_type"` // "cc", "cod", "gmi", "user"
    Command   string `json:"command"`    // The agent launch command
    Active    bool   `json:"active"`     // Was this the active pane?
}
```

## Capture Process
1. Get session info from tmux
2. Get all panes with metadata
3. Detect working directory (from pane 0 or explicit)
4. Get git context if in repo
5. Serialize to JSON
6. Write to storage location

## Command Interface
```bash
ntm session save                 # Save current session (in tmux)
ntm session save myproject       # Save specific session
ntm session save --name=alias    # Save with custom name
ntm session save --overwrite     # Overwrite existing save
```

## Storage
Location: ~/.local/share/ntm/sessions/<name>.json

Directory structure:
```
~/.local/share/ntm/sessions/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ myproject.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ frontend.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ backend.json
```

## Implementation
```go
func CaptureSessionState(sessionName string) (*SessionState, error) {
    session, err := tmux.GetSession(sessionName)
    if err \!= nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    
    panes, err := tmux.GetPanes(sessionName)
    if err \!= nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    
    // Extract agent configuration from pane names
    agents := countAgents(panes)
    
    // Get working directory
    cwd := detectWorkDir(panes)
    
    // Get git info if applicable
    gitBranch, gitRemote := getGitInfo(cwd)
    
    return &SessionState{
        Name:      sessionName,
        SavedAt:   time.Now(),
        WorkDir:   cwd,
        GitBranch: gitBranch,
        GitRemote: gitRemote,
        Agents:    agents,
        Panes:     mapPaneStates(panes),
        Layout:    session.Layout,
        CreatedAt: session.Created,
        Version:   1,
    }, nil
}
```

## Files to Create
- internal/session/state.go - State data structures
- internal/session/capture.go - Capture logic
- internal/session/storage.go - File I/O

title: Session Restore Command
description:
Recreate sessions from saved state.

## Command Interface
```bash
ntm session restore myproject           # Restore saved session
ntm session restore myproject --force   # Overwrite if exists
ntm session restore myproject --attach  # Attach after restore
ntm session restore --list              # List available saves
```

## Restore Process
1. Load saved state from JSON
2. Check if session already exists
   - If exists and no --force, error out
   - If exists and --force, kill existing first
3. Create new tmux session
4. Create panes with correct agent commands
5. Apply saved layout
6. Optionally attach

## Implementation
```go
func RestoreSession(state *SessionState, force bool) error {
    // Check for existing session
    if tmux.SessionExists(state.Name) {
        if \!force {
            return fmt.Errorf("session '%s' already exists (use --force to overwrite)", state.Name)
        }
        tmux.KillSession(state.Name)
    }
    
    // Create session with first pane
    err := tmux.CreateSession(state.Name, state.WorkDir)
    if err \!= nil {
        return err
    }
    
    // Create additional panes
    for i, pane := range state.Panes[1:] {
        err := tmux.CreatePane(state.Name, pane.Command)
        if err \!= nil {
            return fmt.Errorf("failed to create pane %d: %w", i+1, err)
        }
        tmux.RenamePane(state.Name, i+1, pane.Title)
    }
    
    // Apply layout
    tmux.ApplyLayout(state.Name, state.Layout)
    
    return nil
}
```

## Edge Cases

### Working Directory Missing
If saved cwd doesn't exist:
- Warn user
- Fall back to /Users/jemanuel
- Or create directory if it looks like a project path

### Agent Commands Changed
Config may have changed agent commands since save:
- Use current config commands, not saved commands
- Saved commands are for reference/debugging

### Git State
Optionally restore git context:
- `--checkout` flag to checkout saved branch
- Default: just warn if branch differs

## Conflict Resolution
```bash
$ ntm session restore myproject
Error: session 'myproject' already exists

Options:
  --force    Kill existing and restore
  --rename   Restore as 'myproject-restored'
  --merge    Add missing agents to existing (not implemented)
```

## List Saved Sessions
```bash
$ ntm session list --saved
NAME         SAVED AT              AGENTS      CWD
myproject    2025-12-10 10:00:00   cc:2 cod:1  /home/user/myproject
frontend     2025-12-09 15:30:00   cc:3        /home/user/frontend
```

## Files to Create
- internal/cli/session_restore.go - Command
- internal/session/restore.go - Restore logic

title: EPIC: Per-Project Configuration
description:
Project-specific settings, defaults, and palettes via .ntm/ directory.

## Problem Statement
All NTM configuration is global (~/.config/ntm/):
- Different projects may need different agent mixes
- Project-specific palette commands aren't discoverable
- Team members can't share project NTM settings via git
- No way to 'just clone and go' with project-specific agent setup

## Goals
1. Auto-detect .ntm/ directory in project roots
2. Support project-specific config that overrides/merges with global
3. Enable project palettes (command_palette.md in .ntm/)
4. Make project NTM config git-committable for team sharing

## Success Criteria
- `ntm spawn` in project uses .ntm/config.toml defaults
- `ntm palette` includes .ntm/palette.md commands
- Config precedence: CLI flags > project > global > defaults
- `ntm config project init` creates .ntm/ scaffold

## Directory Structure
```
myproject/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .ntm/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.toml      # Project overrides
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ palette.md       # Project-specific commands
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/       # Project templates
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ review.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
```

## Config Merge Rules
1. Project config extends (not replaces) global config
2. Explicit values in project override global
3. Arrays (like palette commands) are merged
4. CLI flags always win

## Example .ntm/config.toml
```toml
[defaults]
agents = { cc = 2, cod = 1 }  # No Gemini for this project

[palette]
# Extends global palette
file = ".ntm/palette.md"

[templates]
# Project-specific templates
pr_review = "Review this PR for our coding standards..."
```

## User Value
- Clone repo, run ntm spawn, get project-appropriate setup
- Share team conventions via committed config
- Different projects can have different agent strategies
- Palette commands tailored to project needs

title: Project Config Discovery (.ntm/)
description:
Auto-detect and load .ntm/ directory configuration from project roots.

## Overview
When running NTM commands in a project directory, automatically discover and load .ntm/config.toml to customize behavior per-project.

## Directory Structure
```
myproject/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .ntm/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.toml      # Project settings
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ palette.md       # Project commands
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/       # Project templates
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
```

## Discovery Algorithm
```go
func FindProjectConfig(startDir string) (*ProjectConfig, error) {
    dir := startDir
    for {
        configPath := filepath.Join(dir, ".ntm", "config.toml")
        if fileExists(configPath) {
            return LoadProjectConfig(configPath)
        }
        
        parent := filepath.Dir(dir)
        if parent == dir { // Reached root
            return nil, nil // No project config
        }
        dir = parent
    }
}
```

## Config Merge Order
1. Hardcoded defaults (in binary)
2. Global config (~/.config/ntm/config.toml)
3. Project config (.ntm/config.toml)
4. CLI flags

Later sources override earlier ones.

```go
func LoadMergedConfig() *Config {
    cfg := DefaultConfig()
    
    if global, err := LoadGlobalConfig(); err == nil {
        cfg = MergeConfig(cfg, global)
    }
    
    if project, err := FindProjectConfig(cwd); err == nil && project != nil {
        cfg = MergeConfig(cfg, project)
    }
    
    return cfg
}
```

## Project Config Schema
```toml
# .ntm/config.toml

# Default agent counts when spawning
[defaults]
agents = { cc = 2, cod = 1 }  # No Gemini for this project

# Project palette extends global
[palette]
file = "palette.md"  # Relative to .ntm/

# Project templates extend global
[templates]
dir = "templates"  # Relative to .ntm/

# Custom agent commands for this project
[agents]
# Override default Claude command
claude = "claude --project /path/to/claude-config"
```

## Init Command
```bash
ntm config project init           # Create .ntm/ scaffold
ntm config project init --force   # Overwrite existing
```

Creates:
```
.ntm/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.toml    # With comments explaining options
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ palette.md     # Empty palette scaffold
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/     # Empty directory
```

## Detection in Commands
All commands that use config should call merged config:
```go
func newSpawnCmd() *cobra.Command {
    return &cobra.Command{
        RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
            cfg := config.LoadMerged() // <-- Uses project config if present
            // ...
        },
    }
}
```

- internal/config/merge.go - Config merging logic
- internal/cli/config.go - Add 'project init' subcommand

title: Feature: Daemon Supervisor
description:
# Daemon Supervisor (internal/supervisor/)

## Purpose
Manages the lifecycle of long-running daemons (cm serve, bd daemon) that NTM spawns. Without this, daemons become orphaned, ports conflict, and there's no health monitoring.

## Why This Matters
- **Port conflicts**: Multiple NTM sessions could fight for same ports
- **Orphaned processes**: Daemons not cleaned up on session end
- **No recovery**: Crashed daemons not restarted
- **No logs**: Daemon output lost to void

## Interface
```go
type Supervisor struct {
    session    string
    projectDir string
    daemons    map[string]*ManagedDaemon
}

type DaemonSpec struct {
    Name        string   // "cm", "bd"
    Command     string   // "cm", "bd"
    Args        []string // ["serve", "--port", "8765"]
    HealthURL   string   // "http://127.0.0.1:8765/health"
    PortFlag    string   // "--port"
    DefaultPort int
}
```

## Key Behaviors
- Find available port if default taken
- Write PID file to .ntm/pids/<name>-<session>.pid
- Stream stdout/stderr to .ntm/logs/<name>-<session>.log
- Health check every 5 seconds
- Restart with exponential backoff on failure
- Stop on session end (but not if pre-existing)

## Ownership Rules
- If daemon PID file shows different owner, don't kill on session end
- Only kill what we started

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Supervisor.Start() finds available port
- [ ] PID files written under .ntm/pids/
- [ ] Logs captured to .ntm/logs/
- [ ] Health checks detect failed daemons
- [ ] Restart with backoff on crash
- [ ] Clean shutdown releases owned daemons only
close_reason: Implemented Daemon Supervisor with port allocation, PID file management, log capture, health checks, and restart with exponential backoff. Supports clean shutdown with ownership rules. Full build passes.

title: Feature: Agent Mail Macros Integration
description:
# Agent Mail Macros Integration

## The Problem
NTM currently makes 4-5 separate API calls to set up each agent:
1. ensure_project
2. register_agent
3. file_reservation_paths
4. fetch_inbox
(5. optionally more for thread preparation)

This is slow, error-prone, and requires handling partial failures.

## The Solution
Agent Mail provides macro commands that do everything in one call:
- macro_start_session: Bootstrap agent with registration + reservations + inbox
- macro_prepare_thread: Align agent with existing thread + LLM summary
- macro_file_reservation_cycle: Reserve ‚Üí work ‚Üí auto-release
- macro_contact_handshake: Establish inter-agent messaging permission

## Implementation (internal/agentmail/macros.go)
```go
type MacroStartSessionOptions struct {
    HumanKey              string   // Absolute path to project
    Program               string   // "claude-code", "codex-cli", etc.
    Model                 string   // "opus-4.5", etc.
    TaskDescription       string
    FileReservationPaths  []string
    FileReservationTTL    int
    InboxLimit            int
}

func (c *Client) StartSession(ctx context.Context, opts MacroStartSessionOptions) (*MacroStartSessionResult, error)
```

## Fallback Policy
If Agent Mail doesn't support macros (older version), fall back to granular calls. Use Tool Adapter to detect capabilities.

## New Commands
```bash
ntm spawn myproject --cc=2 --reserve="internal/**/*.go"
ntm spawn myproject --cc=1 --thread=FEAT-123
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] macro_start_session wrapper implemented
- [ ] macro_prepare_thread wrapper implemented
- [ ] Spawn uses macros by default
- [ ] Fallback to granular calls if macros unavailable
- [ ] Performance: 4-5 calls ‚Üí 1 call verified

## Parent Epic

func VisibleColumns(width int, columns []Column) (visible []Column, hidden int) {

}

EPIC: Plugin & Extension System
description:
Allow users to extend NTM with custom agents, commands, and hooks.

## Problem Statement

NTM currently supports three hardcoded agent types: Claude, Codex, Gemini.
Users may want to use other agents or customize behavior:

1. **Other AI Agents**: Cursor, Aider, Continue, OpenAI API, local LLMs
2. **Custom Workflows**: Project-specific commands and automation
3. **Integration Hooks**: Run scripts before/after NTM operations
4. **Team Customization**: Share agent configs across a team

Currently, users must fork NTM to add new agent types or modify behavior.

## Goals

1. Allow custom agent definitions via config files
2. Support custom commands as executable scripts
3. Provide hook system for pre/post command execution
4. Make plugins discoverable and easy to install
5. Document plugin development clearly

## Why This Matters

Extensibility enables:
- Immediate support for any new AI coding agent
- Project-specific workflows without code changes
- Team-shared configurations and standards
- Community plugin ecosystem
- Future-proofing against agent landscape changes

## Success Criteria

- Users can define custom agents in ~/.config/ntm/agents/
- ntm spawn myproject --cursor=2 (custom agent)
- Users can add commands via ~/.config/ntm/commands/
- ntm my-custom-command (runs script)
- Hooks fire at defined extension points
- ntm plugins list shows installed plugins

## Plugin Types

### 1. Agent Plugins (~/.config/ntm/agents/*.toml)

Define new agent types:

# cursor.toml
[agent]
name = "cursor"
alias = "cur"
command = "cursor --headless --ai-mode"
description = "Cursor AI editor"
default_tags = ["cursor", "editor"]

Usage: ntm spawn myproject --cursor=2

### 2. Command Plugins (~/.config/ntm/commands/*)

Executable scripts become commands:

#\!/bin/bash
# ~/.config/ntm/commands/sync-all
# Description: Sync all agents with latest code

for session in $(ntm list --json | jq -r '.[].name'); do
  ntm send "$session" --all "git pull && review changes"
done

Usage: ntm sync-all

### 3. Hook Plugins (~/.config/ntm/hooks/*)

Run before/after NTM commands:

# hooks.toml
[hooks.pre_send]
command = "~/.config/ntm/hooks/log-prompt.sh"
pass_args = true

[hooks.post_spawn]
command = "notify-send 'NTM' 'Session created'"

## Technical Approach

Plugin Discovery:
- Scan known directories on startup
- Cache plugin metadata for performance
- Reload on ntm plugins refresh

Agent Plugin Loading:
- Parse TOML to AgentConfig struct
- Register with spawn/add commands
- Generate shell integration aliases

Command Plugin Execution:
- Discover executables in commands/
- Run with NTM context in environment
- Pass JSON via stdin, capture stdout/stderr

Hook Execution:
- Define extension points in each command
- Run hooks synchronously (pre) or async (post)
- Pass command context as JSON
- Fail-safe: hook errors don't break NTM

## Security Considerations

- Plugins are user-installed, user-trusted
- No automatic plugin download/installation
- Clear documentation of execution context
- Hooks can see all command arguments
- Consider --no-hooks flag for sensitive operations

## Interaction with Other Features

- JSON Output: Plugin commands can use --json
- Config: Plugins extend config schema
- Remote: Plugins work locally, commands sent to remote
- Tags: Custom agents can have default tags

## Future Possibilities

- Plugin registry/marketplace
- Version pinning for plugins
- Plugin dependencies
- Programmatic plugin API (Go plugins)

title: Implement --robot-health for agent health matrix
description:
Focused health check returning responsiveness and activity metrics.

## Rationale
--robot-snapshot includes health data, but sometimes I just need a quick health check without the full state. This is the lightweight "are things working" query.

## Output Structure
```json
{
  "checked_at": "ISO8601",
  "system": {
    "tmux_ok": true,
    "disk_free_gb": 42.5,
    "load_avg": 1.2
  },
  "sessions": {
    "myproject": {
      "healthy": true,
      "agents": {
        "0.1": {"responsive": true, "output_rate": "high", "last_activity_sec": 2},
        "0.2": {"responsive": true, "output_rate": "low", "last_activity_sec": 45},
        "0.3": {"responsive": false, "issue": "no_output_5min"}
      }
    }
  },
  "alerts": ["0.3: no output 5min"]
}
```

## Health Heuristics
- responsive: has pane produced output recently AND is tmux pane alive
- output_rate: high (>1 line/sec), medium, low (<1 line/min), none
- last_activity_sec: time since last output line

## Alert Conditions
- No output for 5 minutes (configurable)
- Pane process exited
- High CPU in pane (if detectable)
- Disk space low
- Session unexpectedly killed

## Use Cases
1. Quick sanity check before sending batch instructions
2. Detect stuck agents for restart
3. System health monitoring
4. Pre-flight check before spawning more agents

title: Implement alerting system
description:
Notify users when agent health states change. Focuses on human-oriented alerting.

## Revised Scope (v2)

After discussion, Agent Mail integration is **out of scope** for this task because:
1. Agents already know how to use Agent Mail via MCP (documented in AGENTS.md)
2. If an agent is healthy enough to receive mail, it can send its own alerts
3. For crashes, the agent can't receive mail anyway - desktop/webhook is more appropriate
4. Adding Agent Mail writing to ntm creates coupling we don't need

## Alert Channels (In Scope)

### 1. DESKTOP NOTIFICATIONS
- Linux: notify-send
- macOS: osascript (display notification)
- Windows: PowerShell toast (future)
- Include: session, pane, state, action suggestion

### 2. WEBHOOKS
- POST to configured URL(s)
- JSON payload with full event details
- Retry with backoff on failure
- Support multiple webhook URLs

### 3. STRUCTURED LOG
- Always log to stderr with JSON
- For integration with log aggregators
- Enables downstream processing

## Out of Scope

- **Agent Mail writing**: Agents handle their own inter-agent communication
- Agents can send Agent Mail when they detect issues (they already know how)
- If we need cross-agent notification of health events, that's a future feature

## Alert Events

- State transitions: healthy‚Üídegraded, degraded‚Üíunhealthy
- Rate limiting detected
- Restart triggered (include context loss warning)
- Restart failed
- Max restarts exceeded

## Debouncing

Prevent alert spam on flapping agents:
- Min interval between same alert: 60s
- Aggregate repeated alerts in window
- Track alert history per pane

## Configuration

```toml
[alerts]
enabled = true
debounce_seconds = 60

# Desktop notifications
desktop_notify = true
desktop_urgency = "normal"  # low, normal, critical

# Webhooks (array)
[[alerts.webhooks]]
url = "https://hooks.slack.com/..."
events = ["unhealthy", "restart_failed"]

# Which events trigger alerts
alert_on = ["unhealthy", "rate_limited", "restart", "restart_failed"]
```

## Future Consideration

If we find strong need for ntm-to-Agent-Mail alerts, we can add:
- A webhook that POSTs to an Agent Mail bridge
- A config option to specify Agent Mail recipient
- But this is NOT required for v1

## Location

internal/robot/alerts.go

## Acceptance Criteria

- Desktop notifications work on Linux and macOS
- Webhooks fire correctly with retry
- Debouncing prevents spam
- All configured events trigger alerts
- Alert content is actionable

# Create internal/agentmail HTTP Client Package

## Purpose

Foundation for all Agent Mail integration. This package provides a clean Go interface to the MCP Agent Mail HTTP API.

## Technical Details

### Package Structure
```
internal/agentmail/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ client.go       # HTTP client with connection pooling, retries
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types.go        # Go structs matching Agent Mail data model
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tools.go        # Methods for each MCP tool (send_message, fetch_inbox, etc.)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ resources.go    # Methods for MCP resources (resource://inbox, etc.)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ errors.go       # Error types with Agent Mail error codes
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ client_test.go  # Unit tests with mock server
```

### Client Configuration
```go
type Client struct {
    baseURL     string       // Default: http://127.0.0.1:8765/mcp/
    bearerToken string       // From AGENT_MAIL_TOKEN or config
    httpClient  *http.Client // With timeouts, connection pooling
    projectKey  string       // Cached project path
}

func NewClient(opts ...Option) (*Client, error)
func (c *Client) IsAvailable() bool  // Health check
```

### Key Types (matching Agent Mail schema)
```go
type Agent struct {
    ID              int       `json:"id"`
    Name            string    `json:"name"`            // e.g., "GreenCastle"
    Program         string    `json:"program"`         // e.g., "claude-code"
    Model           string    `json:"model"`           // e.g., "opus-4.1"
    TaskDescription string    `json:"task_description"`
    LastActiveTS    time.Time `json:"last_active_ts"`
}

type Message struct {
    ID          int       `json:"id"`
    ThreadID    string    `json:"thread_id"`
    Subject     string    `json:"subject"`
    BodyMD      string    `json:"body_md"`
    From        string    `json:"from"`
    To          []string  `json:"to"`
    Importance  string    `json:"importance"`  // normal, high, urgent
    AckRequired bool      `json:"ack_required"`
    CreatedTS   time.Time `json:"created_ts"`
}

type FileReservation struct {
    ID          int       `json:"id"`
    PathPattern string    `json:"path_pattern"`
    AgentName   string    `json:"agent_name"`
    Exclusive   bool      `json:"exclusive"`
    Reason      string    `json:"reason"`
    ExpiresTS   time.Time `json:"expires_ts"`
}
```

### JSON-RPC 2.0 Protocol
Agent Mail uses JSON-RPC 2.0 over HTTP:
```go
type JSONRPCRequest struct {
    JSONRPC string      `json:"jsonrpc"` // "2.0"
    ID      interface{} `json:"id"`
    Method  string      `json:"method"`  // "tools/call"
    Params  struct {
        Name      string                 `json:"name"`
        Arguments map[string]interface{} `json:"arguments"`
    } `json:"params"`
}

type JSONRPCResponse struct {
    JSONRPC string          `json:"jsonrpc"`
    ID      interface{}     `json:"id"`
    Result  json.RawMessage `json:"result,omitempty"`
    Error   *JSONRPCError   `json:"error,omitempty"`
}
```

## Implementation Notes

- **Connection pooling**: Reuse HTTP connections; Agent Mail may be called frequently
- **Timeout handling**: 5s default for most operations, 30s for search/summarize
- **Retry logic**: Exponential backoff for transient failures (503, timeouts)
- **Bearer token**: Read from NTM config or AGENT_MAIL_TOKEN env var
- **Graceful degradation**: All methods return (result, error); callers handle missing server

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Client can connect to Agent Mail and verify health
- [ ] All MCP tools mapped to Go methods with proper types
- [ ] Error handling covers all Agent Mail error codes
- [ ] Unit tests with mock HTTP server
- [ ] Connection pooling verified with concurrent requests
- [ ] Timeout and retry behavior documented and tested

title: Upgrade Asset Naming Contract Protection System
description:
# Upgrade Asset Naming Contract Protection System

## Background & Origin
On 2026-01-05, we discovered that `ntm upgrade` failed on darwin/arm64 with:
"Error: no suitable release asset found for darwin/arm64"

This was a CONTRACT MISMATCH between two independent parts of the system:
1. `.goreleaser.yaml` - Defines how release assets are named (produces: ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz)
2. `internal/cli/upgrade.go` - Contains logic to find assets (expected: ntm-darwin-arm64)

The bug was only discovered when a USER reported it - the worst possible feedback loop.

## Root Cause Analysis
This is a classic "contract drift" problem:
- Two systems depend on an implicit contract (asset naming convention)
- Neither system validated the contract at build or release time
- Changes to one didn't automatically validate against the other
- No tests existed to catch the mismatch
- Bug reached production and users silently

## Solution Architecture: Defense in Depth
We implement a multi-layer protection strategy where each layer catches what the previous might miss:

**Layer 1: Contract Tests** (Development Time)
- Unit tests validate upgrade.go produces names matching GoReleaser conventions
- Runs on every `go test ./...`
- Catches issues immediately during development
- File: internal/cli/cli_test.go:TestUpgradeAssetNamingContract

**Layer 2: CI Upgrade Check** (Pre-Merge)
- GitHub Actions job runs `ntm upgrade --check` against latest release
- Tests on ubuntu-latest and macos-latest
- Catches drift before code is merged to main
- File: .github/workflows/ci.yml:upgrade-check

**Layer 3: Post-Release Verification** (Post-Release, Pre-Announce)
- After GoReleaser publishes, tests upgrade on ALL target platforms
- Matrix: Linux, macOS ARM, macOS Intel, Windows
- If it fails, release exists but announcement is blocked
- File: .github/workflows/release.yml:upgrade-verify

## Success Criteria
- No user ever encounters "no suitable release asset" again
- Any naming convention change is caught before release reaches users
- Clear error messages if something slips through the cracks
- Future maintainers understand the contract without external documentation

## Project Goals Served
- **User Trust**: Upgrade command "just works" on first try
- **Developer Velocity**: Bugs caught in CI, not via user reports
- **Maintainability**: Safe evolution of naming conventions
- **Quality**: Defense-in-depth with multiple validation layers

## Implementation Status
- Phase 1 (Core Protection): COMPLETE - Commit 7c57a6c
- Phase 2 (Enhanced UX): PLANNED - Error messages, documentation
- Phase 3 (Advanced): BACKLOG - Dynamic config parsing, fallback discovery

## Child Issues
See dependent tasks and features for implementation details.
close_reason: Core protection complete (P1-P3 tasks done). Remaining P4 items (dynamic config parsing, pre-commit hook) are on backlog per design doc.

title: Post-upgrade binary verification
description:
# Post-Upgrade Binary Verification

## Problem
Currently, upgrade replaces the binary and trusts it works. If something is wrong with the downloaded binary (corrupted, wrong architecture, etc.), the user discovers this when they next run ntm - potentially much later.

## Proposed Solution
After installing the new binary, immediately verify it works:

1. Run `<new-binary> version --short`
2. Verify output contains expected version number
3. If verification fails, offer to restore from backup (.old)
4. Only delete backup after verification passes

## User Experience

### Success Case
```
  Installing... ‚úì
  Verifying... ‚úì

  ‚úì Successfully upgraded to 1.4.1!
```

### Failure Case (Auto-Rollback Offered)
```
  Installing... ‚úì
  Verifying... ‚úó
  
  ‚ö† Verification failed: version mismatch (expected 1.4.1, got 1.3.0)
  
  The new binary may be corrupted or incompatible.
  Restore previous version? [Y/n] y
  
  ‚úì Previous version restored
  Please report this issue: https://github.com/Dicklesworthstone/ntm/issues
```

## Implementation Location
File: internal/cli/upgrade.go, after replaceBinary() call

## Verification Flow
```go
func verifyUpgrade(binaryPath, expectedVersion string) error {
    cmd := exec.Command(binaryPath, "version", "--short")
    output, err := cmd.Output()
    if err != nil {
        return fmt.Errorf("failed to run new binary: %w", err)
    }
    
    actualVersion := strings.TrimSpace(string(output))
    if !strings.Contains(actualVersion, expectedVersion) {
        return fmt.Errorf("version mismatch: expected %s, got %s", 
            expectedVersion, actualVersion)
    }
    return nil
}
```

## Rollback Logic
```go
// After replaceBinary succeeds but before removing backup
if err := verifyUpgrade(execPath, latestVersion); err != nil {
    fmt.Println(warnStyle.Render("‚ö† Verification failed:"), err)
    fmt.Print("Restore previous version? [Y/n] ")
    if shouldRestore {
        os.Rename(backupPath, currentBinaryPath)
        return fmt.Errorf("upgrade rolled back due to verification failure")
    }
}
// Only remove backup after verification passes
os.Remove(backupPath)
```

## Edge Cases
- New binary crashes on --version (catch exec error)
- Version format changed between releases (use flexible matching)
- Backup doesn't exist (shouldn't happen, but handle gracefully)
- Permission issues running new binary (sudo needed?)

## Why This Matters
- Catches corrupted downloads
- Catches wrong-architecture binaries (e.g., x64 on ARM without Rosetta)
- Catches GoReleaser misconfigurations that produce bad binaries
- Provides automatic recovery path
- Better than discovering broken binary on next use (could be days later)

## Acceptance Criteria
1. After installing new binary, runs basic verification
2. Executes new binary with --version flag
3. Verifies output matches expected new version
4. On verification failure, offers to restore backup (.old)
5. Verification happens before removing backup
6. Clear success/failure message to user
7. Exit code reflects verification status

## Priority: P2 (Medium)
High reliability value. Moderate implementation effort (~1-2 hours).

title: Download progress indicator for upgrade
description:
# Download Progress Indicator for Upgrade

## Problem
Currently, upgrade shows "Downloading..." with no indication of progress. For larger binaries (~15-20MB) on slower connections, users have no feedback about whether it's working or stuck.

## Current Behavior
```
  Downloading... [hangs for 10-30 seconds]
  ‚úì
```

## Proposed Behavior
```
  Downloading... 45% [=====>    ] 7.2/16.0 MB (1.2 MB/s, 7s remaining)
```

Or simpler spinner with size:
```
  Downloading... ‚†ã 7.2/16.0 MB
```

## Implementation

### Option 1: Progress Bar (Full Featured)
```go
type progressWriter struct {
    total      int64
    downloaded int64
    startTime  time.Time
    onProgress func(downloaded, total int64, speed float64)
}

func (pw *progressWriter) Write(p []byte) (int, error) {
    n := len(p)
    pw.downloaded += int64(n)
    elapsed := time.Since(pw.startTime).Seconds()
    speed := float64(pw.downloaded) / elapsed
    pw.onProgress(pw.downloaded, pw.total, speed)
    return n, nil
}

func downloadWithProgress(destPath, url string, size int64) error {
    // Use progressWriter as io.Writer wrapper
}
```

### Option 2: Spinner with Size (Simpler)
```go
func downloadWithSpinner(destPath, url string, size int64) error {
    spinner := []string{"‚†ã", "‚†ô", "‚†π", "‚†∏", "‚†º", "‚†¥", "‚†¶", "‚†ß", "‚†á", "‚†è"}
    // Update spinner and downloaded size periodically
}
```

### Option 3: Use Bubble Tea Progress Component
ntm already uses Bubble Tea for TUI. Could use its progress component.
```go
import "github.com/charmbracelet/bubbles/progress"

// Integrate with existing lipgloss styling
```

## Considerations

### Terminal Width
- Progress bar should adapt to terminal width
- Fall back to simpler format for narrow terminals (< 60 cols)

### Non-Interactive Mode
- If stdout not a TTY, use simple periodic updates:
  ```
  Downloaded 25%...
  Downloaded 50%...
  Downloaded 75%...
  Downloaded 100%
  ```

### Speed Calculation
- Use moving average for speed (last 5 seconds)
- Avoid jumpy speed estimates from burst downloads

### Content-Length Header
- GitHub provides Content-Length for release assets
- If missing, show downloaded size without percentage

## User Experience Examples

### Interactive (TTY)
```
  Downloading ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz...
  [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë] 60% 9.6/16.0 MB (2.1 MB/s)
```

### Non-Interactive (Pipe/Script)
```
  Downloading ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz...
  Progress: 25% (4.0/16.0 MB)
  Progress: 50% (8.0/16.0 MB)
  Progress: 75% (12.0/16.0 MB)
  Progress: 100% (16.0/16.0 MB)
  Download complete.
```

### Slow Connection
```
  Downloading ntm_1.4.1_darwin_all.tar.gz...
  [‚ñà‚ñà‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë‚ñë] 10% 1.6/16.0 MB (0.1 MB/s, ~2m remaining)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Shows download progress during upgrade
2. Displays downloaded/total bytes
3. Shows download speed (MB/s)
4. Estimates time remaining (for interactive mode)
5. Works in both interactive (TTY) and non-interactive modes
6. Handles missing Content-Length gracefully
7. Uses consistent lipgloss styling

## Why This Matters
- User feedback: Know download is progressing, not stuck
- Time estimation: Can decide to wait or cancel
- Debugging: If stuck at 0%, likely network issue
- Professionalism: Modern CLI tools show progress

## Priority: P3 (Low)
Nice UX improvement. Moderate implementation effort.
Not blocking - current behavior is functional, just not polished.

title: Implement seamless agent rotation
description:
## Overview
Execute the full rotation flow: spawn new agent, transfer context, kill old.

## Location
Create `internal/context/rotation.go`

## Rotation Flow
```
1. Detect agent at rotate_threshold
2. Mark agent as "rotating" (no new work)
3. Request handoff summary from agent
4. Wait for summary (with timeout)
5. Spawn new agent with same profile
6. Send handoff summary as initial context
7. Wait for new agent ready
8. Kill old agent pane
9. Update pane metadata
```

## Rotation Coordinator
```go
type Rotator struct {
    monitor  *ContextMonitor
    config   *ContextRotationConfig
    spawner  SpawnInterface
}

func (r *Rotator) CheckAndRotate(sessionName string) error {
    for _, agentID := range r.monitor.AgentsAboveThreshold(r.config.RotateThreshold) {
        if err := r.rotateAgent(sessionName, agentID); err != nil {
            return fmt.Errorf("rotation failed for %s: %w", agentID, err)
        }
    }
    return nil
}

func (r *Rotator) rotateAgent(session, agentID string) error {
    // 1. Get handoff summary
    summary, err := r.getHandoffSummary(session, agentID)
    
    // 2. Spawn replacement with same profile
    newAgentID, err := r.spawnReplacement(session, agentID)
    
    // 3. Initialize new agent with summary
    err = r.sendHandoffContext(session, newAgentID, summary)
    
    // 4. Kill old pane
    err = r.killOldAgent(session, agentID)
    
    // 5. Emit rotation event
    r.emitRotationEvent(agentID, newAgentID)
    
    return nil
}
```

## Edge Cases
- Rotation fails: keep old agent, alert user
- Summary timeout: rotate anyway with best-effort summary
- New agent fails to start: abort rotation
- Multiple agents need rotation: queue and rotate one at a time

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Full rotation flow implemented
- [ ] Graceful handling of failures
- [ ] Profile preservation on rotation
- [ ] Events emitted for monitoring
- [ ] Integration test with real tmux
